She looks grave for a fraction of a second, so that Den feels as though he has hit a nerve. Then her expression lightens and she smiles. “And now I have other things to attend to, so you will have to excuse me.”

She rises, as if commanding him to do the same. His renewed posturing has managed to annoy her, he can tell.

“Do you want to make a follow up appointment?” he asks. ”Perhaps you would like to visit me in London?”

She snorts, like a compassionate bull in the ring, smiling at the witless Matador out of pity. “I think that will not be necessary.”

He examines her cold planar face, looking for a hint that she might be impressed by some aspect of him.

The meter reads zero.

“I’ll show you out now, Mr. Morris.”

Dermot collapses at his desk. He should really work, but he is exhausted now. After fending off all the pedestrians in the busy streets, winding himself up over Christina, and going without sleep for several nights. It has drained him mentally and physically. With almost compulsive futility, he checks his messages one more time, sizing his own predicament; it is one of desperation.

I am a useless dependent, he thinks.

In the wild aftermath, after civilization fell, he would be dead meat. He would not survive without his computer. It isn’t really like a VR game, is it? It’s much harder without clear rules and a portable pizza oven. His combo subjects him to more humiliation: 

THE WORLD IS YOUR OYSTER!

ONLY YOU CAN MAKE YOUR DREAMS COME TRUE!

So much for inspiration. Thanks for the support.

He has come to the crime team’s offices, seeking refuge from his colleagues who have been taunting him and making him an object of fun, ever since he let slip about Christina. Seeking refuge in work is not always a story for success. He is still too agitated. There is adrenalin coursing through his veins, as if he is really a comic book nobody undergoing a transformation to superhero.

What is happening to my body? Got... to... eat... radioactive... spider!

It cannot continue. He has to do something. Bundling his fears, he punches the number into the combo and calls. It rings four times.

“Hello?” Christina’s voice says. She sounds confused or even annoyed as if she was not expecting anyone. Perhaps she was sleeping? It’s not late.

“Eh, hello, Christina, it’s eh me ... Dermot.”

“Oh hi,” she says, apparently relaxing. Perhaps she has forgotten about him until now.

“So what are you doing?”

“Nothing much.” The television is playing in the background.

“I wondered if you’d like to meet. I have that part for your computer.”

There is a slight pause and her voice becomes evasive. “Oh, no, I can’t. It’s such a mess here.”

“I don’t mind. Really. That doesn’t matter.”

He hears a laugh, a male voice, in response to some audience laughter on the television. She has company.

“I need to clean up first. I’ll call you another time.”

Adrenalin blindness. The room spins a little. “Okay,” he says simply.

“Okay, bye.” She cuts off the connection.

He feels numb and ridiculous. Lonely.

Preeta knocks hesitantly at his office, as if detecting his discomfort.

“Are you okay?” she asks.

He turns his head away, and tries to look busy. “Uh, yeah. What can I do for you?”

She cocks her head. “You look even paler than usual. You could use a break.”

“You look ... ” He considers lashing out, but reins himself in, like a good dog, snatching a glance at her. “Nice.” She probably doesn’t mean to be butting in on his affairs. It was a kind gesture to ask about him.

“Thank you very much,” she says with the very cute Indian lilt. “You know, I was wondering if you wanted to go out this evening. I haven’t had a chance to do anything like this for a long time. While I am here I want to sample the nightlife here, feel as though I am actually alive.”

Yes, alive. What is that exactly? “I am pretty busy... ”

“It looks as though you could do with a night off.”

“Yes.” He nods, mainly to himself. He is not doing anything useful. “Yes, I could.”

She edges her way into his office a little further, without invitation. She is trying to be nice to him. Why? Anyway, he should be grateful.

“Did I tell you what I found out?”

“What?”

“I am not a real person.”

Dermot looks at her, wondering what she is trying to say. “Well, don’t ask me. I can’t tell the difference.”

She grins, and he is forced to laugh at his own remark.

“I am a character in someone’s game.”

The humour drains out of him. “So, are you going to explain that, or just leave me guessing?”

“I found out. Your boss is part of a network that has been manipulating me, choreographing my moves ever since I started working on the game in Malaysia.”

“What? Why?”

“From what I can tell, they needed someone under cover to get inside the information in the game.”

“A spy?”

“An involuntary spy.”

“A stooge.”

“I suppose it amounts to that, doesn’t it? You know the strangest thing about it?”

“What?”

“I don’t really care.”

“You don’t care?”

She shrugs. “No, I don’t care.”

“Why not, I mean... ”

She meets his gaze. “I’m better off, aren’t I?”

He can identify with that.

“Do you think that attack on you was set up too?”

“What!?” A bolt of disgust breaks her expression. She gasps, bordering on a scream.

“The attack. You said you were kidnapped, I mean. Right?”

“What? You mean, it could have been engineered to bring me here?”

“Just an idea. What better way to make you help them than to make you think that a well-known enemy is out to get you. They step in to the rescue and bring you here. It all seems very convenient. ” There is a quiver in his voice, as if he realizes that he has gone too far.

Her eyes are wide and she precesses like a gyroscope in the doorway. “Would someone arrange an attack on me to manipulate me?”

“Well, we might do something like that in a game. So, I mean, you know, it could... It was just a thought.”

“Shut up! Don’t say it!”

“Just thinking out loud, sorry.”

The thought requires processing, but she drops it for now like a hot coal.

Not processing, not processing. No, no, no, no, no.

Not an idea to be entertained in her current frame of mind. Go away.

Dermot sees effect of the idea on her and feels responsible. Best to change the subject. “So anyway. That thing we are supposed to be doing now,”

“Stopping the Christians... ”

“Yes.” He suppresses an instinct to correct the details of what she said. That is a bad habit, a geek habit. That is not who he wants to be.

“What about it?”

“Got anywhere?”

She stares sulkily into space. “I was looking around and I had an idea.”

“What?”

She does not look happy. She came here perhaps to cheer him up and he has cut her down and made her feel as bad as he does.

“Would you like some tea?” he asks. “It’s from the Cameron Highlands, in Malaysia.”

Her trance breaks and she smiles with conciliatory eyes. “Thanks. That sounds nice. On one condition.”

“What?”

“You have to come out with me later, to a bar.”

A smile forms between them.

“All right then,” he says happily. This is progress. This is good. He has reached out and she accepted. Perhaps it doesn’t have to be so hard, after all. “Let me make some tea.”

“Black or green?” she asks.

“Black, plain or with vanilla.”

She smiles. “Plain, please. So, something else. I found a connection using my software. Some people here in Oslo who are working on environmental robots. They have some of the technology that we need. I don’t know how it works, but I figured that Bishop was going to want to know about it.”

“You told him?”

“Yes. He rushed off.”

Dermot is impressed. He would never have thought of that. She has been there for a couple of weeks now and already she is more imaginative than he is.

Consternation, over the ulcerated fabric of the city, racks his mood as they venture out into the chill winter vapours. It does not do to see the repairs that maintain the city’s appearance. No one wants to know of blemishes on the perfection of things. Pockmarks in the asphalt foundations are quietly being steam-rollered into denial by night-workers, under halogen illumination and flashing amber. The city is sinking into a marsh; like Atlantis, he thinks. How long do we have?

The homeless are hanging in the recesses of shuttered shop doorways now, as if driven out of their usual haunts by a gathering storm. Dermot’s mobile indicates that there is a police alert in the city tonight. A football game. That means there will be police everywhere. It is seldom that he ventures out of a tram or a bus at this time of day, in such caustic air. Besides, he is usually working. Dermot the action hero.

They are five puffed up blimps feeling their way forward, towards the a place rumoured to be known to one of them, none of them certain of where they are going. They are a blind gang leading a stranger through the night; rosy cheeks, slapped by the winter.

There should be more people here, shouldn’t there? Is it safe to be out at this time of day?

He feels conspicuous, walking with such a large group, avoiding cracks in the paving. They are standing out too much. The few people around are watching them. Where are the police? Why can’t they see any police? If they are suppose to be out in force, why aren’t they here?

As if to laugh at him, a black cat shifts in a shadow, raised momentarily from its smug camouflage by the tenderest kiss of ambient light.

“Let’s get out of here and go out tonight,” Preeta said.

“You go ahead. I’ll join you later maybe. I need to prepare something first.”

“Come on, Dermot,” Preeta said. “Take a break. Let’s go out and have a good time!” She smiled, bearing a wicked streak. “I’ve always been a bit of a rebel, you know.”

Preeta said, Preeta said. What was he thinking? He had been absorbed by his work for almost a full day, but the suggestion arrested his thoughts abruptly. It touched a primal contact within him, unleashing a spark of arousal. It would be good for him to get out and see people in a social situation. His heart beat suddenly to the rhythm of a different drum.

Dermot seemed to glide down the corridor without feeling his feet touch the ground. He could have been floating or levitating from the attention; if he were only attached to reality at all he might have realized that all he was missing was the very cause of his elation. But he was feeling good, on a cloud, and every worldly tether seemed beyond him at that moment. Break free–burn the candle at both ends. Progress.

But now his nerve is shaken. After work activity is not common here. People are usually just glad to get home at the end of a day. We do not know how to socialize. Some of the older people have families and the younger people just aren’t in the habit. This is breaking new ground.

Their short walk passes, free of incident and they arrive in a small side street amongst a few shops which nest in the ground floors of the four-story flats: the restaurant is really not that far from the police building. Dermot observes a pub next door filled with long and flamboyant leather coats, and black dyed hair, boots and metallic studs. It is a room that seems removed from the rest of this Asian area, like a puzzle to be solved, but he is not in the game now. It must be a real meeting place for these black haired denizens. He begins to feel daring.

Little Saigon. The restaurant is not very James Bond. There are no glamorous dresses and shirt-tails, no roulette tables and exotic bars. The brown Formica tables and orange plastic seats belong to a different stratum and age, but the food is tasty. Garlic and chilli, wrapped in plastic, peanuts and mint, crunch inside his mouth. Small candles flicker in appreciation of their custom.

“This place is amazingly cheap,” someone says. “And the food is good and the beer is cheap.”

“You want a beer Preeta?”

“I’ve never tried beer before”.

“Really?”

She shrugs. “Okay, I’ll try a small one.”

Preeta and Dermot.

World-lines crossed.

She does not know all the faces at the table, but as she drinks the strangely sour liquid, with her food, the unfamiliarity seems to matter less.

She feels important: a meal in her honour.

I am not dead here.

“So welcome to our country,” one of the group announces, raising his glass... Unknown face. A friend of Jonathan. “The land of taxidermy and taxes plenty. Skål!”

“What do you make of our crime team? All the little students and boffins?”

“Everyone seems very nice.”

“She’s too polite!”

“Prima, no, what’s your name?”

“Preeta.”

”We heard you are a wiz with the diagnostics.”

“I have had lots of practice,” she tells them modestly.

“So is it true that you have to work twice as many hours in Malaysia?”

She smiles. “Not yet.”

“And do they put you in jail if you spit on the ground?”

“That’s Singapore, idiot!”

“Not even a whipping?”

“Well, that must make it the opposite of here.” Ivar. “Here we spit all the time and work half the time.”

“No one gets anything done here,” Dermot mutters. “We don’t put in the hours. Too much free time and vacation.”

“Look who’s talking! When was your last vacation, Dermot?”

He squirms. “Not for a while.”

“This man works two jobs. You need a life, my man.”

“I have a life, thanks,” he replies with a trace of anger.

Preeta sips her beer and feels a creeping numbness, almost like a pain that does not hurt, somewhere in her brain. The world is simpler; details do not seem to matter as much. It is as though something has clasped her head and she is wearing it.

The boss-lady of the house inspects their table over the top of her glasses and shouts something in Vietnamese. Anything else for you? Peanuts and noodles. This is a taste of home, in an unlikely igloo. Location stored for future reference.

Time gets gobbled up like spring-rolls, their infused and weary bodies supported in the uncomfortable chairs. Dermot goes quiet as usual, and seems to be anxious to go somewhere else. How long have they been sitting here? It is 23:00 hours and the conversation is beginning to peter out. Preeta is tingling and she does not want the evening to end yet.

“You know, I should go,” Dermot says.

“But we are about to plan our work for the next week,” Jonathan jokes.

“Yeah – let me know. Uh – nice to meet you all. Preeta, I guess I’ll see you tomorrow.”

“No, you can’t go now,” Ivar complains. “Preeta wanted a night out, Look, why don’t we go and have one more drink at this bar just around the corner. By then, we might be all finished.”

“I am pretty tired.”

“Preeta, you’ll come with us won’t you?”

She nods, dizzily. “Yes, I would like that. Dermot, you should come too. Just for a little while?”

He checks his mobile, demonstratively for an excuse to leave. There is none.

Preeta puts a hand on his shoulder and tugs at his jacket. “Just for a little while?”

He squeaks inside. And what if he doesn’t come? Will she go home with one of the others? Will he have missed an opportunity? No, he cannot think like that.

“Come on, Derm! Come with us for another half-litre.”

Trapped. He nods, “Okay,” and is rewarded by Preeta’s broad smile.

They walk back out into the cold night, sounds of drunken shouting and distant, swooshing cars. Just a few blocks towards Young’s Square and then slip into a bar. It is a dimly lit place, with small tea-candles flickering at the tables. The bar itself is brightly lit: row upon row of coloured bottles, with luminous and animated labels line the shelves at the bar. Colours, shapes and sizes. Each label is trying to attract attention with its kaleidoscopic antics. Which of these appeals to you most? Some of the drinks can even change colour, or is it the bottles?

They occupy a table in the shifting half-spaces.

“We have to go up to the bar to get drinks here. I’ll go first,” Jonathan informs.

Unfathomable sound: it is a cacophony of fragmented voices, coming from everywhere at once, like a flock of squawking birds. It reverberates around every corner of the establishment, devolving into a flat mixture of meaningless jabber. Too much information is simply noise. Superposed onto this nocturnal aviary is music, which beats out a simple pulsing rhythm, something to focus on if not to listen to. It is like a string of buoys on the ocean, or a ladder up the smooth side of a skyscraper; it is a crutch for gaining purchase on the otherwise featureless audio.

“Oh my god,” Ivar chants.

It is amazing that a single voice can be heard over this din, truly a testament to the power of the human brain to focus on a single message when shrouded in static. This is Bishop’s doctrine in action, Dermot thinks.

“Have you seen that skirt?”

Their attention is drawn to a pair of black legs, terminated in the merest slip of a loin-cloth.

“Now that’s how you get someone’s attention.”

They laugh, though the sound is laced with a nervous strain.

“She’s beautiful,” she mouths.

“It’s probably been patented.”

“Take a picture and send it to Bishop. This could be the start of a whole new theory of grabbing attention. If we equipped all the WPCs with this equipment, it would bring power back into the hands of the law. No one would be able to say no to them.”

“No kidding.”

Small groups of mainly male or of female friends, are scattered around. They are not exotically dressed, at least not most of them. Jeans and sweaters. It is low-key, informal. Preeta sees football colours and shirts on one table, making a noise. She can see a few couples, but this does not seem to be the place for romantic encounters. The women seem to offer one another vacuous hugs and air kisses as they meet.

“It’s like the girl in the honeypot,” Preetha says.

Dermot glances at her, with a barely posed curiosity.

“One of her tricks for getting attention. Sexy clothes that promise more than they reveal.”

“Right,” Ivar chimes.

“Hey, do you remember that woman, a witness in a robbery case last year. She took like seventy megabytes of pictures and sound in the name of fashion or something.”

“Fashion?”

“Yeah. Apparently she thought this woman, in front of her in the shop, was so cool that she recorded her just walking around. Then suddenly the woman did a runner: robbed the store.”

“People still rob stores?”

“Of course they do.”

“Not cash: detergent. She stole some expensive detergent, for a cleaning company, I think it was.”

“All right, let’s cut out the work talk everyone. This is our night out.”

“So is this our final destination?”

“We probably shouldn’t be out too late,” Dermot warns. “There’s been a football match. There might be trouble.”

“Yeah, I heard Ullevål lost on their home turf. They are probably breaking up the pubs on Karl Johan as we speak.”

“Who cares?”

“Most of the city.”

“Perhaps we should find more of a dance club, where they are not likely to go.”

“Yes!” Preeta exuberates. “I have heard all about the Kan-Klubs. Can’t we go dancing?”

“We don’t know how to dance.”

“Neither do I,” she says. “But we can watch?”

“We can all watch.”

“Yes we can, and that skirt is just asking for a picture. I didn’t bring a cam. Derm, do you have one?”

He shakes his head.

Liar.

Preeta peels off several layers of clothing. The transition from the outdoor cold to heat of the bar has welled up in a considerable surplus of internal radiance.

“So, you didn’t finish. I’m guessing they caught this chick with the detergent.”

“Yeah, they did. And the funny thing is, it turns out that she is part of one of these Christian cults from Sweden.”

“A Swedish sex cult!”

They wooo in unison.

“Yeah, probably. Religion with sexual gratification. Then they send the women out to clean offices and buildings all over the city. It is some sort of turf-war with the Turks.”

Preeta looks around questioningly. “Turks?”

“There’s a lot of Turkish and Algerian immigrants who work in the cleaning industry. It’s one of our failings in Scandinavia. No one wants to do the dirty jobs, so we have to get immigrants to do them for us. But some of the Christian groups are anti-Muslim so they try to squeeze them out of the market.”

”It’s sanctioned racism,” Jonathan says, returning from the bar with a couple of beers.

There is a sudden roar of enthusiasm from the table of football supporters.

“Hey-ho. Looks like the tribe is about to go hunting.”

Dermot looks uncomfortably at the table.

“Looks like a bug in your software, Dermot. I think they belong in a different game.”

“I wish,”

“You could go over and re-program them a little?”

“Avatars are easier to understand,” he mumbles and consults his mobile, checking the state of police reports for good measure.

Ivar laughs. “Understatement of the century.”

“Have you ever been to the football?”

“Sure.”

“Really?”

He nods.

“That’s what we like about you Dermot. You talk too much!”

Preeta: “Stop teasing him.”

Dermot looks at her and shakes his head once, sneaking a glance at her as she peels off a sweater, leaving only a snugly fitting, white T-shirt hugging her torso. Then he regrets the discomfort: she is beautiful and exotic, he thinks. The clothes accentuate that.

His mind races at once at the thought of what it might be like ... No, now he is getting confused. He is already seeing Christina. Well, who is he kidding? He is not “seeing” anyone. And Christina is trouble, he knows it, but he is ensnared. What a mess.

He shakes his head as if to clear it.

“Are you okay?” Preeta asks, smiling at his involuntary grimace.

“I’m fine, sorry. Just a little tired.” Now pull yourself together, he thinks. Don’t force it. Stop trying to make things happen. It puts people off.

A girl comes to the table, wearing a promotional nano-shirt.

“Can I get you folks something from the bar?” she asks. “We have a special promotion this evening on these items.” She points to her T-shirt, where a picture of the relevant substances is displayed. “I can get you one of these, or one for each of you at half-price.”

“I’ll have a beer,” Ivar says flatly.

“Regular drinks at the bar,” she sing-songs. “Or shots of any of these drinks at half-price if more than two of you join in.”

“Why not?” Jonathan’s friend pipes in. “Something exotic.”

“We’ll try a shot of the Russian Oil, all ’round.”

She pulls a bottle from a belt on her waist, and produces five plasticized shot-glasses of some black potion, apparently from thin air.

“Here we are.” She taps on her wristband. “Okay, I’m broadcasting on pay and ... I’m ready for five responses. One, two... ”

They tap at their mobiles to pay. She thanks them and leaves.

“All right, people. Let’s make a skål for new police skirts!”

“Preeta, you have to down this in one!”

Dermot cuts in. “You don’t have to.”

“Yes you do! Mob rule. Everyone!”

They raise their glasses, some more confidently than others, salute and empty. Dermot sips and Preeta gulps.

Preeta sputters and coughs.

“Shit, that’s disgusting,” Dermot winces.

Gasps and grins.

“I think I would like something else,” Preeta laughs.

“Shall I get you something? I know what you should try... ”

“Give me a minute first.” She can already feel the effect of the slug of alcohol changing something inside her, as though some dragon buried within her is flexing with its fires. If they are trying to push her into a single role, make her one of them, like a slave girl, then they are mistaken. That is what she has been running from all her life.

“So is someone going to tell me? What is a Swedish sex cult?” she asks.

They look at one another and laugh.

“Are you interested?”

“How can I know, if you don’t tell me about them?”

“The sex cults. That’s religion with sex and manipulation.”

“We have them here too, just for the record.”

“Where is the religion in it?”

“It’s ceremonial. Same thing really.”

“They are basically Christian Bible bashers, like fundamentalists, but they live in closed quarters, usually with some kind of confidence trickster nutcase at the helm.”

“He’s usually a dictator, and he gets people to cleanse their filthy sins by having sex with him, or in groups, or whatever.”

“Them and their small son’s and daughters.”

“And Bishop would like to exterminate them all.”

“You shouldn’t make fun of Bishop.”

“Why not?” Ivar laughs. “The guy is a little over-serious at times.”

“You make him sound like the fanatic. This sounds awful.”

“Man with a mission.”

“Rumour has it that someone in his family got taken in by one of the cults once, but it’s just a rumour.”

“We haven’t come very far in moving his project forward. Too many other things to work on to fight something as abstract as fighting a brainwashing campaign.”

Preeta shakes her head imperceptibly.

“Yeah, we still don’t know how to do it. At least, I can’t think of the goddamn answer.”

“What about you, Dermot? How would a game designer seduce someone or counter-seduce someone from the clutches of the enemy?”

Dermot is feeling calmer from the ingestion of alcohol. He risks an answer. “Bishop tells us that the church is gaining ground, but I have never understood it. People are selfish today – why would they invest in something like a church, where there is a congregation you have to take care of, unless it gave them something for free? You have to believe that people are basically cynical, not that they’re saints. I just don’t get it.”

“You don’t have to understand it,” Jonathan says. “But it’s definitely happening.”

“The religions are carving up Africa pretty effectively,” Jonathan’s friend chimes. “Islam in the North and the Evangelicals and Catholics fighting it out in sub-Saharan. Maybe people feel that it gives them direction or a sense of family, when there is no sense of safety from government?”

“People have extended families in the game. Virtual family has never been more popular. What do they want with religion in this day and age?”

“People want to be looked after. That has to be why presidential figures are revered, even when people disapprove of their politics. People actually want someone to stand up and tell them that everything is all right.”

“And that’s the point, isn’t it? Now it is falling apart. The trust has gone out of the presidential figures, so religious figures see their chance to step in again... ”

“The point is that they don’t see any benefits from central government, so they live like mobs and tribes, like in Africa. Then you can have any local zealot as your local leader, with his own agenda.”

Dermot’s weariness is starting to fade. He feels that he is beginning to get the hang of being out. The tiredness is passing. He has caught his second wind.

“Preeta, do you know what you want to drink?”

She shakes her head.

“There is so much to choose from. I don’t know where to start.”

“Did you like the beer you had?”

She shrugs. “It was interesting.”

“Why not try a cocktail?” Jonathan suggests.

“All right. I would like a blue drink,” she says.

They laugh.

“How about a margarita with that blue stuff?” Ivar says.

“Will you come with me and tell me what to ask for?”

“Ehmm. Have to give me a minute on that.” He runs it up on his mobile and shows her a picture on a tablet. “This?”

Dermot says, “I’m going to the bar anyway. Come on, I know what it is.”.

The place is filling up now and there is a crowd at the bar. Preeta feels a body pressing into hers, She smells the lactic sweat and wafts of pot-encrusted jackets. Clothes, boring and beautiful. Make-up, scents, body language. Everyone is signalling and sending their messages, flagging their identity and their hopes, trying to influence their surroundings.

If they are talking about how to turn people from the church, the answer must surely lie in this melting pot of signals. The room is literally bursting with audio-visual button-pushing. Bishop would love this.

Dermot’s thoughts parallel her own. The noise in the room hinders his thinking. How do you turn such a mass of noise into something more structured, like a symphony? That is what everyone is trying to do.

Suddenly, from the noise, Preeta hears what she instantly perceives to be a scream. Turning her head, a space opens up behind where they are standing, and people seem to simply evaporate from their positions at the speed of sound. A body, a person, comes tumbling backwards, as if in slow motion, growing in her field of vision, and crashes into the bar beside her, with a man practically on top of him. Like dogs, like animals. One at the throat of the other. They are fighting.

Preeta feels the thud of the man on the wooden bar. Fists pummel into his face and his nose spatters blood. Suddenly there are two groups fighting at several locations. The patrons have scattered to the edges of the room, like Russian Oil expelled by a detergent.

The scene has a sickening presence. It is not like watching a bar-fight in a film, with fake punch noises over-dubbed and balsa-wood furniture that breaks like tissue paper. The real sound of violence is a hollow smack, as flesh gives way to sudden impact, followed by the splatter of thin red blood onto the wooden floorboards, drying in little craters, which darken to crimson. There is the shattering thunder as furniture and bodies crash to the wooden floor. Finally there is the swoosh and thump as one thug takes a chair and tries to break it over the back of his adversary, imitating the scenes he has learned from Hollywood Westerns. But, unlike in the movies, it is not the chair that breaks. The man goes down and does not come up.

In a moment, the fighters have finished their ambush and have vacated the bar, leaving moaning and bleeding bodies around them. The panic button has doubtless been pressed, and police will be on their way. The thugs disappear into the night, perhaps to pick another fight elsewhere.

In the aftermath, the pounding music is suddenly apparent, ridiculously cheery under the circumstance. All voices have desisted. A space remains, buoyed by the shock of sudden violence. No one says anything, but two of the bar staff go to see if the groaning bodies are all right.

Preeta is frozen in position, standing up with her hands between her legs, looking hurt.

“Are you okay. Did you wet yourself?”

She shakes her head.

The police were too far away. They could not come in time to stop this event. Luckily, this was apparently just between gangs. They are not interested in anyone else, except perhaps as spectators.

“You sure?”

“I don’t think I want any more to drink. Let’s just get out of here.”

They return to their table. As if they needed proof that the gangs are a more immediate problem. The gang violence has been a distraction lately. Bishop has been having a lot of discussions with the boys and girls in blue about it.

People diffuse away from the walls, still looking at the injured bundles of flesh and bone, lying broken on the ground, but essentially turning their backs on the incident1 and carrying on with their evening. It is over now. Not their business. Soon it will be as if nothing has happened.

“I don’t get it,” Ivar says. “What it is with these people? What do they get out of this?”

“Animals.”

“Football supporters. They don’t like losing.”

“Yeah, I heard they lost on their home turf.”

“I am so sick of these freakin’ gangs,” Jonathan’s friend gasps.

“What is a gang anyway? How do you define it?” Jonathan struts.

His friend regards him wearily. “A bunch of people with a funny handshake, walking demonstratively down the middle of a street?”

“That’s the seventeenth of May!” Ivar laughs, to lighten the mood. “You’re thinking of marching bands!”

“Well, if they are not a splinter off civilized society’s block, I don’t know a better way to describe them!”

“There are all kinds of gang,” Dermot says simply.

Preeta shudders and takes the remainder of her Russian Oil and throws it back, as the others did, medicinally. Her eyes bulge a little and then she winces and coughs. Perhaps more of it will help to numb the trembling within her.

“Wooo. Careful, girl. We need you to operate that new software you’ve put together.”

Dermot sees her and considers doing the same, but that would not be like him.

“The gangs are happening in Asia too. You have the indoctrination clinics, or Madrassas that offer free education to young men, turning them into stooges for Islamic extremism... and there are Hindu gangs.”

“Yeah, according to TerrorWatch, they actually teach them how to use weapons and infiltrate organizations... ”

“Yeah, I read that too.”

“It’s a familiar equation: fear plus resources equals stupidity.”

Preeta does not feel like arguing in their defence. For all she knows, it might be true.

“Preeta, you don’t look very well. Are you okay?”

“I think we should leave,” Ivar says.

“Yeah. Let’s get out of here.”

They don their clothing and push their way out. Several others have been thinking the same thing, since the fight.

Preeta and Dermot huddle together, as they meet the icy air outside the bar.

“You two look like a sorry pair.”

“I’m just a little tired,” Dermot replies.

Off in the distance, they hear a dirge of male moaning, droning out a vacant melody èn masse, as if celebrating certain brain-damage. It could only be the sounds of a post-pregnant football match. It booms out from a bar accompanied by vicious shouts and guttural roars. Dermot looks unnerved, but Preeta merely feels a distant disgust through her intoxication. They have seen the transformation from human male to rabid animal, all for the love of a high-tech pig’s bladder with spots on.

“I need to go and dance and feel happy,” Preeta says, giddily.

“Do you belly dance? Can I come and watch?” Jonathan’s friend. Idiot.

“Grow up,” Jonathan says.

“Don’t tell him to grow up. He’s trying.”

Preeta says: “Boys. Be nice. Anyway, for the record, we don’t ‘grow up’. We get worn down, we lose our sharp edges.”

“Wooo.” They laugh.

She points her finger a little too pointedly. “We make compromises and accept society’s lowest common denominator package of values and ... ideas because it saves us the effort of thinking for ourselves.”

They exchange significant glances.

“And on that note,” she slurs. “I want to party. Come on, Dermot.” She sets off in the direction of Grensen.

Ivar says. “We’d better look after those two.” He calls after them. “You two are important to us, if we are going to get moving on Bishop’s counter-campaign.”

Preeta on the new software and Dermot with the programming. Better keep a clear head.

“Okay, first place we find,” Preeta shouts, pointing to a couple of girls walking together. “Let’s follow them.”

From a line of decorated bodies, through a door bouncer control point, they descend into the underworld of a club. The stairway leads down past black painted bricks, spray painted with art and pseudo-graffiti. Posters are thrown up haphazardly, showing concerts and bands and coming attractions, overlapping and torn. A thunderous pumping of bass reaches up to them, as if they are entering a gigantic heart, giddy on speed.

The regular din of voice noise and laughter accompanies it. It is just the two of them now. Jonathan’s friend had other plans, and Ivar was looking tired. Dermot too looks like a ghost, withdrawn and misplaced in this universe. She can see him looking around, as if trying to find the puzzle that he has to solve to get past this level of the game.

Preeta is sailing, as if on dream auto-pilot. She feels drawn to the sound, to the warmth. By luck, two bar stools are free. She throws her coat over one and sits there, Dermot beside her.

Dark Gothic phantoms glide around with stylish mobile bracelets and silver wires used for decoration. Coloured hair and gelled sculpture. Everyone is a painting. Everyone is a work of art.

The art is cold, she decides, not like eastern art. It is chilly and aloof, pretentious. They are gargoyles, not love elephants. If I were art, I would want to bring people together, she thinks. This is masculine art. It shoots its message outward and says ‘fuck you’. Her art would be more feminine, more inviting and would say ‘tell me about yourself’.

The pulsing of the lights, hypnotising, cleansing. Worries are excised. They order a simple beer and look around them. Dermot tries to say something a few times, but they have to press their faces close together and shout to be heard over the music.

He is sweet, she thinks, but too careful for me.

There are no hot men here, but look at the girls. Sexy girls everywhere, with amazing figures. She cannot help but gape. Feline bodies, twisting like tornadoes, hugging an inner volcano in a tight shell; snaking like cobras, living vines. Their short-cut dresses reveal ribs and breasts, with coloured hair and knee high boots. Preeta is entranced. It was not like this in the subcontinent, where people are trying to conceal middle-age obesity with airy tents.

She feels the effect of the alcohol. It is a new sensation, like being in a dream. Perhaps dreaming is like being drunk?

There is a dance floor, raised slightly, a short distance away, behind a cage wall.

The pulsing rhythm seems to activate parts of her brain that her anaesthetised centres would normally reject as irrational, but the prickling of the alcohol simply makes it feel comfortable. It is like being in a womb. She feels an urge to kick.

“Do you want to dance?” she shouts.

Dermot smiles a no. Is he feeling the same effect?

I am here, she thinks. I feel free, more free than I have ever felt. She has journeyed half way around the world to be here. She turned her back on her friends, just like those people in the bar turned their backs on the victims of violence. She is transforming from a kind grey moth into a selfish butterfly, with colour. But why should she resist? Why should she care? What is there to lose. Only the string survive. She has been trodden on all her life. Perhaps the road to happiness is not paved with good intentions at all. Perhaps you have to push others aside and look after yourself, because no one else will.

The notion spins inside her mind, like a rising cyclone. It seems to buoy her, lift her out of the dread and the guilt. What is there to feel guilty about? Look around, there is no guilt in this room. All she can see is a purging of responsibility. A cleansing of daily stresses. She wants to join in. She too wants to be purged of guilt.

Preeta gathers focus and smiles at Dermot.

“Come on,” she says and jumps off her stool.

Dermot shakes his head, shyly. He does not feel the spirit of freedom that courses through her veins. “Someone has to watch our things.”

She shrugs, too far down her path to change gear now.

She has arrived. She has seen the enemy and it is only her own inhibition. She pushes her way through the tightly packed crowd and jumps up onto the dance floor. The music is beating and people are swaying and singing. She does not know the words, but she wants to join in. She dances with hands raised and eyes closed, allowing the music to infuse her spirit. The movements are instinctive and primal. She does not care about appearances. Freedom has reached her mind, and freedom is not about control.

As she looks around her, seeing others in the same state of release, she recognizes the look. The look, the very image that she always wanted to imitate, it is that carefree look of freedom. It is the face of not caring.

Just look at the beauty. The sexy bodies, writhing in their expansiveness, riding on their buoyancy, having shed their earthly burden. This is where she wants to be right now.

In front of her, in a black dress that clings to her body, with short blonde hair and a long, pale neck, she recognizes someone. Not their face, but their understanding. The blond girl grins at her and moves closer. Preeta grins back, happier than she has ever been, connecting with her chromatic opposite, unified by erasure of guilt and worry, worlds from distant galaxies brought together by music and beer.

They dance together, holding out hands to one another. They ripple and move together, as though they were both spirits yin and yang, lock and key. The girl moves forward and touches her. They slide together with eyes half closed, and kiss. Not a short kiss, but a long intense kiss, with tongue. A surge of excitement floods through her. How daring, how contraire! How unbelievably cool she is! Every part of her is aroused.

She turns to look back for Dermot. Then she sees the horrified road-kill at the bar, gaping is disbelief. The madness had carried her away, but why should she care?

Come on, she thinks, this is every boy’s dream. Two girls instead of one. She lifts out her hand in a regal beckoning as she dances as if to invite him into an unholy trinity, inviting him to share in her adventure, but he is paralysed. This is way too much. It had taken all his daring to talk to her in the first place. Now the thought of parading in front of the entire club with two gorgeous women is just too much. She sees him crumble slightly, not quite able to understand what has happened or how he managed to get into this. Then his deflation turns to discomfort and panic and he turns to flee, to expunge the dream.

She wants to go to him, but the girl in front of her is now pressing in close running her hands down her back, which seems like an opportunity that is too good to miss. This is my adventure, she thinks. I can save him later.

White Christmas

Imagine a conversation, the first words of a language. It begins simply, an embryo of clear statements: the exchanges of proper names and mutual humilities. Gradually the babble swells in sophistication, in context and convolution. It matures and crystallizes with its own grammar–a lattice to support and guide the organic growth of its ideas.

Then, as the rigidity of the lattice begins to feel small, life-giving dialogue strains against the captivity, flowering in defiance of an unwanted and resented structural conformity. An arms race begins, between the need to express more elaborate intellectual growth, and the need to package uncertainty in a safe scaffolding.

Layers of establishment accrete around the struggling organism, choking it. The beast collapses under the weight of a cancerous armour-plating. Bureaucracy, once the friend that supported the spindly shoots of adventure in their growth, has built a morsoleum for thought and creativity.

Rest not in peace, but in perpetual debt to the system: a mortgage of ever-outstanding yet mediocre reporting, ever queued up to exhaust the conversation, to stifle its power to innovate. This language, Jonas believes, is the language of administration.

Freezing fog has lain a veneer of perfectly smooth ice onto the ground. He cannot even make it up the slight incline. He sees a car attempt its start up and slide back down, sideways into a tree. No sense in trying to make it that way.

Jonas drives south, once again, following the snaking road out beyond the ring road, from the conference hotel. The road is still slippery, but the adaptive tyres are holding on to their promise for now.

The events of two days ago are still fresh in his mind. He has driven this route several times now, and it brings back awkward feelings.

He dropped Martin off with his mother, that day, just half an hour before she finished work. He told her that they could talk later, no time now, and that he had to rush off. She swallowed her anger for the time being, and it felt as though he had gotten off lightly.

It won’t last long. She will remind him of it soon.

Something has changed in him since the experience. He has survived one attack on his life. What about the next one? Surely, feeling ones mortality makes one stronger.

Arriving back at the council offices, after his social seminar cleansing, messages queued up in the message centre lie in wait for him. He has officially taken a day’s leave to wind down, but there is no escaping the next step. There lay the memo he was putting out if his mind. It calmly informed them all that the government had intervened and placed research back together with church matters, back as it was in the 1990s. Unlikely bed-fellows, thrust back into an irreligious union by the politics of fear.

He read his messages numbly, absorbing their content without letting them alter his spirit. What else could one do? Then he returned to the hotel retreat to unwind, in the pursuit of knowledge.

Jonas spent the next days making sense of things, using the social seminar as a base for this meditation. What kind of society are we living in? Am I an outdated fossil, who should move over for a new age? Can I be so wrong in my beliefs? Can I just stand aside and let things fall into disarray?

He arrives now at the offices in a new frame of mind. Hostility has gestated within him. He feels like a soldier resigned to the prospect of battle, intensely aware of failing to achieve any of his worldly goals. It is surely time to rectify that. But how does one fight an immovable object? A little civil disobedience?

I have to try to do something for Sara, he thinks. But what?

Perhaps it is time to put on his academic hat for a while. He should try to contact the project team for a start. He has no idea what is going on there. They just seem to have disappeared. He is still her advisor, after all. And what about Professor Hart? He might have some clout.

His intern, John, tells him: “I called a friend in embassy circles and he said that the American embassy has decided to go on alert due to some threatened action. The French are protesting at their behaviour and are playing silly buggers by going off in a huff. Now riots have started there and in Eindhoven too.”

“This is what happens when governments and politics get involved in knowledge management.”

“Can you try to find out what Professor Hart is doing at the moment. Is he in the country? Tell him about this development and the effect it is going to have on his research.”

“Okay. I’m on it. Anything else?”

“I need to think. I going to need the details of our past agreements.”

“Have you tried the archive?”

He nods. “It’s worth a try.”

“Oh, Jonas?”

“Yes?”

“A policeman has been trying to contact you. An American, I think. Bishop?”

“Ugh. That can wait.”

He returns to his office to access the files, whose information is not available by mobile. Knowledge and experience are our saviours.

A functionary from the ministry, who has been loitering in the wings, sees him as he is leaving the building.

“Jonas Lindgren? I’m glad I found you.”

The feeling isn’t mutual.

“You were not at the meeting the other day.”

“I was not.”

“It was an important announcement.”

“There was an emergency.”

“But you must have seen the memo by now. You must have heard.”

He nods sternly.

“Then I hope everyone is going to go at this with their full vigour.”

“We have other things to clear up first.”

“Like what?”

“Like research projects that are in full swing. People’s lives that are being thrown into disarray because of this. I have a student who is stranded in the field, and a collaborative project with the space agencies that is already falling apart without your help. Somehow, I need to fix these things that have been broken.”

“Jonas, why are you still working on this? You know that everyone is going to be working on the Africa project now.”

“That doesn’t come into force until the new year. I am still a scientist. Science can’t just stop.”

He laughs. He actually laughs.

“Then perhaps it’s time do some real science and apply yourself to what the board has decided is our strategic focus.”

He regards him pityingly for several seconds and says: “I’m going to send someone down to advise about the new administrative procedures. It should help you adjust to the new system. In future it won’t be possible to let money disappear into these non-approved sidelines. We want to make sure that we get the maximum amount out of our research.”

A wave of protest rings through the virtual aether of academia, like a World War II air-raid siren. Take cover, the bombs are coming. The tolling of the Reason Bell spells judgement in the works for an intellectual future.

“What is an intellectual anyway?”

The question is posed with the clear resonance of rhetoric. It reverberates in the artificial ambience of the meeting. The words could have been read by a vicar as the opening of a sermon. In truth, they ring with the irony of an assumed loss.

The debate has reached a level of agitation that Jonas has seldom seen in without actual physical presence. A debate was, of course, inevitable; it has not taken long to self-organize.

In a circular theatre of tense participants; they sit, like the members of a war council, academics and scientists from Universities, College and industry. Even the press has come to observe and report on the transcription. They have come to search for meaning, to blow off steam and even to talk of strategies for reversing the perceived damage of the leaked decision. Is it still possible to overturn the judgement?

What is an intellectual anyway? The rhetoric hangs in the virtual air.

“I think it is clear that intellectuals are people who want to influence society with their ideas. They are not just scientists, they are more than that.”

“So you are saying that they are more than simply those who have a College education?”

“Of course. Are politicians intellectuals? People in marketing? They influence society with their ideas, but we rarely think of their daily ramblings as intellectual... ”

“Politicians and marketeers are merely the plumbers and carpenters of influence mechanics. They are not usually the progenitors of the ideas themselves. Not the ideas that change science or even society. They do not conform to a level of importance that warrants the title intellectual.”

“But people are arguing that society doesn’t need academics. We have burned ourselves on that stove before. We need people we can use. Professionals and craftsmen, not puffed up thinkers.”

“What makes you think that there is any contradiction between the need for professionals and the need for thinkers?”

“Well, look at what happened in the information technology bubble. There was enormous demand, but no one to step in. There were plenty of graduates but they were not ready to take on the job. They knew the theory but they didn’t know how to get down and dirty. The same with biotech. We did not master these fields quickly because we did not have people who had practical knowledge of the day to day tasks.”

“My academic colleague is correct. We do not need thinkers, we need people who can implement existing ideas well. Let other countries innovate and make the mistakes.”

“Doesn’t our country have a responsibility to innovate, as one of the world’s richest countries?”

“Indeed it does. Professionalism,” as if spitting, “It is the scourge of academia. It’s a goddamned virus.”

“I don’t think I know what you mean,” another says.

“What I mean is that young people used to have a right to an education. Now they only have a right to a profession. It’s not about ideas and independent thought anymore, it’s about training people to behave like good little soldiers.”

“Professionalism is filing the sharp edges off society. It is making everyone into silent, uncontroversial trained monkeys. Think no evil, do no evil. It is the opposite of intellectualism.”

“I think this may be somewhat overstated. I think some of us do survive. I took on this job, hoping that I could help to reverse that trend.”

“I left my teaching post for a sabbatical, hoping to make a difference, but there is no perceived value to intellectualism in the state system. It has been smeared as something for a slightly unpleasant elite for so long that people have rejected it. All that matters now is the accumulation of wealth.”

“As long as it is no longer about innovation, our task is hopeless. We are just a political can opener.”

“If it is not about innovation, what is it about then?”

“Multiplication. It’s about making more and more of what you already have. Mass consumerism. Thou shalt not create, thou shalt produce and consume, and fill out a tax form at the end of it, but you’ll not get any points for inventing something new, and upsetting the status quo, incurring development costs.”

“No, that’s not true. We can still get money for new projects.”

“Only if we are guaranteed a quick return. Only if we can turn it into a ‘product’ straight away.”

“We have tried to convince the government leadership before, but they have no incentive to listen.”

“They have their own club. The blinkered ruling elite. The system is corrupt. If you do not agree with them, they brand you as a trouble-maker. Democracy has perished in their hands.”

“This is supposed to be the knowledge-based society. It has become the ignorance society – the consumer society. The ministry has seen to that.”

“That’s right. We are not even allowed to teach what we want. We have to teach what the students think they want, or whatever is politically correct. How the hell can they know what they need to know when they don’t know anything?”

“The whole thing started going pear-shaped when they started focusing on this idea of better ‘management’, where management is supposed to mean competitive leadership. But the role of management is not commercial dictatorship, it’s about coordination. Management ought to be be a conduit–something that receives and coordinates the autonomous activities of the specialists under its wing. Not under its command! A leader is something else entirely.”

“The people with the purse strings are just ignorant. It’s not their fault.”

“That means that we are just playing a game of made-up rules to get money for the development of society. But we cannot figure out what we’re getting. It’s like pulling the lever on a one-armed bandit in a Casino. Throw the dice and see what comes out.”

And every application has to have ‘milestones’ and ‘deliverables’ because non-experts want to feel as though they have some kind of control over what we are going to be doing with our time and what they are going to be out of it.
