Fever has finally drained from her and she feels strong. The chance to rest has actually been welcome. Old Donald Duck comics (paper), movies and news on the TV. And Bea. The girl might not have had more than an average schooling, but she is a Professor when it comes to making her feel better.

She hasn’t felt like a prisoner, precisely, more like a raptor in a tar pit. She lost them, the French team. She failed to get what she wanted. She fell behind. Her raison d’être evaporated. She ought to pick herself up and move on. Find a new one.

At two o’clock in the afternoon, her premonition is realized. The leather beat-bitch tramps her chequered garb into the mountain hotel’s lounge and regards her with that absent bitchiness she is so good at.

Her cardboard-on-toast voice tolls: “It’s over.”

Sara Stensrud glances up at her from the tablet in her lap.

“Call you later, mum,” she says, completing a different conversation, and meets her unassailable nonchalance. “What’s over?”

Steroid Sally stands is poise, as a rock would poise, in the entrance to the lounge, with face-lift pony-tail sucking her backwards, and cold blue eyes avoiding those of the only person in the room. “They have surrendered. All of them. The army is rounding them up now.”

“The football gangs?”

She nods, chewing some kind of gum, as if masticating flavoured plastic can blow smoke in Vibe’s face. Looking anywhere, everywhere but at her.

“And their friends. Out of their depth in this weather.”

“Does that mean we can get out of here now?”

“We’re getting rid of you.”

Likewise, bitch.

“District will be up to clear you later. Be good, and say nice things, or you might end up with a fine.”

She backs out of the entrance, turns and leaves.

District will clear her later? Like she were under arrest or something? In your dreams, Sally. She can think of no good reason to stay here any longer than necessary. She’s just afraid I might say something about her hobby...

Say nice things...

In other words: I know you saw me distributing illegal spirits, and you’d better not say a word, or I’ll have you.

The news from Saskwatch Sally is a turning point.

What can she do here now that her project has been pulled out from underneath her? Dr Lindgren says he will sort something out, but what the hell is that supposed to mean? Since when did he ever come up trumps?

Call comes in. Luck of the devil.

“Sara Vibeke Stensrud?”

“Ehh... yes. Sort of, anyway.”

“My name is Edward Bishop. I work for Interpol’s research centre. I spoke briefly with Dr Jonas Lindgren and I would like to talk to you about doing a job for me, perhaps permanently.”

She checks her message board.

TARGETED: INTERNSHIP WITH RESEARCH OPPORTUNITIES, APPLICATION OF BIOLOGICAL AND ECONOMIC MODELS TO CIVIC ORDER AND CONTROL. CONTACT QUERY RETURN. HELP NEEDED IMMEDIATELY.

More details are in some other attachments...

“Just wanted to speak to you directly. Look at this, then we can talk in a little while.”

“Thanks, I’ll look at it.”

She stares out of the window at the rock just beyond it one last time. It seems to symbolize her predicament. From the inside of the hotel, the rock looks harmless and scenic, biding its time: just a painting on the canvas of the daylight. But, if she goes outside, it is rough and hard and sharp and cold. It is dangerous. It cuts.

How much we sacrifice of reality, she thinks. Pain is truth, if anything is. This rock. This cage. It is time to be leaving. Time to reclaim the world of pain and future.

Could have sworn she saw Ethanol Emma talking to the man at the hotel desk. Probably selling her moonshine. He is an old cardigened shrew with a bulbous red nose that tells her he is more of a country alcoboy than mountain guide. She goes out there.

“Did you see what happened to that police woman?”

“Who?”

“You know, tall weight lifter. I don’t know her name. She was right here.”

“She has probably gone.”

“Ah.”

“So you heard the news?” the balding receptionist asks.

“Yes. We’re not quarantined anymore.”

“That means the busses will be running again from tomorrow morning.”

“Does that mean there will be a bus soon to Oslo?”

“Just got word from the Express. First one is due in tomorrow at six in the morning.”

“Nothing sooner? I’m in kind of a hurry. Now that we’re all free.”

“Eh, no. Not unless you want to sit with me to the town. I’m going down the mountain later. I can’t wait for some supplies. You could get a train from the station.”

“Really?”

“It’s not a limousine, but it’ll roll down the hill.”

“Yes, yes, yes, yes! Thank you!”

“All right then,” he chuckles. “Be ready in an hour... ”

“Check me out!”

Not like that, Grampa!

She packs her rucksack quickly, stuffing everything in as quickly as possible. No sense in being tidy now. With luck she will be home before long where real clothes await and she no longer has to live in tent fabrics. She is not certain how the local police will react to her simply leaving, but cross that one when we get there.

She can imagine the incendiary glare of Suicide Sally threatening to melt her own icy demeanour. There must be a volcano beneath that ice. A real mud pool. Give yourself a facial.

The little box she received from the American has been waiting on her dressing table, like the mysterious visitor from 2001: A Space Odyssey, ever since she received it. She packs it into her backpack. She has been staring at it for minutes on end, without being able to penetrate its secret. A note is attached to the box. “Sara–don’t try to open this until December 12th,” it says. It seems to be locked, so there must be some reason for the message. She placed it next to her mirror and tried everything barring telepathy to reveal its mystery. Perhaps they simply wanted her to have a Christmas present. Maybe it doesn’t matter now.

New message from mystery sponsor.

REPLY: THANKS FOR RESPONSE. DO YOU HAVE A KNOWLEDGE OF THE THEORY OF ECONOMIC INFLUENCE? PROGRAMMING?

REPLY: YES. HALF WAY THROUGH A PHD ON AUTONOMOUS AGENT INTERACTIONS. SHOULD BE A DAB HAND.

So who is this person? Some kind of introduction might be on the fair side of polite.

REPLY: INTERESTED. CAN YOU MEET ME IN OSLO?

REPLY: OKAY. CAN MEET YOU ON ARRIVAL IN OSLO IN A DAY OR SO. CURRENTLY IN JOTUNHEIMEN.

REPLY: WILL CALL YOU ON TABLET IN 10 MINS.

She waits for the call, sitting cross legged on her bed, holding a tablet. Incoming. She opens.

“Hello.”

An older man.

“Hello, Sara. Thank you for responding. I have need for your skills in several ways. I have a police operation to conduct. It has to do with the gang violence and the rise of radical groups. I can’t tell you the details until you come and sign non-disclosure agreements. This is confidential police business.”

“So you are police?”

“I am interpol, Norwegian branch.”

“I have been working on a collaborative project which now seems to have been halted.”

“I heard. The expansion of Chri... certain influences in the United States has resulted in a sudden change of budget. Space and BioTech in particular have been axed in favour of so-called ‘Moral Research’. Enormous pressure has been levied on their international partners to withdraw from the projects.”

“Are we supposed to live in the dark ages now?”

“I suppose so. Sara, would you be interested in coming to work for me?”

“What would I do?”

“Close to what you have already been doing. Working in a team. I can guarantee that the work will be at least as interesting and challenging as you have been doing. Now you get to work with humans and machines.”

“We should talk when I get home. I’ve been a bit out of it. Sick.”

They are driving along the winter road. Her escape chute. The snowplough has wiped and stacked the landscape, giving them tunnel vision. She is a mole burrowing through a trough of feta cheese.

“Looking forward to going home to your folks?” the hotelier asks.

“Yes!” she agrees.

“They should be glad to see you after this trouble.”

Ah, the trouble.

He is right. It will be good to get home, but her decision to leave quietly could backfire: her immunity to others’ instructions has always served as a provocation to them, as her brother with attest. Always she has faith that nothing bad will happen. She has duck feathers, as well as the beak. Trouble runs off her, to her brother’s annoyance. She knows how to use her looks to activate forgiveness when necessary.

It is dark by the time they reach the small town station. She thanks the hotelier and steps out of the warm cocoon into a biting chill. They have timed the journey so that she will not have to wait more than a few minutes for the train to arrive, so she shouldn’t have to freeze her nipples off for too long.

She pulls out her backpack from the rear seat and waves a good bye. The car moves off and then stops a little way down the road, but he doesn’t get out, so she turns to find the platform.

Moonlight lights up the mountains behind her. Pretty, but it’s time to say her good-byes. The road she has arrived on stretches back up the valley, snaking its way up the mountain; on it, a blue light, far off, reaches out to her across the darkened pass, as if pointing across the mountain with the long, icy finger of the law.

Her heart skips a beat. A police car this way comes.

Beat Bitch Sally? Who else could it be? Frank, coming to say good-bye?

She turns to see what became of the hotelier and sees that he has received a call, which he takes on an old hand-held receiver. He looks about as if searching for her and she knows then that the call is about her. Damn. It was an even bet, but she is not sticking around to be talked to or stopped.

Vibe turns and walks away from the vehicle towards the small station building. There are not many places to hide here precisely, but she can lie low.

This is not a time to allow herself to feel guilt for leaving. If she just keeps moving around, they should never have to meet. Anyway, as long as she is near civilization, they know where she is by her mobile. It’s not like she could hide. The blue light is edging closer. It will arrive before the train comes.

She checks the time. Just a few minutes until the train arrives. Browse some magazines, buy a book? There is a platform barrier here, she sees. The best place for her to be is on the other side of that barrier.

She heaves her backpack onto her frame one more time and heads for the gate.

“Where do you think you are going?”

She flashes her mobile strap. “I have a pass for the train.”

“Not with that, you don’t,” he says, pointing at her backpack.

“But... what?”

“Train is extremely full this evening and there is no room in the cabin. You’ll have to check that in as freight. Over there. Better hurry.”

He points her in the direction of the baggage office.

Registered freight and luggage. Special baggage. Post. Post?

She goes to the postal desk on a sudden whim.

“Eh hello. I’m in a bit of a hurry. Can I send this to my address in Oslo?”

“You can, if you can pay for it,” he laughs.

“When would it arrive?”

“That depends where you live.”

“Oslo. Centre.”

He consults a list, as if he doesn’t know the answer. “Probably tomorrow afternoon. You would have to be there to receive it, or collect it from the depot.”

“Okay. How much?”

She has some money from her mum now. She can afford this. It will even make the journey more pleasant. She has to suppress a hopping up and down motion.

“Scales,” the clerk barks.

She rests the pack on the scales.

“It’s already tagged,” she says.

Train now arriving for Oslo Central Station on platform 2.

Damn, she thinks. This is cutting it a bit fine.

He scans the pack and extracts her details, taking a little longer than she feels is necessary under the circumstances.

“All right. This looks okay. You can send second class and save a little, but I don’t recommend it.”

“No. That won’t be necessary. Just get it to me as quickly as you can!” She grins, giving him the school girl look.

“Ooookaaaayy. Here’s a copy of an agreement. Read the top part. Sign to accept.” He indicates for her to download it from the counter, working at a clockwork speed, with no indication of knowing the meaning or urgency.

She looks over the form. “All right. Everything seems to be in order.”

Train on platform 2 leaves immediately for Oslo Central Station. Passengers are advised that there will be no waiting.

Through the window she can see the police car park outside. She sees Saskwatch step out of the car and start towards the station.

“Eh–so can I just leave this with you?”

“Anything dangerous in here? You checked the box?”

“Yes, yes.”

“In a hurry are we?”

Thats what I said!

“Actually yes,” she smiles sweetly, remembering her demeanour. “I have to catch this train, and it’s supposed to be very full.”

“I see. Well, it looks as though everything is in order.”

“So I’ll get this tomorrow?” she asks, redundantly, but hoping for a dismissal.

“That’s what the man said.”

“Great service. Thanks.”

Train now leaving for Oslo Central Station on platform 2.

No time!

“You’d better go,” he says calmly, “if you want to catch that”.

She exhales. “Thanks!”

She turns to leave and her eye catches that of the policewoman, through the window, glaring at her. She has been spotted. Saskwatch turns towards the door from the exit side of the building.

Vibe’s heart skips another beat, but she forces herself to pretend that she has not seen her. Without much encouragement, she walks quickly to the back-door leading towards the platform and trots towards to the platform barrier, breaking into a run as she goes. The conductor-barrier registers her ticket and the human waves her through.

She runs for the train.

Doors close.

Whistle blows.

Behind her, no one is following.

She plops herself down into her designated seat and allows herself to calm her beating heart.

I am going home.

She is looking forward to the prospect of being back in the city, where time runs at the proper rate.

Silver eel, electric and hushed. It carries Vibe from the pods of rocky leviathans, in the high ground, into the lower pastures of the capitol. Back towards to Oslo’s basin of attraction. A journey of several hours. Time for sleep.

Urban re-entry deep-fries her in a sensory feed. Sizzling data streams boil her. She is fish’n’chips. She is Burger’n’fries. This is the 24-hour Deli. Yet it contains the life support, the basic feeds to buoy 21st Century incompetent life. It has proper clothes, the trappings of ceremony, and warm bodies for tactile relief.

Hello immersion tank, my silver lining.

The train deposits her rested and more lightweight soma at Oslo’s central station with just enough possessions to find her way home. It feels good to have the city coursing through her senses once again. Mountains are necessary and beautiful, but above all they refine one’s appreciation of the city.

It is about 20:40 hours when she arrives in Oslo. She tightens the straps on her mobile to better absorb the subtle notifications from the smart environment. The canopy of the city is both dark and light at the same time.

There has been a light rain in the capital and the air is cool but fresh. Compared to the mountains, it seems damp and almost warm here.

Vibe takes a town-bike from the stall and cycles the half kilometre or so to her small two-room flat. She is itching to shower and change into something more like clothes. Something befitting a girl.

I used to be that, she thinks.

It is quiet and dusty in the flat. No air has circulated here for over a week. The level in the toilet is low, where the water has evaporated. She has bought fresh milk from the corner Deli for making tea.

After a purging shower and hair cure, she puts her mobile pieces in to be washed, and switches to her house combo.

As she does so, a message comes in for her:

POST OFFICE TELEGRAM: YOUR BAGGAGE, LABELLED UNDER PACKAGE CONTRACT 17045 HAS BEEN INTERCEDED BY ORDER OF LOCAL POLICE AND CANNOT THEREFORE BE DELIVERED AS PER CONTRACT. NO FUNDS WILL BE CHARGED TO YOUR ACCOUNT AND THE SAID CONTRACT IS THEREFORE VOID. PLEASE RETAIN THE ATTACHED RECEIPT FOR THIS ITEM, WHICH IS NOW IN POLICE CUSTODY.

She stares in horror at the message, her mouth wide open.

She sits down.

The bitch!

Then again.

The bitch!

Now she has gone out on a limb.

If she has used police privilege against her, she’d better have a pretty good explanation.

What the hell have I done to deserve this?

She summons calm. There was nothing she urgently needed in the pack. Her tablet and a few clothes, mostly, and gear she doesn’t need here. But that is hardly the point.

What the hell are you afraid of, you stupid freaking bitch?

She sits for a long time with a frown that is half way towards wanting to cry. Too much stress lately. Too much.

She needs to feel calm and complete. She needs her shiny confidence back. Sleep will help, but she is the opposite of tired at this moment.

Consideration calls forth the spirits of healing.

I know what to do, she thinks. This doesn’t matter. It can be sorted tomorrow or even the day after. There are ways to deal with it.

She considers calling her mum, but that will just make her want to complain and even cry about it. Not going to happen.

She stabs at her combo and pulls up her buddy list. Neighbours are useful sometimes. Geography isn’t dead yet. Paul, where are you? Just back from a trip. You busy?

She invites her chum over and strips him. She needs to feel the heat of someone between her legs. He obliges her, as any half-sane male would. Afterwards, she sends him on his way and settles into her cocoon, feeling empowered.

Text to Bea.

“Back in black, babe. Just male-nutrished. Wanna come and sleep over?”

“Dr Jonas Lindgren. My name is Edward Bishop. I work with Interpol. I have a project where I need some urgent consulting. Would you be willing to help me?”

Bishop follows Jonas as he walks through the sterile lobby of the research council offices, in the centre of town. He has been waiting there for a few minutes and was told that Jonas would come out from a meeting in a short time. The secretary pointed a telling biro at him as he appeared.

Reporters have gathered outside the Research Council: headline hunters and interview hounds. A crowd of them is accreting.

Jonas looks wary and tired, but not unreceptive. “Help? What kind of help did you have in mind?”

“I left a message for you. It has to do with your work on autonomous agents and influence networks.”

Jonas stops and regards the older man.

“That was you,” he says thoughtfully.

“That was me.”

“I mentioned to you my student. Well, ex student, as it turns out. Did you try her?”

Bishop nods. “Yes, I am in touch with her. In fact, I have an appointment to meet her here.”

As the words come out, a slim beauty in dark, booted jeans with a broad leather belt and a short white winter-jacket appears through the main entrance, swishing her hair to one side. She sees Jonas and strides up to the two men.

“Hello,” she says. “What the hell is going on out there?” Then: “Remember me?”

She seems a little thinner and a little tougher than the last time he saw her, but he responds with an air of pleasant surprise, for someone obviously a little stressed out.

“Sara, speak of the devil.”

“And angels appear!” she chastizes with smiling eyes.

“I am Ed Bishop,” Ed Bishop adds.

“Ah hei, nice to meet you. So you two know each other?”

“Ah no, no we don’t. Not yet. But now that we are all here, I would very much like to talk to you both. This is a matter of some importance and I know that it is going to interest you.”

Jonas looks around, as if wondering where they should go. His office? The receptionist is waving to him.

“Jonas, Kaja is here... ” she whispers.

She points out of the entrance at a figure in a long coat, paused at the foot of the steps with a small child.

“Damn.” he says.

It never rains, but it pours.

He casts a worried look at his visitors. “I can’t see her now.” Then to the receptionist: “Tell her I had to go out would you?” He looks panicked. “Please, both of you, come this way.”

He practically pushes them along a corridor, leading to a separate but connected part of the building.

“Come on, this way. I don’t want to run into her on the way out.”

Vibe and Bishop regard one another quizzically.

As he shuffles them out, Sara says. “Don’t suppose you’ve you talked to the embassy? Have you heard from the team?”

He shakes his head. “Sorry.”

“I think I want to kill someone.”

He grunts. “Governments are shutting the door on everyone’s future, not just yours.”

“Aren’t there laws protecting against this kind of thing?”

“Glad you asked,” he winces without further embellishment.

He leads them into something of a blind alley within the building; the only way forward is an emergency exit.

“I’m really sorry for this,” Jonas says. “I have some personal matters that are taking up my time. We won’t have any peace if she finds us, and we can’t go out front because of the reporters. Let’s go out and try to find a coffee shop.”

They seem agreed. Jonas pushes the fire exit bar and they slip out into bright, grey daylight.

It one of those damp days when sounds travels more efficiently than usual, when cars make more noise and passing aircraft seem almost to be upon you. Crackling winter tires break up the air making it hard to talk. Not far away from them, there is an unholy sound of roaring people flocking, from the old Blitz house.

“What’s going on there?” Jonas asks.

“Youth activists, It think,” Bishop says. “They have organized a some kind of demonstration. I think it’s some commemoration–or commiseration of the old Blitz house.”

“Looked like there were Nazi hecklers throwing things at them when I passed there a moment ago.”

She sees that Jonas looks a little freaked.

“We shouldn’t go that way.”

“They’re just people,” Vibe says. “A bit too loud, but they’re probably harmless.”

He shudders.

“I suppose I’m getting too old for this kind of thing.”

“People with a cause to unite them,” Bishop mutters. “A mob.”

“Yesterday it was Christian Rights on the stands on Karl Johan. Old people complaining about young people. Plus ça change, eh? Maybe I’m turning into one of them.”

“Was there violence?”

“No, no. Well, not physical, though I’m not convinced their message is any better than a thump in the face. Small town politics, but there is big money behind it all. They are probably more dangerous than a few louts. They ties to established institutions. They take each other more seriously.”

“I heard some gang was coming to get us,” Vibe says to Jonas.

Bishop nods. “Tried to get your advisor here. Come on, let’s go back up this way. We can walk through to St Hanshaugen. It shouldn’t be too slippery.” He starts off up the road that snakes up the hill, passing by blocks of flats built along the curvilinear road. There are plenty of cars parked on each side to conceal them from watching eyes, and they can cut in to the many pedestrianized side streets.

Vibe looks at Jonas, intensely. “Really?”

He nods. “Really. They never got as far as you. You went away at the right time, but they probably would have.”

“Right now their cronies are busy with a protest rally. You’ll be okay for now.”

“So, Mr. Bishop, what is it you do exactly? You still haven’t told me.”

“Nor me,” Vibe adds.

“Yes. This is where it gets difficult to explain. I have an interesting job,” he procrastinates, slowing his stroll to face them. “Basically you could say that I am employed to apply the science of control and maintenance to policing our society. I work for the police force. Interpol.”

“Coppers aren’t just running around hitting people over the heads with their truncheons anymore, eh?”

“Well, there is still a bit of that too, I’m sure.”

“Does it pay well? Career prospects?”

He laughs at Vibe’s odd question. “Not really. International policing has to make its own money these days. We invest in businesses and currencies and run things like a charity–donations from interested Samaritans, and so on. You can’t fight corruption in governments if you are on their payroll. So funds are limited. I get a comfortable amount.”

“So you don’t work for the Norwegian police?”

“We are part of the international branch, but we are formally part of Norwegian police force, yes.”

“And you say you need our help?”

He smiles. “Yes. Two different reasons, as it happens. Finding people with a science education isn’t all that easy these days. Recruiting people to work for something other than money is just as hard. You both have expertise that overlaps with our own.” To Sara, “You have been doing some very interesting things in the VR. Perhaps you have some friends too. I am not sure about that, but I know at least that you are involved.”

Her eyes widen and she laughs nervously. “What things? What makes you think it is me?”

“Well, mainly because it is my job to know.” He winks.

Vibe smiles sweetly.

“The bottom line is this,” he says. “Law and order, the world over, is going down the tubes, largely due to the fact that people no longer see the need to rely on one another as citizens. That makes it hard for the police forces of the world to function properly.”

“Uh, here it comes.” Vibe gives him a look. “At school we learned that society has never been better in terms of individual standard of living.”

Bishop seems to recognize her involuntary disrespect and crushes it, calmly but firmly like a policeman should. “Don’t you ever question what they teach you at school? Or have they made you into a nice standard letter size songbird for their tired notions?”

She swallows the thought without reply.

“Police forces are struggling against the odds. Something has to be done to preserve their potency. After the big cuts in resources, in the last decade, police are no longer really equipped to deal with the rising criminal gang culture. When vigilante groups start to spring up, then you know the you are in serious trouble.”

“Where’s Batman when you need him?”

Jonas is following the conversation, but his head is scanning around to see who might be following them.

“We are trying to preserve that potency, partly with the help of governments and partly in spite of them.”

“Are you talking about the game business?” Jonas asks. “It was in the news a while back. About the American government spreading its message of peace and capitalism?”

Bishop regards him. “That’s part of it,” he agrees. “But it’s much more complicated than that. The whole thing is a battleground and our research has shown that the messages they are trying to convey are complex and intermingled. I’d have to explain some of the background... ”

“Please, go ahead. I’m interested. You know I had no idea that the police did research.”

Vibe nods. “Does this have to do with the job you mentioned.”

Bishop nods. “All right. Let’s see where do we begin?” He points up a side road. “Let’s go up here.” The road is quieter and it is easier to hear him speak. “So, let’s say there are several theories about how to keep society in order. There is the expression of rules in law, but how to enforce? We can start with rule by fear. Fear of reprisal, whether it be incarceration or punishment, fines, torture in a dictatorship, or the threat of what might happen if people do not behave by law... ”

“Happy thoughts. Okay, so we have done fear.”

“Then there is the dogma of good habits. Prevention.”

“If everyone is good, then everyone else sees them being good and wants to join in, and so the whole world is just hunky dory?”

“Exactly.”

“What else?”

“Well, now we have to decide if we have democratic law or edict from an authority, like a church.”

“Which you are going to tell us is an oxymoron, because no one can agree on what is right and wrong.” Vibe kicks herself internally for involuntary huffiness.

Grow up, girl. Just relax.

She finds herself wishing that she were sitting somewhere working on her thesis, programming or doing something where she did not feel out of place.

“No, no one ever agrees. The point is not that everyone in a democracy has to agree. A sufficient majority has to agree, but what’s more important then is that the remainder of society has to accept defeat. They have to sacrifice their ideals for the sake of the whole system. It is a trade off and the result does not necessarily have to be benign. It just has to be agreed.”

“So that’s the catch?”

“The catch is that people do not accept defeat anymore, because they can pretty much do as they please. We all have the tools and the means to do essentially as we like today. That makes it very difficult to maintain the traditional institutions of government. It makes it hard to police rules that are openly considered irrelevant by a population without a sense of civic duty.”

Jonas is nodding. “Money pulls the strings these days,” he says. “It has nothing to do with democracy. You just need money. The only voting democracy we have is in kids’ mobile polls and pop contests.”

“Some people have said that the real threat is global capitalism. That is the West’s form of terrorism. It’s not terrorism, of course, but it is a kind of a virus against democracy, in the real sense.”

“Apes used to groom one another and that is how a clan was bound. Now we exchange money. It’s just virtual grooming. Little gluons that bind society together.”

Jonas seems to be enjoying this peculiarly abstract discussion. Vibe thinks it is all just a bit odd, here in the middle of town.

Hello! I’m here... .

“Nature abhors democracy,” Bishop adds. “It is inefficient – except in very special conditions.”

“So I don’t get it. Where is this going?” Vibe says, silencing incoming on her mobile. “Where do we come into this?”

“You know about controlling the behaviour of autonomous agents.”

“Robots, maybe... Come on, let’s go up here.”

Jonas leads them into an avenue that rises even more steeply through the residential functionalism, towards some shops.

Bishop stops for a moment, panting at the exertion of walking up the steep incline.

“There are basic principles ... involved ... that can be transferred. And besides... we are also using robots: virtual robots ... in game playing.”

“What for?”

He takes several breaths. “For encouraging people ... to obey the law, ... and have a sense ... of civic duty.”

“People can be bought or manipulated.”

“Yes, they can. We can. Or you can brainwash them.”

“Brainwash them?” Vibe’s exclamation seems to be suggesting that they have lost their marbles completely.

“If you can make everyone agree by brain-washing them from an early enough age, how can you say that it is wrong? How do you know that you are not already brainwashed? Maybe its a good thing. You have agreement, after all. And it’s a legal game move in the democratic process.”

“But that’s manipulation.”

He nods. “Sure. Point to a country or society where this has not happened. What society does not preach some form of moral righteousness? Do you mind if we stop here a moment?”

She shrugs.

Jonas adds: “Politics used to assume individual maturity and deal with objective issues of society’s development and the governance of popular intellect. Now it is full steam ahead in talking directly to people’s emotional brains, manipulating their subjective beliefs and views of the world. It’s telling us how to think and feel.”

“And that mollycoddling is needed precisely because we are all getting more selfish.”

“You address individual subjectivity because people are no longer a uniform ideal gas. It has to be personal, or they don’t care.”

They pause to catch their breath. Sara texts a message to someone furiously and refocuses. She is not fully certain that she understands what she is doing here. Jonas does not seem disturbed or surprised by the conversation, rather he seems distant, as if thinking about something else.

“So,” Bishop concludes, as if turning a page, after his moment. “All of this brings us to the virtual reality games. They have become the new battleground for indoctrination. It’s about the competition of doctrines in a group: who is most efficient at tapping into people’s instincts and needs.”

“The survival of the fittest doctrine?”

“Partly. Well. There are many degrees of freedom here. Money plays a role too–social currency. I shouldn’t get these things muddled.”

“The survival of the richest.”

“For an idea or a doctrine to take hold, it just has to be robust and sustainable amongst the forces and processes that move society. It does not have to be right or wrong, it only needs to have support in the processes of the day. That is why we are able to pass laws about all kinds of things that seem immoral.”

Jonas nods. “Like patenting genes. Drug companies have the power, using the money they command, to distort the balance of opinion in their favour by paying for huge indoctrination campaigns.”

“This has become par for the course,” Bishop agrees. “There is no one who is not using these techniques today. Not even us.”

Bishop talks directly to Vibe. “I have been looking you up. Do you know how rare it is to find someone with an education like yours? Someone close by who has actually studied similar problems? You could be invaluable to us, with your knowledge of the techniques. Imagine applying your knowledge to social engineering instead of robotics.”

Sara is not sure whether she feels a little taller, because he clearly respects her, or a little freaked out, because he is a weirdo who has her in his sights.

“I’m ... flattened,” she says.

They continue on up the hill to the small shopping street, and pause at the crossroads. With busses thundering past, the conversation falls to Jonas and Bishop. Cannot really hear what they are saying. She is left to mull over the idea of working with a megalomaniac with a social justice complex, or signing on to social security and considering prostitution as a career.

She feels like a fraud. How could she, of all the unlikely souls, possible do this job–whatever it is he is even asking her to do. It seems totally weird and more than a little immoral. After everything that has happened to her in the past couple of weeks, there must be some simpler option than this?

“Let’s go in here,” Jonas says, pointing to a coffee shop with plenty of room. “I’m going to have to leave pretty soon, I fear. but you should keep on talking.”

They sit around a table and can look one another in the eyes for the first time. The sounds of the road fades into the background.

“The more you look at society,” Bishop rants, “the more you realize that it is not what you think it is.”

“Of course,” Jonas agrees, understanding his point, or at least believing that he does.

“We play these elaborate charades that we make up to pretend we are satisfied. They confirm our visions of what is good and right. You remember as a child how you used to make believe? You pretend to play out scenarios? Well you don’t stop as an adult. You just think you do.”

What am I doing here?

“All right. So civilization is a deception according to you?” Sara drones, in a funk. “We have society, politics, commerce. Isn’t that civilization?” She recalls the game of civilization and its basic milestones.

“Well, it sort of works, so it is not a deception. But only in terms of deeds.”

“Hello?”

He smiles vaguely, pursing his lips. “Everyone has their own delusions and it is not just some conspiracy, as some people think. They really believe in these delusions. That is the point. We are all out there, trying to control the world, but the world is really controlling us to a far greater extent and we just fantasize our involvement in it. But then you must have seen all of this in your field? I mean, all of these emergent phenomena in biology are cases in point.”

“Is it worth saving?” Jonas sighs.

Vibe cuts in with some searing logic that raises their eyebrows. “If you are a purist, and society cannot be protected by legitimate, authorized means, then you can make the argument that it does not deserve to exist. It is doomed to failure. Stability will surely be lost to competing opportunism.”

Bishop laughs in appreciation. “Yes!”

“It rocks and capsizes! So you need a police force to balance the boat. Mobsters have become sophisticated now. They are providing all kinds of signals of their own. Business and religion are in there too, if you care to distinguish them.”

“The good news is that all of the money that we were forced into spending on anti-terrorism measures, to appease the United States, in the early years of this century, is now proving to be a good investment for helping us with the gangs.”

“Computer tools?”

“Information is power. Even the simplest-minded form of gang has a structure that is based on relationships and interactions. It is all networking. The tools we have developed to study networks have allowed us to see connections and important clues that we might never have understood. You have a network model, tied to a database and then you perform correlations. And then there is the VR.”

“Gaming technology?”

“Exactly. They have masted quite different skills: they don’t analyze the present, they create the present in incredible detail.”

Sara nods. “I can go along with that... ”

“You might think it sounds like a bad conspiracy theory, but it is just the day to day mechanics of marketing, essentially. And it is getting easier. People are not as critical of what they hear as they used to be. Take the example of you two. The mob, or some vigilante group, whatever, you see, misunderstood something about your work. They found a title on the web.”

“Yes – it has all the right words for an uneducated mind to attract attention. We believe that they are looking for you because they are trying to master these techniques for themselves. Lucky for us, people don’t understand much of what they read anymore. We have already apprehended two men who were sent to possibly kidnap you.”

“And who is it you want to influence, Mr. Bishop?” Jonas asks, entirely dispassionately.

“Everyone. I want to make sure that there is a fair fight in the information, so that no one can usurp our lives. Some people think that means you have to leave things alone. But they forget that every living system needs maintenance to keep it looking good.”

A low buzz emanates from Jonas’s wrist. “Excuse me,” he says. He gets up and walks away to speak in private.

Bishop mutters on philosophically. “To have a working society, you need to have a whole chain of self-fortifying things in place. It’s so fragile.”

Vibe watches Jonas, looking somewhat agitated and feels a little sorry for him. Something is going on today for him. Perhaps his life is not as cushy as she has assumed.

“So you think it’s all breaking up?”

“Look around! Who has respect for the law? If people don’t basically agree with the justness of a law, they will not enforce it themselves, and then the police can’t do anything but erode their own authority by trying to enforce it.”

“We take more liberties than before? We’re more liberal. Is that the same thing?”

“We have to respect the idea of abstaining from certain behaviours for the good of others. We have to obey the laws we create. We must respect the people who make and enforce the law, and they also have to respect it themselves. Even that isn’t easy. We have a huge problem in some areas with police thinking that they are above the rest of society and that the law basically does not apply to them – they can park their cars in a no-stopping street. That only leads to other people imitating their lawlessness and turning tiny transgressions into large ones.”

She nods. “I could tell you a story about rural policing.”

“All of this is failing, Sara. Our work is about fighting that reversal by reminding people of the values that society is based on. It is a new kind of meta-policing if you like.”

Jonas interrupts.

“Look, I apologise, but I’m going to have to go back. Maybe you can keep me informed. It sounds as though Sara can help you with what you need. And I am happy to support this. This is very interesting.”

The café is quiet at this time of day. Oil paintings, dark and brooding, fill the walls of room, between its large windows; the imagery is somewhere between fascinating and disturbing.

“Who’s the artist?” she asks.

“Oh.” He laughs absently. “I’m not sure.”

“Cocoa,” she says.

He smiles appreciatively. “The maintenance theorem says that we cannot really control anything. At best we can fool ourselves by keeping a system in a rough balance over time. But we are never precisely in control. We only moderate the balance of change so that it never strays too far from what we want.” He pauses to take a sip of his cocoa. “This game that people are playing in the VR. “The purpose of the game is to serve the needs of the world’s largest trans-global companies. They are now suffering the from the very lack of law and order that their own ideas have resulted in. “Captive audience.”

“Sounds hard.”

“Me?”

“You wish. It’s one of the ways that we benefit from the technology built in by the government for modelling. It looks like noise, but you are just one person and you cannot possibly generate the amount of information needed to be noise. But you have found some kind of pattern that is even more effective than noise at causing mixing, convection in the system. Instead of allowing it to fall into its preferred configuration, your activities have been preventing that from happening.”

“My friend and I like to have a little fun with the palm heads.”

“Palm heads?”

“Gamers whose salutes are stuck on to their foreheads.”

Bishop laughs.

“You have them dancing to your merry tune.”

Like the pied piper...

“I suppose it’s something I learned from the VeiVeks. If you keep on applying random strong signals to a diverse mass, you will just keep splitting it up. You’ll never unite them. It’s the opposite of what they want. It’s like saying to a group of people: wear this fashion, no wear that fashion! Not everyone will hear all the messages, and even if they do – not everyone can respond. Too many war cries just create tension.”

“And applied to people, the same thing works.”

“People will change, yes, at some individual threshold that you can’t really predict. Just like the VeiVeks. So, if you want to be sure, you have to out-do each message and you end up with an arms-race. That is not a recipe for stability.”

Bishop nods. “That was my idea too. It’s actually better to be hands-off. Let people mix into stable masses – find equilibrium by themselves. If you keep on tugging, nothing ever settles down. They go unstable. The conclusion is that you have to makes them all deaf so they can’t listen.”

Cathy Kim is standing in the dry heat of the little ghost town in the Utah desert. Outwardly, it appears abandoned: cheap hotels with broken doors and smashed toilet bowls. Inwardly, it has been concealing a terrible secret.

The ghosts have been haunting here.

Until a few moments ago, this has been a centre of operations for one of the worst religious fanatic groups. The place was just bursting with illegal operations.

They are in home territory here. Not far away is a little town with only eight hundred inhabitants but fifty different churches. Are they involved in this?

No one was here, no human. But a single computer connected by parabolic antenna to a network tap, was purring its operational readiness, handling coordinating activities for lists of operatives.

How can so much chaos be so organized?

There are explosives here next to bibles. This is nothing more than a terrorist camp. The blood-red rock of the surrounding desert seems to condone this stockpile of filth, as if the blood of the enemy has been congealed into boulders and cliffs. There are professional recruiting agencies operating out of this camp: preying on kids to break into computer systems, recruiting hackers while persuading them to keep their virginity. Lists of names and addresses on blocks of embedded memory. This will take some time to analyze.

“Justice is a luxury some people have to fight for.”

The baking heat makes her a little dizzy, or is it simply the impact of all this?

She wants to get back into the air-conditioned safety of the car, and have the officers take her back to civilization.

“You shouldn’t be here, Ma’am.”

Time to make Den deliver her from evil once and for all.

He remembers her tight sensual body and feels aroused, wishing that she could be there with him at that moment; but in this situation there is also something about her that seems small and merely self serving. Den nods. He’s seen enough of it, now that you mention it. “So, how are you getting on?” he asks her. “I’m still investigating some leads.”

She pauses. “Well, I got it covered I guess. Looks like you are a definitely a centrally important person in this. But there are others sneaking in from the sides.”

Some anonymous Spanish beauties... , he thinks.

Kim seems to toy with something, then decides to share. “And I think I’ve figured out what might be going on now,” she says. “If we’re still helping each other.”

Dean simply stares back coldly. He has heard this kind of criticism before from the enemies of America, but never from within his inner circle of allies. No one has ever dared to say such a thing in a closed session of the Lion’s Den.

The senator shakes his head. “You are wrong, sir. The future of America may well be jeopardized. The world needs class systems and it needs superpowers. We cannot afford to relinquish our hold. Damned heart burn. All this excitement, all the effort that has gone into this behind the scenes. He’ll be glad when it is all over.

Den left Catalin Cortina feeling oddly off balance. Once again, he finds himself thrown into uncertainty. He has made the decision to stay in San Sebastian for a few days, while he thinks about their meeting. In spite of her practical dismissal, he does not feel yet ready to be written off.

San Sebastian is an agreeable location for thinking. There are bars here where he can hang out, places to go to enjoy himself and think. He has seen one place where the women seemed to be just waiting for someone to whisk them off their feet. But something was broken in him last night.

It was her.

She changed him, his view, not merely of his work, but of himself. He thought he was succeeding in his work; now he feels like a loser.

Suddenly, he feels the precariousness of his situation. He is clinging on to his obligations more by luck than by judgement. It is something like the sensation of skiing down a black run, in the Alps, at full speed, barely winging it, almost flying off into oblivion at each irregularity in the terrain, legs burning and shaking with the effort of standing up to the barrage of gravitational anomalies. This is not being in charge.

He has to admit that she was good. She is an expert manipulator. She has transformed his feeling of serendipitous triumph into one of minor unworthiness. She agreed to see him at his request, but rather than convincing her of his own value, she has turned the tables on him. He was putty in her hands.

She is someone to look up to, no doubt about that.

Don’t they know that people have to sleep?

Have to work?

This apartment box does not know its neighbours, does not fraternize with the other life-forms that use the stairwell. There is no shared toilet. If you meet someone at the launderette, just ignore them.

From your box, you cannot tell where the sound is coming from. Contact sound reverberates, in this rabbit-hutch, like Morse code through a submarine... You feel like a ship in a bottle that collided with its fog horn. You hate your neighbours for their insensitivity, but you it never occurs to you to think about their needs.

To hell with them. You are never likely to meet them anyway.

One has to admit, there is a certain austerity to it all. Someone’s hard graft and industrial ambition yet clings onto the present in these old brick-hulled trading vessels. They seem like outcast elders of the global village: buildings that cry out their dereliction and alienation. They can be tolerated, but not revered by the city of today.

Shuttered warehouses, filled with prosperous memories, disused or adapted to fringe life: they have all been rejected from the city’s mainstream dreams. The bricks recall a time when buildings were meticulously stacked, piece by piece, not injection-molded into computer generated spaces. Rows of individual units worked together here, in harmony, to create a functional and pleasing pattern. Unfortunately, there is no time for such rituals in the modern world.

But there is no doubt about it: this is construction from an age that tolerated texture and variety. Every brick does not have to be identical. That is surely appropriate, under the circumstances. It seems to say something about the city’s policy. Where is this rugged art in the brushed aluminium and glass buildings of today? Where is the willingness toward cultural diversity, embracing the foibles of nature’s own materials? Where are the open arms embracing society’s minor tributaries?

Three figures descend the incline towards this riverside gallery of twisted past. Over the rickety wooden bridge that crosses the river, burrowing through unkempt trees, held in check by wrought iron railings. Rats scuttle near the water.

The arched holes, where windows once were, are now boarded up, mostly. Imagine the once hot, orange light of industry in these buildings: a crucible of molten iron lighting up the arches with its promise of wealth and purpose.

Today the bricks are painted over, first with black, prima facie canvas and then with luminous pop art effigies. These buildings are fit only for troubled youths and eccentric artists. This is not the slick polish of commerce and orthodoxy.

Joseph’s centre lies in this outcast realm, rehabilitating disenfranchised youth from their self-imposed rejection. The buildings seem like a fitting place to locate the centre. Could some of this nobility rub off on the city’s new squatters? The people of that past were more responsible, more consumed of the necessities of their survival than in imagined disputes and conflicts. This is a place to learn about the meaning of building one’s legacy, and abandoning whimsical destruction born out of the boredom and absent hope of today.

What happened to that age? Where did it go? Should we be glad that no one has to struggle for their existence anymore?

The visitors are wearing the suits of the present. They look out of place here, Joe thinks. They are church representatives: lawyers. They come with money in the form of glad tidings. They are coming to buy this centre. They want to run it, to change it. They have brought their establishment with them. One can almost taste the sour flaw of reasoning, but that is not his concern. There are no spires here. This is not where people reach out to God above. This is where God’s agents lurk in the shadows to capture what souls they can.

“Our programme takes the kids who have become caught up in crime,” he will tell them. “we get kids who have come straight from prison.”

“The Get Smart programme seems like a success. We would hope to extend it, to bring a more Christian message to these kids,” they will reply.

Is this what he wants? Is this what these kids need? What they understand is the currency of violence. Paying back. There is an unwritten rule of the street: people sort out their own problems. It’s tribal.

What should he tell them? “The increasing willingness to use weapons to solve any dispute is their sickness. For a lot of them, their horizons simply don’t extend any further than their own town district. A lot of disputes start just because an outsider strays into their territory. These kids have been picking up weapons to solve their problems since they were eleven or twelve.”

Erland over there was convicted for grievous bodily harm. The victim was left permanently brain-damaged for the price of a piece of dope. There is a picture here to remind him of the consequences of his actions. All for the sake of enhancing his reputation on the street. Respect, so they say.

This has been a place to study modern city tribalism, to learn about it and to understand its origins. What will it become now? Will they simply try to paint over the offending surface with evangelical rituals? It might appeal to the aging wealthy right, but it is no answer to the problem. Just because someone is singing a happy song, it does not mean that they are well-adjusted.

Joe got involved in this programme out of his own conviction about Christian values. He does not recall the part of the bible where it talks about brainwashing. If the money they were supposed to get from Jonas was forthcoming, then they could turn these suits away and carry on as usual.

So they come, he thinks, to weed out the diseased element of society, not to heal it. And it is not merely these violent kids–just go down to the city’s edge. There are plenty of strange, twisted people staggering or riding bikes, bent and distended by drug-alcohol abuse, looking like nothing that nature would have allowed: is this also part of what humanity is? Perhaps we are all simply insane in different ways, perversions of nature.

Jonas would have said: “You shouldn’t even talk of disease. It’s opportunism. It’s one organism that says, hey, if you’re gonna be stupid, I’ll exploit the opportunity, thank you.”

We think in static terms. Change, aging and disease: you are standing still and other stuff is getting the better of you. A little hedge trimming and weeding is fine, but killing God’s children goes beyond the reason.

“Maybe rap is a channel that can reach them,” he hears one of them say, as they approach the entrance.

They arrive at the entrance and step into the simple open room of the old mill, where Joe is waiting.

“Good morning, friend!”.

A row of bulging suits, beaming at him like expectant fruit, wearing mildew like a bad aftershave. They know their trade. Eat ’em up and spit ’em out. Infect their kernels and let them grow into diseased bushes.

There was surely a reason why God set the burning bush alight.

Jonas prostrates his soul before the symphony. The music is a soundtrack to his troubled consternation, dark and full of the tremors of gratuitous complaint. The day has ground him down to the point at which escape was his only option. So here he must lie, resonating with the angst, until it absorbs the energy from him.

A symphonic masterpiece assumes command of its audience, physically and mentally, he thinks. He has chosen a tragic, wasteland of war-torn desolation to ease his suffering. Its wintery introduction of frigid strings gradually descends into a tar pit of inescapable, strung gravity. Deep grumbling friction fades and is replaced by a sudden race of bows hacking rhythmically like axes clearing a forest. Then, scintillating violins, herded by grave trombones, swell like portents of a pending revelation. Military snare drums snap him to his senses and the sardonic tones of the woodwind mock his optimism with their grey corroded snoring. Life is this rusty pipe – don’t expect any more from it.

The music penetrates him, violates his defences, and works its cleansing magic as if the experience of this tortured symphony is a deeply acting antibiotic for his personal strife, using up all of his emotions.

Schostakovich knows this, he thinks. He understands pain. It jars from his music.

The eleventh lifts him, shows him pride of stature, then lowers him gently to confront the hopelessness of his misery. Then just as the thought of continuing seems impossible a life-giving rain of strings pours over him and washes away the dirt and decrepitation of those treacherous woodwind vermin. Finally, thundering brass and percussive artillery shake him to alertness and leave him spent at the climactic tidal wave of the gong. The blast flings him across the universe leaving him stranded and alone.

For minutes he cannot move or speak. Then he begins to relate once again to the objects around him: his body, his hands. He breaths and nods. The music is his confidante. He bears his soul to this music as he could to no mere human. Thank goodness he has the solitude to enjoy it. Still, the complexity of the symphony is still mere child’s play compared to life itself.

He looks about his cocoon of familiarity, at the books that he has collected over the years. They are familiar and comforting; they are friends.

It is not the notes of life’s symphony but the spaces in between them that heal him. His cocoon is a controlled environment in which he can exclude everything that he does not want. The nourishing familiarity cleanses his frustrations. The friendly books, old friends that don’t answer back, don’t complain or demand. His film collection, fantasy to transport him away as a passive spectator. His music.

The doorbell warbles, making him jump up in panic. Jonas collects himself and goes to pick up the door-phone.

“Jonas, it’s Joe. Can I come up?”

“Joe?” He rubs his tired eyes. “Come in.”

“They were like a couple of wasps, Jonas.” Relentlessly and mindlessly picking away at other people’s business and dirty garbage. “And they were standing there just waiting to sting at the first sign of fear. I fear them more than any of the kids at the centre.”

“I don’t know what to say.”

“It’s not your fault.”

“Are you sure? Maybe they heard about this business over funding. It could be my fault for starting a media circus.”

“The council funds... Everything has been turned upside down.”

“I’m sorry.”

“C’est la guerre.”

“Funny you should put it like that. More whisky?”

He shakes his head. “I suppose I’ll have to notify the other sponsors that we won’t be part of these larger city projects.”

“The European thing?”

“Get Smart, Save our Schools.”

“No kidding.”

“Thing that worries me is that some of the kids have no hope without us. People don’t take care of their own in these communities anymore. I’m afraid of what could happen when we are not running the centre.”

“What?”

“The kids are not all that well balanced, Jonas.”

“What might they do?”

Joe raises his eyebrows and tilts his head slightly.

“They come to us sometimes because they feel that they are lost, that no one cares about them. But other times they have been given an ultimatum that they cannot handle. They lack the social skills to resolve the crises they make for themselves.”

“And the weak shall inherit the Earth.”

“Jonas, if you have never experienced the feeling they have of being utterly trapped by circumstances–with no possible way out, then you have not contemplated suicide.”

In fact, I can relate to that, Jonas thinks.

These past days, he has understood, for the first time in his life, why someone might consider it. You are just trundling along in life, mastering your job, making everybody happy and then suddenly something happens that is utterly dangerous to that stability. You go into a blind alley that seems like a good move, but you realize that it’s a cliff top. There is no way back without hurting everyone who means something to you, and there is no way forward because there are immovable obstacles in your way. Perhaps you are faced with a choice: to kill your lover or your child. How do you choose? You can’t go forward. you can’t go back. What other choice is there but to reset your options and start over? Remove the centre of the problem.

“Violence is often their language. It’s a matter of desperation. They either have to die slowly, where they stand, or jump and get it over with quickly. But if you take your life, you know it will hurt the people you love and that makes you feel even worse. Eventually the pain threshold increases to the point where you cannot bear it anymore and you self-destruct.”

It seems like those old films from the 60’s where people used to talk computers to death by giving them some logical contradiction. But where it the logic?

“I didn’t mean to ... ”

“And all the Evangelical Lutheran Lawyers want is to buy a captive audience.”

Where indeed.

He thinks of Kaja, the times she calls and asks him to be there for her. And he usually isn’t. Is it by choice that he prioritizes work, or is there a greater responsibility? Could she understand this at all?

Is anything important, if it is not about the two of them?

He looks at his pile of old music CDs. One for every bad mood. A pill for every malady. They seem like old friends.

“I have never understood religious communities,” Jonas shakes from his his head. “It all seems hostile to me. And yet sometimes the rigours of these dogmas have inspired great beauty, great music.”

“The music of Bach, Chopin... Discipline is not a bad thing.”

“Alfred Schnittke’s fourth symphony, a perfect discipline of tonal religious bureaucracy. Discipline is okay, Unless it is used to suppress creativity.”

“Yes.”

“Did I tell you? The government has a goon squad now–auditors who check every action we take. We have no freedom of expression anymore, not in this current political climate.” They will be sending more of them tomorrow. They do not need him any more. “Oh, Joe. There are times in our lives when it seems that disaster just piles on disaster and everything seems beyond repair. Don’t you think?”

He frowns into a distant space and then inhales deeply as if recalling something important. “I have to back out of these project commitments. Did you ever read about S.O.S.? The organization that runs it?”

He recalls some papers in a folder. Jonas shrugs. “Rings a bell. I got sort of side-tracked.”

“Save-Our-Schools. It’s run by... well, never mind.”

“Is there anything you can do, if the government has already changed its mind?”

“The government is not the people. There are still some advantages to our predilection for these things.” He taps on his mobile. “Bureaucracy works both ways. Tar pits might capture the wildlife, but they also stop the predators from reaching them.”

Joe lifts his head, as if he is signalling incongruous pride above his flaring nostrils. “You gave me an idea, Jonas.”

He nods.

Jonas raises his glass. “Hope for us yet.”

Mary is collecting and retaining. She has followed a lead from Milan to Copenhagen. She knows their key players, the principal components, the eigenvalue centres, and she has a causal tree of probabilities to bring that cartel into Denny’s reach.

She knows their likes and dislikes.

She has a ninety percent full transition matrix telling them how to get there from here.

How to push them in the right direction.

She has a model with a sixty two percent probability of success.

Time to report back to her brother.

He likes to call here his pet rock.

“An influence agent, or succubus as we like to call them, is a virtual character whose judgement is motivated by a fuzzy goal.”

“A fuzzy goal?”

“Something that is not too blatant or obvious.”

Vibe and Preeta stare at each other from across the room, for a long instant. She has heard about Preeta from one of the others, some dribs and drabs. It was she who located her, who discovered her. Now here she is.

Fascination, or is it perhaps a sense of threat, halts them like deer in the headlights. How will this alter the dynamics of this little group? Who will be the alpha-female now?

Brown and blue eyes meet in space. She believes she see some admiration in the look, and then the moment passes. Vibe feels that they have looked into one another’s’ souls and negotiated a stand-off in that instant. They will be a team, not adversaries.

We are the same somehow, Vibe thinks.

It’s that old tree again: the power of life expunged from it long ago. The remains of it leer like an angry witch, staggered by years of discord, and petrified here, fingers and icicle nails jabbing a final accusation at its absent assailant. A girl sits on the ground at its base, leaning against it. Tired shards of bark wither around her in a solemn benison of extended death. The bark falls as snow and the world turns white.

She stays quietly in the little clearing, surrounded by towering trees, leaden with their snowy load. It is quiet and crisp, a beautiful night. Even now she cannot fail to appreciate the quietly beauty, the starry sky and the moonlight shadows of the trees. A slight breeze is blowing. Slowly it picks up and the pendulous hulks being to sway in a slow and lofty rhythm. The wind picks up steadily, chilling her to the bone.

Then she has been standing still for too long and her joints are seizing up in the cold. The trees seem to rise to the call of the wind, swaying in concert back and forth, back and forth. The shadows create a shimmering effect and the gusting wind shakes loose a momentary blizzard of snow, blasting it into the clearing, showering her in fine crystals and cutting through her with an icy blast. Then, as soon as it began, it is over and all it quiet again. The night is quiet and the wind that rolled off the mountain is silent.

She moves a few feet forward, crunching the snow with her boots.

“Are you coming back in?”

She awakens with a start.

Everyone in the team is too distracted to see the wood for the trees. That means it is not going to happen without her. Is it really her responsibility? Maybe it doesn’t matter whose responsibility it is.

Vibe knows, from the mountain patrols made by her little robots, that damage begets damage. Once something has fallen into a state of neglect, it will attract further abuse that compounds its misfortune. People treat stuff with derision if it looks like it’s already been spoiled. So the aim is to pick up the litter as quickly as possible. She knows this stuff.

They can set up a game with influence agents who create damage and robots that fix it. The math tells her that she should look in the most connected places in this virtual landscape of interconnections. That will tell her where to position her robots at any given moment.

“The theory of agent cooperation is quite straightforward. It’s all about building cooperation from free will.”

She imagines a naked woman and a man taking her from behind in some game simulation, saying: “Oh baby, if you vote for them, they will destroy us with their puritan values. We might never be able to meet like this again!” The man would of course choose what is most important to him.

“What the succubi have to do is to make an agreement. That means there has to be an incentive, and it means they have to make a contract about what it is they are going to do. It has to be a two way contract.”

“Well, it is a prototype society. We start with our nomadic hunter gatherers, then they start to gravitate. They bind to each other together by grooming one another – forming bonds. You scratch my back, et cetera. One monkey pulls nits out of the other and they reciprocate and the payoff is access to a nice orgasm at the end of it. Whatever.”

Jonathan coughs.

“Of course, all of this grooming is pretty expensive, so after a while they figure out the principle of a Trusted Third Party: the leader or god. It is actually cheaper to form a group by tying yourself to a common point than by tying yourself to everyone else in the group.”

“Self-organizing government?”

“Yup. Essentially, they pledge allegiance to a head monkey, or whatever and in doing so form an implicit group. It’s like joining a club. If you’re a paid member, you get the benefits of being a group. There’s an implied contract. It’s cheaper than maintaining contact with every single individual. Of course, the downside is that you then are connected to people you haven’t verified for yourself.”

“That’s what has happened to the church though right?”

“Yes. So we have to build something stronger and then attack their weak spots.”

Preeta picks up a pad of paper and a pen and places it in front of them. “Draw him a picture.”

Vibe grins.

She smiles at him, feeling smart and useful. “Good thinking, Batgirl. Here. Draw, say, ten blobs for the different agents. Now draw a line between every pair of blobs. There are nine lines coming out of every blob. That means that every blob has to behave nicely to nine others who are going to punish it if it doesn’t. If it breaks one of its obligations, it still have eight others to keep it in line.”

“Okay.”

“Now ask what happens if we have a centralized government. Now we pick one of the nodes as representative of the others, and we draw one line from each of the nine subordinates to the centrally governing node. Now there is only one line from each of the subordinates. It is very cheap to maintain, but if a line gets broken, then they are unbound by obligations. Then they are free of any order–they have fallen outside the system. It is quite precarious.”

“But the central node still has nine lines.”

“True. The central node is still obliged to do as much work as before, but the chance of keeping all its agreements is much smaller, because the likelihood of the other agreements being broken is so much greater. That’s where you try to break it up.”

“If you can.”

“Isn’t that what someone said today? At some point an operation becomes so big – so complex that no one really sees what it is anymore. It becomes too big for anyone to comprehend. It becomes a self-sustaining living organism. If you suddenly change your mind and try to kill it, all of its parts will resist, try to protect themselves.”

“You ought to nip these things in the bud,” she agrees. “But if you can cut the right channels of communication.” She strikes through the central nodes in her picture.
