“My government would not support me, so I am supporting them,” Vibe tells Preeta. They have found their way into the underground club, where Preeta found her friend. She considers it a celebration of her freedom.

“It is something I learned from this game I have been playing. Sometimes you have to take a loss to move forward. I came here because I realized I didn’t have to wait for approval of my advisor to figure this out. Call it arrogance or maybe inspiration. My dad’s always been a bad influence on my like that. And then the game reminded by of my duty.”

“So what was your revelation?”

“Just something. It occurred to me that there is more going on here than what I am doing. All this stuff I’ve been learning for the VeiVeks: it’s all based on old studies in social sciences, mathematical models that were done years ago. But those people seem to have forgotten those old models they came up with, so now we have to teach it back to them.”

“And you are willing to spend all this time and effort working on something you are not even sure you believe in?”

“Sometimes you’ve gotta climb the mountain just to see if what you’re looking for is up there,” she notes, from personal experience. “You have to take a certain risk.”

Preeta nods. “I think Dermot would not agree. He would say it was inefficient.”

“So who is this Dermot, anyway?”

I keep wondering that myself. “Mystery man.” She rolls her eyes a little. “He is a very good game programmer that Mr. Bishop recruited from a local company. But he is a little bit of a computer geek, I think. He is not so convinced of the importance of this work. I think he has other things on his mind.”

“When do we get to meet him?”

“He ought to be here now. He’s not showing it, but I think Bishop is furious that he has not been in to work. We have no idea what he’s doing. He is holding us back now. None of us knows how to animate these agents like he does.”

“I could probably figure it out,” Vibe suggests carefully. “Maybe not as well as him, but if he’s not here... at a push.”

“Something tells me he will show up.”

It’s my fault, she thinks. I have to put things right.

She casts her mind back to the evening when she left him at the bar and he fled like a scolded animal. It was not a nice thing to do to him. He seems so fragile, not hardened to the world as she is. She sacrificed his confidence for her own, as though she ate his soul and became stronger. No, that is being too melodramatic, but it doesn’t change the fact that it is her fault. She will make it right.

“So, what’s it been like for you meeting the group?”

Vibe shrugs. “Okay. not that different from the College really. What about you? You haven’t been here so long yourself from what I understand.”

“A few weeks. I am getting used to it. Even the darkness. Do you have a boyfriend?”‘

She shakes her head. “Not as we speak.”

“Looking?”

Should she tell her about Peter Green? Maybe not tonight. Besides, what is that really all about? She doesn’t know what to think anymore.

“You?”

Preeta shakes her head.

“Someone you left behind?”

“No, no one.”

What is happening far away in Kuala Lumpur? Are they okay? Her friends could be suffering because of her penchant for flight.

“So we have to fix you up with someone?”

“I’m fine for now, thank you.”

Are the Asian gangs still after her? Were they ever after her? Was it merely a ruse to recruit her? Her head is still dizzy with the possibilities. Perhaps it is time to stand and fight her tormenters, whoever they are?

There is something to be learned from Vibe. She seems all too ready to confront things; she doesn’t run away. Can you really steer your destiny by running? When these succubi learn to speak Punjabi, perhaps it will be possible to make a difference to the Indo-Pakistani hinterlands.

Preeta watches the interpol channels carefully every day, with the help of her worms and assimilation agents. She means to know if they really want to find her and if her friends are all right. And if no information surfaces, then it could be because there never was any gang. Nothing yet. In a sense, the very project they are working on now gives her a way to draw a line in the sand. If she can borrow Vibe’s courage, she could make a difference.

“So you know about the police database,” Vibe slips in. “How would I go about finding someone in the force?”

“Internationally?”

“No, here. When I was up in the mountains, I left something behind.”

Preeta wheedles the story of her backpack out of her, and Vibe tells it will a mixture of girlish indignation and cheeky bravado.

“How are you going to get it back?”

“I thought I would try contacting Frank first. He was nice.”

“You could go back?”

“Are you kidding? I don’t want to make things worse.”

“Are you going to report the woman?”

“Why? What’s the point?”

“Smuggling?”

“People have been smuggling ever since taxes were invented.”

People have different ideas of right and wrong.

But who is she to judge? In the past few weeks, she has not only fled from responsibility into an unknown future, merely for her own selfish gain, she has broken every imaginable taboo from her upbringing. She would be chopped up and burned alive if her family knew about her behaviour.

Vibe is a different kind of creature altogether, she thinks. She is sleek and elegant, but tough at the same time, like a Hollywood heroine, not like a Bollywood princess. And now that she has confided her story, Preeta can channel her admiration of her to see that there is a template for her own life in there. If she could become more like this Sara.

But has she really experienced the same kind of danger? Bravery is easy until you have felt the fingers of inevitable surrender touch your most vulnerable parts.

“I don’t know if Bishop really thinks I can do the job without a lot of help. I don’t want to leave now and make a bad impression. Besides, I don’t want to shatter his squeaky image of me.”

“Squeaky? You think? Why is it that old people always underestimate young people?”

“Wisdom comes with age?” Vibe jokes.

She laughs. “Prejudice comes with age. Knowledge, if you’re lucky.”

“I want to show him I can.”

“Good for you.”

“We can do it together.”

Preeta. “Yes. I think we can.”

Vibe regards her with a sly look. “So, tell me your story,” Vibe probes. “One of the boys was telling me it sounds exciting.”

Preeta goes blank. “That’s a long story. Maybe it should wait for another time.”

Vibe shrugs. “Okay.”

“I have a better idea.”

“What?”

“What about maybe you can help me find some new clothes? I have been trying to do some shopping since I came here.”

The fires of a different daemon summon a mischievous sparkle in Vibe’s eyes. “Oh... now we’re talking.”

She consults her mobile and starts to text a brief message into her wrist band.

“So you’ll take me shopping?”

“Hmmm. I think we need to introduce you to my friend Bea. You’re right. It’s about time we did a little prospecting.”

“I see it as my duty to be a kind of agent provocateur, Señor Morris. You are a yea sayer.”

“I’ve made a career of it,” he replies with sarcasm.

Den suppresses a rising frustration. His meeting is not working out as he had hoped. Catalin Constanca Alexandra Cortina has conceded interest in the fact that he did not simply run home with his tail between his legs, after their last meeting. She has made herself available for a rematch. It has not changed much, however. He might have won a little attention from her critical eye, but he has a long way to go before he can claim to have her respect.

She has agreed to meet him, for a second time, this time away from her impressive and distracting home. The little courtyard café nestles amongst the historical buildings of the old town. He expected that this neutral territory would remove her obvious advantage, but he is beginning to wonder.

She looks at him with an almost patronizing derision. Their sparring is not entirely friendly, he knows.

“Really? In my experience, Señor Morris, when people say they are looking for a career, what they mean is that they have no idea what to do. They are, in fact, looking for guidance. They want a place to belong and be held by the hand. They are not ready to move society forward by themselves, they are merely hoping to hitch a ride into retirement.”

“And you think I am such a person.”

“Are you telling me that you want to make a difference now, or are you simply changing allegiances?”

He summons all of his self-control, stuffing his ego a box that he can open to release the scream later. “You go out of your way to insult me,” he says calmly. “Is this how you usually do your business?”

“Here in the Basque we like to be direct. I do not have time for time-wasters. I have taken on an enormous task and it consumes me.”

“But you run a business along side your other activities. You know that we have to make a living from our work.”

“At the expense of principles?”

“Aren’t there some principles that have to be compromised to live in the real world?”

“That depends on the skill of the individual.”

“Or on the constraints of your company.”

“Ah, a company man,” she chides. “My company looks after me. I love my company.”

“But you are also a company woman, surely,” he presses, barely concealing his exasperation with her. Is she trying to make him show weakness?

“Companies can be both awesome and terrible at the same time,” she dodges. “Godlike and mind numbing. They lure you in like the wolf in the Little Red Riding Hood, yes? They give you your hood and tell you where to look, what to see, when to open and close your eyes. Then they give you a kind of life plan, to replace whatever you might have had. They promise to save your soul by delivering you from idleness, while they make you sign it away to the fires of hell, forcing you against others in competition.”

“You’re talking about workers, not management.”

“Are you sure?”

“I don’t see myself in that position.”

“You probably help to design indoctrination packages for companies.”

“That is one of the things we do, yes.”

“And this is not for management too?”

She’s right, he thinks. Damn it.

He attempts to maneuver out of her trap. “So you don’t think it is possible for someone like me to want to do the right thing? Isn’t that a bit hypocritical? What makes you so much better?”

“Actions speak louder than words, Mr. Morris. I am still waiting to see what you will do. I would like nothing more than to have you as an ally, but which gods do you worship?”

“I don’t think I worship... ”

“I think you worship perfection, for a start. You need approval for what you do.”

He nods. “You might be right. But I am willing to listen to criticism. Can you say the same?”

“Bravo. Listening is one thing. But will you take the necessary decisions? Will you implement the necessary measures to make things happen?”

She lifts her hands and looks up, as if reaching out, but always her burning gaze refocuses on his.

“Education has become my main priority. It is where everything begins. It will be either our future or our epitaph.”

“I can see that. But what can someone like me do about that?”

“But that is what someone like you must tell someone like me. That is your job, your speciality. Marketing is a subtle thing, I think. How can you bring this message to the world?”

“I suppose there are ways.”

“What about that book that recently became a bestseller, something that everyone is talking about. A conspiracy that makes everyone curious. Just that one book might stimulate thousands of new readers to become literate. A simple trash novel might have a huge positive effect on the world. Is that not a significant result? So much better than making people play passive games. How could you do the same in Africa or America?”

“Well, games are not just games anymore. They are whole environments. We might have actually come back full circle–to the point where people are making their own entertainment with what they find in the games. There is actual thinking involved in gaming now.”

“In research, our budgets are controlled by the opportunities programmes. That defines the areas on which one is allowed to concentrate. Huge amounts of money are thrown away on trend setting. But as a marketing manager you could define new trends. You can make things cool or necessary.”

“That is what the game consortium wants,” he agrees. “There doesn’t have to be a contradiction between encouraging learning and sending the messages that they want to send.”

“And what are these messages? Believe in the authority of the President? Believe in the authority of God and the Church. These are all very well, but they are not the messages that will save society in the log run. They are a plaster on a sore–one that will hurt when you have to rip it off again.”

“I am not a Christian, by any stretch of the imagination, but I can see the value of rebuilding community. The argument is that mobiles have effectively isolated people, by... ”

“I know the arguments, Señor. They might be true in parts of Europe or Russia and Japan, but in the U.S.? People have a culture of talking there. They blabber even more than the people of Spain! All right, they might not say anything significant to anyone off mobile, but they can still look one another in the eye. No, the problem is the fragmentation. The need for guidance and welfare. Keep me safe, at any cost, even if the cost is my individuality, my soul.”

“A deal with the devil?”

“When people expect the state or the environment to look after them, then they have lost the human spirit, the will to survive. They would rather sue someone if it rains and they get wet, than find a way to adapt and learn from the mistake. What they need is not a prayer group, but the presence of mind to make critical observations about the world. By telling them to accept the authority of a government or a church, all they have done is to stick people together with some glue. It is artificial. If people are transmitters of ideas, not just receivers, if they mix and talk and criticize one another–that is how a society works.”

“But the game consortium is trying to do exactly that.”

“Do you believe that? I think they have you wrapped around their, what you say, little finger?”

He ignores her thrust. “You have some interesting perspectives,” he says simply. “You’ve told me about a side of things that I had not thought about and I want to go back to High Wycombe and think through what you have told me. It would be helpful if you were more supportive of the effort. I didn’t have to come here, and I don’t have to help you now.”

“But I don’t want you to help me. I want you to do it for its own sake.”

“It could be no other way.”

“Why did you come here?”

Tell the truth, she will not believe anything else.

“Why? Because, as part of my research I am trying to identify the most important individuals in the game consortium. Your name came up, for obvious reasons. I wanted to know if I could use you as a vector in a campaign.”

“And instead, I have infected you?”

“There is a certain irony,” he agrees.

“You know, Mr. Morris, when I started this game idea with the others, I believed that the game project could be used to do considerable good in the world. I still think so, but that is not everyone’s motivation.”

“And you can’t persuade the other board members of your mission?”

“This co-called inner circle does not exactly seem to be on the ball. Even I can seen that they don’t know what they are doing. They are split and some of them are caught up in the Christian religious movement.”

“So you continue by yourself.”

“No, not by myself. I have many allies. I would like you to be one of those allies.”

“But only as a true believer.”

“Exactly. You have the power to interest people in a focused way, even while working for others.”

“Perhaps I am not an interesting enough person?”

“I think that you are more interesting than your understand yourself. But you are too willing to please others to get ahead. Please understand me, Mr. Morris. I believe passionately in what I do and I will invest in this goal, not because I am a philanthropist, but because it is our only survival option.”

Den picks up his almost empty glass of water and swirls the ice around.

“It’s not just me. I have to persuade the people I work with.”

“Now you are a big man–a figurehead.”

He ponders. “It seems like a small thing, a change of style. To make people use their minds. To ask questions. To think about what they see.”

“These opportunities are born of our little weaknesses.”

“Then here’s to those moments of weakness,” he salutes with his glass and drinks the rest of the water. “If what you say is true, they won’t last long anyway, once people start to cotton on.”

She nods. “If more people start to think for themselves you will have to rethink your strategy. But I think that is something you have to do anyway in your business.”

He nods. “I think I can sell the idea to my company. The game consortium just have to like the results we produce. They don’t even have to be aware that there is an ulterior motive. As long as we can still make money.”

“You will have to be careful. They are not stupid, at least not in that way.”

“They seem to think I am the expert on this. I can bring them around, pull their strings.”

“Perhaps they are really pulling your strings, as you put it?”

“You keep implying that. Why do you think I am so inept?”

“Because you are a yea sayer, because you seek approval.”

“No, give me some credit. I think that I have been getting what I want out of this, and I’ve done quite well so far.”

“Or they make you think so.”

He sighs, beyond anger now. “You don’t have a very high opinion of me.”

“Perhaps you have too high an opinion of yourself?”

Here we go again, he thinks.

Is she right? Will he join her cause, not because he believe that her cause is righteous, but because he still needs her approval as a woman. She has starved him of his masculinity, and he wants it back. Is that why he will do her bidding? He shudders, realizing that he is not even sure.

They seem to be leaving. Cortina rises, taking some papers from the table. A pen flies out of her hands; she lunges after it, but it lands on the ground. Den bends down to pick it up and hands it to her and sees her smiling at him, cruelly.

“So you think you are pulling the strings?” She smiles: “Sweet Señor Morris, I do love it when a man goes on his knees before me.”

Den pushes open the door of his High Wycombe house and pries off his shoes. He goes to the kitchen to administer that universal English remedy for every malady from a slight chill to broken bone: the cup of tea. It is raining cats and dogs in the chalky green countryside and he feels damp and cold after his trip to San Sebastian.

His housekeeper has been here again, tidying up his things so that he cannot find them. How many times must he tell her to leave the goddamn things alone? He leaves her explicit instructions not to move his junk, and she defies his wishes, and puts things away where he cannot find them.

“Listen, Mr. Den,” she says, with her undefinable accent. “you cannot live like this. You are a respectable man.”

Telling him how to live in his own house. What is it her house now? He retaliates by leaving his things untidily strewn about. It is almost open warfare between them. He is paying her good money to come here, and she still has him frightened of doing something wrong in his own house.

There is a stack of good old-fashioned paper post on the kitchen table.

“You should pay your bills on time,” she tells him.

He always waits for the first reminder which invariably provokes moral outrage from her.

“That is not very decent, Mr. Morris.”

“Betty, don’t tell me how to run my affairs.”

“Suit yourself. Don’t blame me when they throw you in gaol or come and break yuh windows.”

He makes his tea and a couple of crackers of unpasturized Camembert with black pepper, and takes them into the living room, enjoying the sensation of a thick pile carpet under his feet. A little electric light makes the room a cozy haven from the great outdoors. Rain splatters from its grey home onto the fake latticed windows. He flicks on the gas fire and puts on some classical music.

It seems like a long time since he was here last. It soothes him to know that he has a place which is his own. The living room is nice, and the bedroom, but the rest of the house is a sterile showpiece. He rarely invites anyone here, unless it is for his pleasure.

The house seems too full of trophies, he thinks, for the first time he can recall. They seem to jump out at him now. He cannot recall their being so prominent before. Not the ostentatious sporting variety, with mirrored silver cups, but reminders of things that have meant something to him: framed academic accomplishments, prizes for their work over the last ten years, some souvenirs of the women he has known. He would keep pictures of them all if he could, to savour their beauty.

He looks through his post. There is a postcard here, a good old fashioned postcard from the Florida Keys. Celia Waites. There she is again, intruding into his thoughts. It is a comfortable feeling to think of her. And it is truly flattering that she thinks so much of him. How could that be?

Is he the one to save her, from boredom, from domineering abuse? Her husband is a philandering bully. She is his trophy, but he cares nothing for her. For years, she has been beaten physically and psychologically into submission, until finally she identifies that abuse with the strength that protects her.

The devil you know.

He is her dream of a better life.

Den is no angel when it comes to sticking to a single partner, but he has never bullied anyone, never been violent or made a promise that he broke. No one could seriously compare him to that man. He feels genuine compassion for her. She is entirely wasted on him.

Den closes his eyes, wearily. So, here he is in his Englishman’s castle, wondering about the course of the future. The voyage started bravely enough, with support of crew and company, but the sirens of the sea are calling to him to change course. They have finally unnerved him. How does one navigate blindly in such treacherous waters?

He needs to sit and ponder these issues carefully. Isn’t that the only way to plan his next move? Den has never considered himself to be an overtly thoughtful or deeply introverted man, but sometimes such work goes with the job. You just have to knuckle down.

He reclines for a while in the sensation of home. The feeling will last a few minutes, then he will go and check in with his sister, as duty demands. When did the trappings of responsibility attach themselves so insistently to him?

Maybe Cortina is right. He is merely a yea sayer. “All right, gov. Right you are. Whatever you say.” How will that help him to resolve this paradox?

Surely there is no logical resolution to the conundrum; there is no calculus of truth, which correctly identifies the profitable path through the rocks. And profit by whose accounting scheme? Is he headed for moral or financial bankruptcy?

However he cuts it, he cannot see any natural way of reconciling the antipodes: faith and blind authority versus conflict and scientific curiosity. They are oil and water. They simply do not mix. Trying to conceal a message of learning in a message about faith would be like having a snake claim that it hasn’t eaten a rabbit.

He mulls and wallows, exhausted from his travel, but too agitated to fall asleep. He should not come here to think my himself. That was probably a mistake. Being alone merely ferments indecision and insecurity. He relies the assurance of others around him to support or revoke him. Cortina is right. He does not have the self-assurance to make the big decisions. Like the very people he wants to appeal to, he needs the approval of a higher authority: perhaps not a god or a boss, but someone, just someone to lean on.

We don’t do that anymore. It’s old fashioned to need someone.

He has his mobile. He can always call someone. But what does that really say about him? Real explorers, the real movers and shakers do not need such crutches. They accept the responsibility of their own decisions and choices. Cortina is right. He lets people push him around, all the time convincing himself that it is he who holds the reins.

He recalls the battery-hen, stupified faces on the flight home from America. There is no doubt that people accept what they are given.

We have become zoo animals, incapable of living in the real jungle.

She is right, of course. There seems little doubt about that. But what can he possibly do about it? Can he afford to let the Christians have their vote? Their right to exercise opinion is not so bad, but what if they get their way in the long run? Would it plunge the West back into a dark age of ignorance and subservience? A few years ago, the idea would have seemed absurd, but that was before mobile communications tore at the fabrics of civil society.

For America, society is already more authoritarian, but it floats on a sea of chatter that binds people more strongly than here. Europeans think that society means a welfare check and a strong dose of bureaucracy.

Is it even up to him to make the decision? After all, suppose he does their bidding–succeeds in a campaign to get them their vote of power, it needn’t interfere with other responsibilities of his job or his company. He could satisfy Cortina in part, through some of the messages he has promised to market. There is authority and pride in learning, but there is nothing much to learn from authority.

But there is the paradox of her ideology. Authority is about decree, proclamation, edict. So doesn’t that mean that, if you are against blind faith, it ought to be up to everyone to decide for themselves what they want? Isn’t the idea of making up peoples’ minds for them then hypocritical?

There is no guarantee to be able resolve this conundrum. And if he can’t do it, then he can’t do it. At least he has tried. But who does he let down? How does one minimize the loss of face?

Sometimes, if you leave things alone, they will somehow work out right by themselves. He doesn’t have a better idea right now. It’s just that, above all, he hates leaving things to chance.

It’s a whitewash. But they have had an idea. It came from playing the game itself. So far, they have been trying to force feed ideas, but this is just provoking game players to rebel. It is too authoritarian. Too obviously manipulative. It is like listening to your parents tell you what to do. But suppose you could make education seem subversive to the establishment, then teenagers would go for it, as well as more radical adults. The hip-hop gangs would rebel against this straight away, although they usually respond only to instructions that come by rap.

Den realizes that he is just doing exactly what the U.S. government groups want. This whole adventure seemed like the best way to wheedle his way into the driving seat, but somehow he has realized that everyone is really making him jump through hoops. At least it should be moving him up the ladder where he will be in a position to do the same to others later. Right now it is Cortina who worries him the most.

What we need is some radical opposition. A punk movement, or something harmless but attractive? Of course that might be dangerous. If we encourage them to learn independently, then there is a greater chance that they will fall outside the game parameters, out of their control. It is a potentially self-destructive strategy that Cortina is suggesting.

His head is going around in circles.

Mary will sort this out for him. He needs Mary.

Den pulls himself out of his chair and goes into the room where he keeps his combo. He dons glasses and gloves and drops himself into the VR.

He finds Mary on a park bench, outside the Savoy, in central VLondon. She is reading a newspaper whose surfaces shimmer and change with colourful advertising. It is a sunny day and the place is visually quiet, but for the paper. A few angels are flapping around with their banners. The Muslims lose out in this competition, he thinks, not being allowed to make images of their faith.

Den checks over his programme list from their last meeting. He gave her several priorities, including the latest leads from San Sebastian.

He admires Mary’s slick graphical appearance. She is a work of art, there is no doubt about that, yet somehow he does not feel the same thrill at meeting her that he has done in the past. His emotional centres are already taxed to saturation just coping with the present crisis.

“Hey, sweetheart,” he says, trying to feign a convincing enthusiasm. For the first time, this little game seems like an empty exercise.

“Hi, Denny. Howz things?”

“Fine,” he lies, not altogether convincingly.

“That doesn’t sound like my big brother. Low spirits?”

“I’m okay. Tell me what you’ve got.” That’s right: down to business, don’t spend time talking to the simulation. Just get the information and be done with.

“Nice day,” she remarks, looking around. It’s all part of the illusion. “I’ve been interacting with some other agents this week.”

“Not players?”

“No. Specialists. They are putting together a project that matches most of the search parameters in your list.”

“Most? Specify.”

“Scores are minus sixty four percent Christian index, plus thirty five percent authority index, fourteen percent... ”

“Government?”

She shrugs. “I don’t know. It is possible.”

A competitor? Or a kindred spirit?

“That’s interesting,” he mumbles. “Can you calculate projection rating for possible collaboration, with standard copyright loss deductions?”

“It will take a few minutes.”

So I have company. Will like poles attract or repel? he wonders. Should we make contact or release countermeasures?

She adds: “The agents are not working with any copyright restrictions. No licensing protocol as far as I can tell.”

Den raises an eyebrow under his VR glasses. “The plot thickens. Have they made any offers to collaboration?”

“Not yet.”

“Any common function points?”

“There is a low probability link with one of the names you added to the list recently: Vascon.”

“Son of a bitch.”

She knows not to respond to this outburst, but her eyes follow his, as her programming dictates.

“Country of origin?”

“Probably Norway or Sweden.”

He observes the scenery as his mind turns over.

“Mary, I want you to create two more agents and let them interact with the group. Remove access barriers from one of the them, and see how it gets infected.”

“Rodger dodger.”

He drops out of the VR and calls Kylie.

Apparently he wakes her from an early night. Her broad Scottish sarcasm seems to sound louder than usual.

“It seems as though someone else is researching this. We might have a competitor.”

“Why wouldn’t we? These are ideologies, not just ad campaigns.”

“You’re right,” he agrees.

“It is the duty of thinkers to sell their ideas to the common man. An idea worth having is worth prosecuting in full view of its critics.”

“And we need to build on that. Perhaps we could get some celebrities with out opinions to stand forward make guest appearances within the game, to target individuals.”

“It’s all about fostering the right prejudices.”

“Appealing to peoples’ prejudices. Yes, it’s a powerful springboard.”

She gives up being abrasive and even sounds sympathetic to his concern. Perhaps his male charms have not worn off entirely.

“You know, when I was young my father told me not to blow my nose on toilet paper, because toilet paper was ‘dirty’. A simple association of ideas, transferring what you do with a toilet into something that you use in the process.”

“That’s nice.”

“But true. On another occasion he changed his mind and said toilet paper is actually sterilized. This was a reaction to his fear of germs, but it altered his behaviour completely. Two different perceptions from the same facts.”

“Cortina wants to eliminate these prejudices, by educating people, and have everyone just thinking for themselves, but that is missing the point isn’t it?”

“People like simplifications. It saves them from having to think every single time they do something.” She taps her temple. “Here we are, equipped with the most powerful processing device in the known universe and all most folks want to do is switch it off.”

“That’s what our business is trying to do.”

“Dennis Morris, think what are you saying. We need to see thinking as a partner of ideology, not as its enemy. Here’s another example for you. Homosexuality. People started out believing that homosexuality was wrong because it goes against God. Attitudes change and people figure out that science is the dominant authority, so then suddenly it’s against nature, i.e. science.
