Lying this close to her, she looks so calm so beautiful. No muscle tone in her soft face. He wants so badly to reach out and take advantage of the situation, while she is helpless, but then he would be everything he despises in others. And he knows that the only reason he is here at all is that she knows he won’t.

“Wait a minute,” he says. “Why are we so stupid?”

“What?”

“Don’t you see? Christmas is something that still pushes people’s buttons. It sends them running back to their families to dance around stupid trees and shit. Maybe that is what we can use to recrystallize the larger groups.”

“You mean the traditional message of Christmas cheer, lots of love Santa Claus.”

“Like Scrooge,” he thinks aloud and laughs.

Sometimes it’s just staring you in the face.

“All right. So what is the best thing about Christmas,” she asks him.

Dermot has to think hard. “Mince pies,” he says and adds: “Have you ever been to England?”

“You mean steak and kidney pies?”

“No. Mince pies, but not meat. I mean it’s a fruit mixture called mincemeat. I don’t know why really. It’s all kinds of leftovers of fruit mixed up and left to ferment. The result is amazing. Mince pies.”

“All right, so how do we send the message of Christmas into the game?”

He grins happily. “We make it snow.”

RENT YOUR OWN PRIVATE VILLA IN SPAIN!

SPACIOUS, MODERN VILLA WITH MODERN FITTINGS, PRIVATE SWIMMING POOL AND FENCED GARDEN. GROCERIES DELIVERED TO THE DOOR, NO NEED TO LEAVE THE GROUNDS. PEACE AND SECURITY FOR YOU AND YOUR FAMILY.

SUNSHINE-ADVENTURES.COM

BOOK NOW AND WIN A FREE CABLE SUBSCRIPTION!

The bar is more or less empty, and Joe has forsaken his new jeans for a pair of beige slacks and a brown shirt, under his anorak. Back to old habits. Chocolate colours and clichéd styles. Today, Joe looks like a Christian missionary. What happened to Africa’s burgeoning fashion industry?

“You know the latest? The American group has bought our youth organization. It’s going to be taken over by the Methodist church of Atlanta.”

“Nice.”

”I have to go and meet them.”

“That’s why you’re looking so stylish today.”

Joe grunts as he sips at his beer. “And something else.”

Jonas raises an eyebrow.

“We were raided by police yesterday.””

“Really? What happened?”

“Terror alert.”

“Terror alert? Muslims?”

He shakes his head. “Christians. They’ve been buying just about everything that plugs straight into the psyche. Then they can stick their corporate logo onto it and claim the authority of Jesus Christ.”

“Jesus Christ,” Jonas agrees and gulps his beer.

It feels good to be hiding out with Joe in this bar. The past couple of weeks has been intense to the point of exhaustion. Jonas’ lack of self-control has made the issue of the diversion of research funds into a national news item. Some even think that international news agencies have taken an interest in the story. The furore has been building and he is becoming inundated with requests for interviews and comments. Perhaps this was not strictly what he intended, but it bears a certain moral justice.

“You know, it got me thinking. The policeman who coordinated the arrest when you were being followed. He said something about these vigilante groups originating in youth groups and centres. Kids of around eighteen who are looking for their purpose in the world. I started asking questions around some of the kids who spend a lot of time on the net.”

“And?”

“I don’t know. Some of them might even come from our group.”

“Don’t you wish you had that research money now?”

Jonas drinks a slug of beer and looks around the bar. He likes to see the art and the rows of bottles on the shelves, even if he never tastes any of it. Old beery habits die hard. A few more people in the bar wouldn’t hurt, as long as they were there to shield them from attention rather than to demand their piece. None of the regular fixtures are here.

“Radical Islam or Christianity. The return to tribalism,” he philosophizes. “Kids who are eighteen or nineteen, trying to understand the world. Angry and disowned. Whether they come from the foothills of Kashmir or Setesdal, they are all ruled with an iron fist by elders who maintain the tribal traditions.”

“There are people out there just waiting to prey on kids of that age. You find people spreading out leaflets at Mosques and churches. Even at our group. I haven’t noticed it much fortunately, but I’m sure it goes on. They are careful that their spreading programs don’t target people like me who could put a stop to it.”

“These are dangerous times.” There is a certain exhaustion in his voice.

Joe continues. “The Evangelical Christians are tribalizing the south of the U.S. like an industry now, and even here in parts of Scandinavia. They are isolating themselves from the wider law, dealing with problems internally and ignoring the criminals within their midst. People are in denial. Europe is becoming Africa, as Africa tries to become Europe.”

Jonas laughs. “Africa? I never thought of it that way.”

Joe shrugs. “Sure, why not. The problem in Africa has always been that people will not rise to the challenge of helping each other out of poverty. They think small. They don’t trust government. Government has been the enemy for so long, so tribalism persists. If you don’t have a sense of wider civic duty, how can you create a civil society? Basic services, impartial administration... ”

Good to see Joe has not forgotten his intellectual heritage in working with these kids, Jonas thinks. Youth centres need people like him with a smarter version of reality than they normally offer. If people can just get past figuring out which gang to belong to, it might be possible to save society from the breakup it is experiencing.

“Are you going to stay on at the youth centre?”

“Not sure I can.”

“They want to get rid of you?”

“No. They want me to stay, but I can’t swallow this new style of leadership. At the same time, I don’t want to abandon the kids.”

“What do they have in mind for it?”

“More like a church community with prayer meetings and preaching.”

“I suppose that’s what they do.”

“Missionaries do not have to spread their doctrine as part of their work. We have always tried to keep that part of the church out of the centres. We want people to think for themselves. Most of them are there precisely because others have been doing their thinking for them, in the first place.”

“It’s your French education showing through.”

“Liberté, egalité, fraternité? It’s not politics either.”

“You know what they say. Religious leaders, are just politicians in dresses.”

“They say that?”

“Apparently.”

“It doesn’t have much to do with the spirit anymore. People don’t think that God is listening, maybe.”

“Cause God never got himself a mobile... ”

“Don’t laugh, Jonas.”

“I’m not laughing. I am saying it is what you can expect if you place all your hope in someone else. People have to take responsibility for themselves. It’s just no good to palm off the responsibility on someone else or something else.”

“That’s why we’re here, getting drunk?”

“That’s why we’re here, getting drunk.”

“Too many people, just falling apart. You can see them one moment working well in some niche of society, getting along, playing their role. Then something changes and they cannot adapt.”

We don’t make kids that can adapt any more. They are too protected, too factory moulded. They learn one thing – just one thing and when they are no longer needed, they get thrown on the garbage pile. A pile of wasted humanity, sustained with pain and reality killers.

Jonas drinks from his own glass.

“You know, I’ve seen kids age from twenty-seven to forty-something in just a year. Youth vanishes in an instant. I’ve seen it many times. The girls get thin and starve, then they get help and they get fat and red, with high blood pressure. Skin creases and bulges. They end up at the centres. Lost, helpless. We try to remind them about how to live in a society, except it’s not a society this thing you have here. It’s a machine now. And if you don’t fit in, you are just replaced by a new part, not repaired. People are just components to be replaced here.”

Good intentions fraught ...

Joe studies his distant expression. “Do you think I am too weak? Do you think that I should just pick up and move on – go somewhere else and start again? Or should I stay and fight, like you?” He points to a newspaper. “They are advertising that now. Kids call it rebooting. You do a reset on your life. Move somewhere, start again.”

“Why run away?”

“Is it running away? Or is it seeking adventure?”

“If you need to ask I think you know the answer.”

Joseph regards him with his powerful black features and penetrating eyes. “Jonas, look at all you have done. You have achieved far more than I ever have. Every time I look at you, something has changed. You have achieved something and that is good.”

Jonas laughs. “What have I done?”

“Your research. Knowledge, learning.”

“No... I think that’s has all collapsed.”

“You have something to show for your work. A legacy.”

“What use is it now? The politics of the day are saying that knowledge and research are pointless.”

“People always try to take advantage and knock you down.”

“This is the story of the Tower of Bullshit? And all the men did perish? No, I am not trying to build anything. I am a plumber, Joe. I spend most of my time fixing things. But I would love to build something again.”

“So would I.” Joseph reaches into his back pocket and pulls out a chain. Hanging on the chain is a small figure made of wood. “Look. I wanted to give you something.”

“Give me something?”

“I got this when I was a child. I kept it because I thought it was a powerful image.” he says. “Now I would like you to have it.”

“Me? But why? Don’t you want to keep it?”

“For a heathen, you are one of the most spiritual people I know, Jonas. I would like you to have it.” He dismisses Jonas’ sceptical expression. “Don’t worry, it is not a Christian thing. It’s from the old religions of the west of Africa. Did you know that the banks of the Niger were one of the few civilizations of the world that were not hierarchically organized? No pyramid of power. Just distributed cooperation of small groups.”

“I... eh... did know, yes. That’s very kind of you ... but what have I done to deserve a gift? And such a precious one?”

“Just a little ju-ju between friends.”

He smiles and stares at the piece to conceal his embarrassment. How does one receive such a gift?

Graciously, of course.

He shakes Joe’s hand and thanks him again, certain that he does not deserve any such gift. As an academic he has been persuaded to abandon the pursuit of knowledge to decide on funding policy. He has betrayed his roots. Even as a human being, he is far from angelic in his attitudes or accomplishments. Kaja would laugh at him know if she knew of this exchange. If he is so great, what is he doing hiding out here in a brown bar in the middle of the city, looking for cardiovascular relief in a glass of beer, instead of standing up to the hawks of government?

Jonas looks down the long bar to where the old drunk usually hangs onto the woodwork, not talking to anyone, just downing his beer. He is not there today, not yet. Then a thought strikes him.

Has Joe lost his faith?

Jonas’ eyes looks deeply into his dark friend’s face, as if searching for the meaning of this development. Joe seems to be happy staring into his beer for a moment, and Jonas feels suddenly tired and worn.

It reminds him of something. His life seems to roll past him, as if on film and he sees something that he should have seen a long time ago. He stares back at the space on the end of the bar, where the old drunk usually hangs out. Where is that loser? Where is that sad old fuck who comes here to avoid company and drown his sorrows?

It’s me, he thinks. I am that sad old fuck.

Just give me a beer and let me stagger home alone.

Where did it go wrong?

It is possible to do everything right and still fail?

It’s you, idiot.

He sees himself staring back from the mirror.

Kaja’s mother calls and asks him to be more helpful. His son needs him. What do these people want from him? They profess to care but all they do is demand his attention. They give him nothing in return, not even understanding. So why do they hold on to him? Why won’t they simply let him go?

Punishment at the hands of our loved ones, Jonas thinks.

We are their chance to let down their barriers and let the flood gates roar. An understanding ear becomes a garbage chute for relief. No doubt he is partially to blame, but what is it that makes them perceive each issue as a conflict, with points to be won?

He can hear her voice even now. “You’re so goddamn selfish, Jonas. You buy me a gift, but you don’t get me anything I want. You buy something that you think I should have. Have you never thought if my feelings? All you can see is your own precious life.”

“And you see more?”

“Oh, so now it’s my fault? That’s typical!”

She will spend half the day just stewing in hormones, not getting anywhere, just feeling confused and lost. There’s not a chance of rational thought.

“Evenly happy for the rest of your life? How is that possible?”

“Do we really need these extremes?”

Then his secretary calls. “It’s the girl I mentioned. She is still trying to get to you. You should really take one of her calls, just to give her some satisfaction.”

“I know. I should.”

Sara is not to blame for this mess; she is still trying to reconcile the changes that have taken place in such a short space of time with what she thought was the plan for her future. Suddenly one finds oneself on a completely different road, headed for the unknown. He knows all about that.

I ought to call Sara, he thinks. I ought to call Kaja,

He has been disinclined to call and discover who she is seeing at this moment in time. That and all of the chaos of the past weeks seems to have disabled his sense of responsibility towards his patchy family.

We hurt the people we love. Why can’t we just resist the temptation to strike out?

Obviously because there are no barriers. The threshold for venting senseless frustrations is too low. Everyone needs a valve, but that is no excuse for blasting our nearest and dearest with bad-tempered steam.

Marriage was a release from all that, of course. It transformed the hard creativity of romancing into a simple contract of obligations. Like the law itself: just an excuse to stop thinking about how to behave well. Just follow the contract and you will be a good person. But it didn’t last either.

Well, he is not convinced. You cannot buy your future in a box, with a money back guarantee. When you put a dog on a leash it is not generally for its own good.

Joe has lost his faith.

The revelation is like a lightening bolt from the Lord himself. Is the whole world falling apart? Joe seems to be clinging on to the idea of it, but he has already lost the battle? And the clothes–is that where the jeans come from? Perhaps he cannot wear the fake garb of a would-be priest any more. He will not say it, and Jonas can not ask him, but somehow they both understand it.

Yes that’s it.

Jonas can see it. Joseph is too smart, too rational to be a religious man. His faith has been shaken. He has asked the forbidden questions. But, for now, he is trying to continue with his duties.

You can always live a lie, for the sake of appearances, he thinks.

Maybe that is actually his easiest path through life?

Kaja calls and asks for a truce. They have not spoken for some days. He leaves a message.

The man, the bureaucrat, has arrived. He swaggers around his department like the town bully. The ministry has sent him to make sure that their plan is enforced.

His mandate is like my croissant, Jonas thinks Layer upon layer of paper thin deception, rolled up and blown up on an empty core of hot air.

If only there were some administrative coffee one could use to wash it all down.

There is no point in my even being here? It is a farce.

Presumably they gave him this job to emasculate him. Vociferous researcher: too smart for his own good, rein him in, neutralize by promotion within the ranks? Control and regulate. The more they steam towards nominal de-regulation, the more rules they implement to ‘guide’ its progress.

What remains of his scientific mind knows that it is useless of them to try, and useless of himself to protest. You can’t cage something that wild and still expect it to live. It’s like putting a rare animal in a zoo, or plucking and pressing a beautiful flower to have it. Life withers and dies in captivity. The more you try to control it, the less of it is real. At the same time, you cannot argue with denial.

Now, they are ready just to punish someone who has disobeyed government policy for the good of the people. So, does all this protestation make him a terrorist? A revolutionary? Robin Hood?

Jonas is right about his decision to oppose them: of that he is certain, but they have puppies and kittens on their side. How can you argue against a humanitarian cause and still use words like ‘ethics’? Every conscientious person, with respect for themselves, knows that you are supposed to preserve life in desperate circumstances. How could one not spend money on the African famine? How could selfish and elitist research be of any use to mankind when there are people suffering?

Apparently, preservation does not extend to investing in the survival of our whole way of life: our future.

We have become fire-fighters, and charity is a bucket of cold water in a growing conflagration of politics.

The sanguine bully that the ministry has sent to coerce him is regrettably pleasant in his administration of their medicine, sporting joviality and an array of blunt administrative instruments in his cause. Jonas does not want to force a dislike of everything he represents onto its animated cadaver, but he finds himself projecting more animosity than restraint. The man pretends to be their friend, but the charade wears pretty thin.

“It is such a pleasure to finally meet you.”

I am about to hurt you.

“As you know, some new rules have come into force.”

I just cut off your head.

Jonas has the sick feeling of being railroaded by a cattle herder with no ethical or moral manifesto. His interest is purely in moving up the food chain, by shifting the economic game pieces around the board so that government ministries can feel good about their half-assed pledges to the media.

“We all need a little breathing room from this reallocation. A little slack in the rope, so it doesn’t strangle us,” Jonas tells him, as nicely as he can. “It is wrong of the ministry to make this decision that will kill off Norwegian research.”

“It’s a shame,” he agrees. “But it is what has been decided.”

It’s a sham, you mean.

He is just following orders.

Soldier, ask not.

Jonas recalls Ed Bishop’s comment about democracy: people have to go along with the decisions once they have been made. Does that mean he being undemocratic in this behaviour? Let’s face it, no one was asked to vote on this decision. It was a unilateral action. The government is betraying its people with its indolent and supine acceptance of commands that don’t even come from an agent of any country or people. This is direct pressure from American, Christian lobbies. They represent neither U.S. nor Norwegian policy. We ought to be viewing this travesty as an infiltration of national security, not as a directive to be accepted with nauseous servility.

Douse us in cheap guilt and change our whole economic strategy. Are we so push-over?

Jonas has still not come to terms with losing Sara. And losing her to the police of all things. Since when did the forces of creative anarchy transfer to become part of the sentinels of establishment? At least she has a home for the time being, and income. She is a smart kid, but he needs to feel that he has done more to protect her from what is going on.

All our futures lie in the hands of people like her.

So he returns to the business of making his conscience feel better. He fends interviews with journalists who have caught wind of the scandal he has leaked. Now his minder is there to keep him in check.

“Of course, we are deeply committed to solving this problem.”

After the day’s interviews, Jonas feels spent and hollow. Reiterating his own message so many times, he is not even sure that he believes it himself anymore. His scientific training makes him suspicious of any ‘truth’ that trips off the tongue. He pulls one of the journalists to one side.

“In reality, we are not free to make these decisions. The ministry has put both sides in shackles. I can try to resist those forces and they can try to push them, but there has to be a point of balance in the middle. Luckily, their own system is preventing such a rapid change from taking place. You cannot force the bureaucratic leviathan you have created to be flexible when it suits your needs.”

“Would you agree that corruption is so ingrained into the daily lives of government that they really cannot see anything wrong with what they are doing.”

“Only in an academic sense. Any hierarchy of command is, by definition, corrupt and self-serving, but let’s not exaggerate.”

Now he has received a number of calls and threats from officious persons at the ministry, suggesting that he could be arrested for treasonous behaviour if he continues. He wonders if they could they set the crime team onto him now, with his new friends at Interpol?

He finds himself becoming impatient with the process, approaching a point at which he must decide whether or not to allow himself to become angry, or whether to suppress the urge and maintain his equanimity.

He has disturbed a lot of people today, including himself.

When he returns the next day, there is a memo from the chief administrator. Mr. Lindgren, due to new construction renovation, we find that we are in need of your office to store the necessary building materials. We hope this does not inconvenience you significantly.

This is how they humiliate someone in government service.

Christmas is approaching, hark the herald angels advertise.

Jonas walks along Karl Johan, admiring the prosperity of the retailers and their wares. It is good to see the world working, the wheels of fortune grinding on their investments. It is good, even to see so many people out of their homes, simply walking around. The power of Christmas is still strong. Some things never die.

Designer drum beats pump out their own wares onto the shopping street, warming the twilight chill with musical toddy. The rhythms seep involuntarily into his psyche, defying his own reticence and teasing him to dance, as he has never actually been able to do in his entire life. The producers are good; they know their trade. But he wonders how much it costs kids to play it.

Oh come, all ye faithful, and subscribe to our streamed hypnosis. It’s not as expensive as you think. And the sacrament of copyright law will commit you to oblivious financial servitude for your incidental pleasure.

Just thirty years ago, it was possible to buy recorded music and be done with. Now everything is licensed by the hour.

A woman approaches who reminds him of Kaja, but knows immediately that it could not be her. This woman walks at a calculated pace, on designer shoes that cry out exhibitionism, prying distance between herself and the waves of pedestrians that shuffle about her. That is not Kaja. He has been trying to reach her for a whole day, but she has not been answering him. The tables have turned.

Jonas browses the shop windows, looking at the electrical goods for inspiration. They are all foreign, even now. If he were allowed to do his job, some of these could be Norwegian. If he could only convince government to reform their attitudes to risk and investment. If the country is to survive the next generation with declining oil revenues, it will have to innovate, not merely import, even if it means manufacturing. But the country is barely trained for it. Education is little more than attitude engineering and button pushing now. The house-of-cards economy is still buoyed by fossil fuels and fossilized ideas. Sooner rather than later that wealth must expire and be replaced by something more permanent. His job is about securing that permanency, if only they could see it.

A gang of teenage boys comes along the street, wearing red and silver tinsel like football scarves. Did they bother going to school today? A couple of police on horseback are clopping along behind them, at a discrete distance. The sight of uniforms take his mind back to Sara.

He has walked more or less all the way around the shops now, as the daylight has faded. With the long nights moving in, he feels tempted to simply go home and sleep, but it is only four o’clock. He should work some more. If he goes home, it would become a self-fulfilling prophesy.

Jonas backtracks and goes into a little shop to buy coffee. Simple pleasures are what carries you through the hard times. Besides, the shop is unusually quiet, which suits him perfectly.

He chooses the appropriate blend of beans and asks for them to be ground. The lighting inside the shop makes it look even darker outside now. The bluish hue of evening is descending rapidly. He gives his card to the young boy behind the counter and waits for him to deal with the transaction.

Then, through the window, even through the reflections, he sees her across the street. It is Kaja.

She emerges from a side alley between two shops, smiling and laughing. Behind her is a man he does not know. He head is thrown back joyfully. The man is some years older than she. Jonas is suddenly impatient to complete his purchase and see where she is going.

He feels a stab of something undefinable, something like betrayal but more violent. Is it jealously or anger? What does it matter? His every muscle pulls taut with a surging scream and he begins to shake with the adrenalin rush. Of course she would not answer him if she had spent the entire night and day with a new lover. How could he have been such a fool?

When he emerges clumsily from the shop, she is already far down the street. He begins to run after her, not wanting to be seen, but not wanting to lose sight of her either.

Are they lovers? They must be! He is not an attractive man, but then Jonas has never understood what turns women on. The thought of her in bed with him burns like an ice-water flooding into his lower body.

He follows them for some distance, back to her apartment feeling a mixture of guilt for his intrusive voyeurism and anger at her callous mind games.

She clasps the man as though they are about to part company. But then they pause. Some new possibility seems to have emerged between them. He follows her inside.

This is so like her, he thinks. And what a fool is he, who falls for her promises and assurances every time? He has been proven the fool time and time again. What possession drives him to prevaricate in ending this charade?

It could be true that people need change about every ten years. The timer starts ticking and we either we change or we enter into an emotional crisis. Those who marry at twenty learn it when they are thirty; those tho change jobs when they are thirty learn when they are forty... What hope is left except to accept stagnation? To make peace with endings?

Their end was like a fabled nightmare: telephone calls that she would ignore in his presence and then find an excuse to return later; visits from ‘old friends’ and ex-boyfriends; her increasing lack of interest in him. Finally the signs could not be ignored and his fears consumed him in a rain of presumed truths, like a stoning from the inquisition.

In the chill, it begins to snow.

Jonas crawls back to the offices the next day, still feeling like a wounded animal. He has not spoken to anyone. He escaped the evening by throwing off his shoes and settling down with a glass of fine Madeira and Honegger’s grave symphonic rumblings.

More snow is forecast today. That pleases him. Somehow, the snow seems to light up the city with optimism. There is still something in that peace and goodwill to all men nonsense, when it snows. Such a pity that it melts so quickly in the city.

He nears the site of the neighbouring demolition that has been taken over for parking spaces, and hears the protracted complaint of a motorist getting closer. The man is trying to enter the parking area, but the security guard is explaining some kind of problem.

“My parking space is taken.”

“Sorry sir, there is no reserved parking today.”

“But I work here. How am I, are we supposed to... ”

“Sorry, sir. You cannot park you car in its reserved spot today, we are expecting visitors from the ministry. They have reserved these spaces.”

“I wasn’t told.”

“You can park in the unmarked spaces over there.”

“But how are we going to find our vehicles again?”

“Just move along, sir. We don’t have time to discuss this now.”

So the ministry is screwing with everyone’s heads today. Somehow seeing someone else’s meaninglessly stunted predicament helps his own spirits. He refuses to believe that the point of authority is to reduce ordinary people to powerless ignomy, but sometimes it is a hard theory to refute.

Of course, when it snows later, you won’t be able to find the cars again, he thinks to the guard as he walks past him. The guard stares through him to make it clear that he is no one.

Jonas arrives at the research council offices and walks unwillingly down the corridor to the day’s ritual humiliations. He would rather transport himself away from here to help Sara, or finish his business with Kaja, but he wills himself forward with cheerless effort. He has no usable office to attend, but he can make use of the other facilities the building offers.

Things are moving in the research debate. Well, he wasn’t going to stand still and be steam-rollered by a minor minister, at least not without a fight. His new spiritual low incites him to make the matter international now. When one of the richest nations faults on its responsibilities to its poorer neighbours, the matter goes beyond local politics. Today, he feels like stabbing back.

Almost as soon as he has posted a commentary to a research magazine editorial, his combo signals an unusual call invitation. At about the same time, he receives a text from Joe, saying that he should expect a call.

He pushes aside some of the boxes from his desk, to make room to sit down. The call is from Spain. Spain? He rummages around for some glasses and accepts the invitation. He enters the virtual meeting room.

He finds himself on a balcony overlooking the sea. A slight sound of surf is audible. It feels a little uncomfortable, sitting like this in his office. He has never been a great fan of using glasses. The inconsistencies between vision, sound and touch make him a little nauseous.

A woman is standing beside him, looking out at the breaking waves. She is slim and attractive, with dark hair and a middle aged face, young and old at the same time.

“My name is Connie Cortina,” she says. “I am executive director of a company called Vascon.”

“Jonas Lindgren,” he reciprocates.

“It’s nice to meet you, Dr Lindgren. I’ve been following some of the debate, thanks to a friend of yours.”

“Who? Joe?”

“Joseph, Joe, yes.” She exudes an elegance that Jonas finds charming. “I hope you don’t mind my interruption. I have been reading about about your struggles for Norwegian research. I find them very interesting.”

“Thank you,” he says, uncertain of what else to say. “What can I do for you?”

“I wanted to lend you my support.”

“Your support?”

“Yes.”

Now he is perplexed. “What kind of support? How can you help me?” Then, he adds: “Forgive me, I don’t mean to be rude.”

She shakes her head, matter of factly. “Moral support to begin with. It is hard work to go against one’s own government. I wanted to talk to you about my own experiences and perhaps lend you some of my thoughts on this.”

“Are you for or against my writings?”

“I don’t think of it really in terms of sides. There is only one alternative for any country–to survive.”

“What do you do?”

She considers her answer for a split second. “My company is a large concern. It sponsors good-work projects in research and education. It is rather complicated to explain why and how. Let’s just say that I am always looking for allies around the world. Those of us who believe in such things are few and far between.”

Jonas laughs without humour. “That’s interesting,” he says, unsure of how to respond. “What kind of allies are you looking for?”

“People who can stand up to the storm and face the future, as you have done.” She wants be his friend.

“Well, I am open to all kinds of input,” Jonas says. “But I’m a little taken aback.”

Cortina smiles at him and swishes her hair. “My company has many specialities, but information is our business. I have a group that works with the police forces of many countries to trace threads of crime and corruption. We have work related to the global VR games. But, whenever I can I return to the issue of education.”

“I don’t follow you.”

“An incident that you reported recently, related to a threatening phone call was correlated by people working with our company, with data from international police forces and our models put together a scenario that was very interesting.”

He starts. “Me? How did you know? I’m not sure I understand. I thought you were talking about the research articles... ”

“This is very complicated, señor Lindgren, but your police report formed a missing link that allowed us to see connections in the patterns of behaviour across Europe. My company specializes in this kind of analysis, and we work with Interpol to weed out organized crime.”

“Mafia?”

“Not just the mafias. There are many players in the game. The report was useful because it placed activities in this area close to others that were close to others... and so on. We have expert modellers who put together hypotheses about organized criminality.”

“This is all a bit confusing for me. I am new to this. I am not used to being so ... involved.”

“In this instance, we were able to use it to shut down the group who contacted you.”

“You... ? But I heard that ... Can I ask who it was?”

“Just amateurs, associated with a Christian religious group from Eastern Europe. They were not very smart, and that helped us to pin-point their identities. I doubt that you will hear from them again.”

“That’s amazing. I’m a bit flabbergasted.”

“Take a moment.”

“How can you know about this police business. Are you with the Interpol group here?”

“I know of them.”

“But you’re not working with them?”

“No, but our company is very powerful. We develop the systems used by the police forces and we donate some funds to them whenever we can.”

“And this gives you access to their data?”

“Exactly.”

“So, if I am hearing you correctly, then from this, you became interested in me, here in backwater Norway?”

“Not really. At least not directly. It is just that the power of analysis, sometimes brings you to places you do not expect, Mr Lindgren. That is why we do research, no?”

“Yes. I’m trying to remember that.”

“And so we come to the other matter.”

“Of course.”

“I started to look into your work, wondering if there were any deeper reason why you were approached.”

“Was there?”

“Possibly. I don’t think so. I’m not sure. But I learned something of the dilemma you are facing.”

“Any in particular?”

“You see I have several projects that I have made my work, and one of them is fighting ignorance.”

Jonas does not know how to respond. Conversations in the VR are hard to interpret. The body language is primitive.

“Ignorance is not bliss,” he jokes.

“Not unless you are a radical Christian activist,” she parries.

Jonas’ radar flicks on. “Christian radicals. They seem to be cropping up everywhere these days.”

“Yes they do, don’t they?”

“But Joe... ”

“You have a number of good projects in your research council proposals and they are about to be turned over by a directive that comes from one of the most powerful of these groups.”

He nods inside his glasses.

“I want to ask you not to allow these important projects to be displaced by a cheap political gambit that your government is being coerced into.”

“It seems that I no longer have the power to make that decision.”

“Hold off as long as you can. This is a matter of importance.”

“What makes you say that?”

“This pressure to divert your funds is not based on a sound judgement. It could still blow over. There are groups working against these organizations in several countries, and on several fronts.”

He thinks of Sara, and Edward Bishop. “Yes,” he says. “Yes, I know.”

“The team you would send to the famine area will achieve nothing. That is not their purpose. The aim is simply to delay progress in more important works. I know this to be true.”

“But how?”

“Because I attended the meeting at which the decision was made.”

Jonas looks shocked. She cannot see his expression in the VR, but she can probably guess from his silence.

“You were at the meeting?”

“Yes,” she says quietly. “It was a meeting of the game consortium in fact, but the originators of the game are people with powerful friends and strong motivations. Some of them are good and some of them are not so good.”

“Who?”

“Oh, the rich and the bad and the ugly. You know. People who still have power, but are seeing it crumble in this new age of street gangs and mob wars. The famine aid is just a cover. Money means nothing in this situation. What matters to them is that they can exert control over society’s thinkers.”

“It has always struck me as odd that, when one can simply eliminate billions of dollars of debt, or that countries can continue to go on with budget deficits the size the U.S. has, that one would need famine relief from a source like research money.”

“Yes, money doesn’t exist. If you wipe out money, we still have everything except for the financial acrobatics that the banks perform. And when you realize that our world is ruled by an enormous Virtual Reality game called the global economy, it makes perfect sense. It is pure pinball based on a fictitious scoring system. Anyone can say: I don’t care what my score is, at any time. The only real consequence is that they piss off all the other players. But it doesn’t change anything real.”

“So when a government from one of the richest countries in the world comes and tells you that you have to divert funds from research to famine relief, you know that they are covering up something.”

“Exactly.”

Jonas feels a little stunned, numb in his seat. His hand knocks into one of the sheets of plasterboard that they have filled his office with and it jars him back to disoriented concentration.

“All right,” he says, taking some breaths. “All right.”

Ms Cortina gives him some time to think. Then she says: “But, of course, you are asking yourself why.”

He nods.

Damn right.

“Yes, tell me.”

“Well,” she treads carefully. “I wish I could tell you exactly why. I am not sure I understand it myself.”

“But you have an idea? A theory?”

“Yes I do.”

“So?”

“The church leaders who are sponsoring this activity have seen a trend. They see that people are getting dumber.”

Jonas laughs despite himself. “Getting dumber?”

“Yes. Society has been dumbing down for decades. They see this as an opportunity to get back what they have lost to science over the years.”

“You are serious, aren’t you?”

She nods. “Knowledge is religion’s greatest enemy.”

“Because knowledge is subversive?”

“It is counter to the authority of the church.”

“Yes... ”

“They locked up Galileo, had a go at Darwin... ”

Cortina’s figure comes closer to his, filling his vision.

“And you think society is getting dumber.” He nods. “Well, I can’t disagree with that.”

“It is an inevitable process. Perhaps it is even a phase that every civilization has to go through.”

“Yes,” he thinks, not really agreeing with her, but the wheels and cogs of his mind race with thoughts that he has had a thousand times, yet never quite assimilated into a coherent jigsaw puzzle.

“When society learns, it begins with real hard-earned knowledge. It takes a long time and a lot of sweat to acquire. Sometimes we have worked for years to achieve it.”

She is talking about herself, Jonas thinks. This is a smart lady, however eccentric she might be.

“Gradually,” she continues, “Knowledge becomes assimilated into our consciousness at a deeper level. We begin to speak of it without the need to explain or elaborate. We begin to take it for granted and see it as a part of who we are.”

Jonas pulls himself back from his own thinking to follow her. “You mean society takes it for granted.”

“Yes. Finally, that hard earned knowledge gets passed on to those who have not toiled and struggled for it, to those who have not tasted the sweat on their brows or the thrill of understanding; that is when we begin to disrespect it. The knowledge becomes like a war veteran, something laughably caught up in a past struggle. We reduce it to simplifications, to slogans and jargon, perhaps even to Three Letter Abbreviations, whose stories and details we have now forgotten. At that point, damage has occurred. Society has lost the value of the knowledge. And a whole new generation must relearn it all over again.”

She makes a eureka noise and freezes amoment. The background imagery in the VR changes. She projects them into an image of the Los Angeles traffic machine.

“Here,” she says. “Look at this traffic chaos. It speaks of miracles, Jonas.” She calls him Jonas. “That so many careless, half-competent idiots can get behind the wheel of such dangerous equipment, and not simply end up in a pile of torn metal, seems astonishing, don’t you think?. There is surely a lesson to be learned from it.”

“What lesson?”

“That trained monkeys can do this task,” she says. “We are so proud of ourselves for mastering this simple task, and yet it means nothing. It requires little skill that is not merely the domain of our primitive brains.”

“It is mainly motor skill, yes,” he agrees, acknowledging the pun.

“The same is true for most things. Once the hard part of thinking up the inventions is done, once the technology is in place, you don’t need to be a great expert. You don’t need great precision or fine control to make the world work. It is robust. There are basic protective instincts built into humans that allow them to escape the most bizarre of catastrophic ends. We don’t need to be utter control freaks – things will sort themselves out. We just need a little faith. That, of course, is what the church relies on. What is truly surprising is that we advance – and that requires conviction and concentrated effort.” Her hands gesticulate with a passion. “For all our reputed intelligence, we get by on nothing more than primitive instinct for most of the time. And yet we have surpassed that reflex in our creativity, in science and in art.” She shakes her head and continues more quietly. “Now that we have created our lap of luxury, we must not fall asleep in it, like Rumpelstiltskin.”

Jonas looks at her with admiration. He wishes he could see what she really looks like. “You don’t think you might be overstating things just a little bit?” Even as he says it, he knows that she is right.

“No, Mr. Lindgren, I am not. I wish I were. But already the forces of trivial economics and faith are dominating the behaviour of society.”

He cannot disagree with that. It’s the paradox of the century.

We’re consumed by trivia so there’s no room in our heads for expertise. At the same time, we’re so singular in our privacy that we cannot even mix the ingredients of a half-baked society.

“Society truly is becoming the proverbial ‘bewildered herd’.”

“This dumbing down of society is not just about entertainment. It concerns our most important institutions, our education, our subservience.” Jonas wonders how her passion would sound if she were speaking in Spanish. “I am here partly because your friend, Joe, is part of a group working against the kind of ignorance that some would have us perpetuate.”

“The Get Smart programme. Yes. What ignorance, in particular, are you speaking of?”

“Today it is the leaders.”

Jonas laughs now with genuine amusement.

Cortina laughs too. “Perhaps I am talking too much? It is a habit of mine.”

“Please continue. Our leaders... ”

“Our leaders, yes. Well, you know, in our information society, it is not the leaders who are the card holders anymore. In ancient times, in the days when Europe was a melange of warring houses, it was a hierarchical society. The leaders and their aids were the most educated persons and all they needed was obedience to carry out their commands. They had their Machiavellis and others to advise them, but basically the expertise was at the top.”

“But today the expertise is at the opposite ends of the tree.”

“Exactly. The roots are dying and the leaves prosper but for the fact that they are shackled to their roots and their aids, the inflexible branches. Now they want to stop that from changing, by stunting the leaves, by taking away from people the basic right to be good at something, to succeed. The right for one person to be better than someone else.”

“Hmm.” Jonas nods. “Everyone is equal until proven guilty.” He nods. “I know this tendency. It has been around since the seventies here. It almost ruined our maths education.”

“Before it was only the poor who had the luxury of ignorance. Now it is the opposite. The rich and powerful–who can lead because they are already ahead in the Western view of economics–are increasingly falling behind the curve required to understand the world. This is dumbing down. Yet they retain the power to bludgeon us with instruments beyond their understanding, simply because we all play the game of money.”

“Welcome to my world.”

“It affects everyone. We are simply closer to it.”

“So how do we change it?”

“I am asking you to take a stand. Norway has a history of standing up for moral principles. I am asking you to do this now.”

“But you realize that I, too, am just a puppet of the government if they want me to be?”

“Don’t believe it,” she says, shaking her head and piercing him with the shrewdness of her gaze. “Whenever They make laws, they set traps for themselves. Use your imagination.” She smiles. “You must think me slightly mad to come to you and say such a thing; but, you must understand the reason.”

Jonas nods.

“In a sense, technology is a test for society. It enables us, allows us to cooperate, use agriculture to feed millions, make tools for others, have division of labour. But there is also a trap. We have moved from being a loosely-knit flock of do-it-alls into a tightly woven fabric of specialists.”

He nods, impatiently. “Yes. But we are killing off the specialists now. Now that we need them.”

“Yes, you see it too. These specialist skills are of paramount importance to our society. Once we have division of labour, there is no turning back. We no longer possess all the skills to survive without our neighbours. If the electricity suddenly were to go away, or the telephone suddenly refused to allow you to talk to the producers of things, could you survive? We have seen what happens in the great natural disasters that wipe out civil infrastructure. People become lawless and opportunistic savages again–just as the poor areas of the U.S. we are seeing now.”

He sees it. If trust in the delegation of responsibility breaks down, if the roles are not carried out properly, the system itself breaks down, and no one can fix it, because they no longer have the skills to do anyone else’s job.

Today, society is not just local, it is globalised to the point at which the entire world could crash if a part of the system ceased to work. As the Romans were fond of saying: society is never more than four meals away from anarchy. Perhaps that is what killed the dinosaurs, Sara might say.

“So you see that we are committed to civilization. We cannot go back to a simpler life, at least not without causing massive fatalities. But society is becoming lazy, dumbing down. We have invented technology after technology that makes us into passive, button-pushing servants of machinery, reducing real knowledge to simplistic, searchable keywords. In a few years, the dumbing down of school curricula will result in a consumer culture with no skills. When that day comes, there will be no one to repair the machines, no one to save us from the collapse. Without education, society is on a downward spiral to disaster.”

Jonas stares at her, half seriously, half wishing that she had picked any other day of the year to bring this to him. He cannot quite find the words to respond.

She examines his intensity, as if reading him. “Mr. Lindgren. I have been fighting for this belief for as long as I can remember. Sometimes when I lie down at night, I feel that I am helpless against this tide, as if I am drifting on a restless ocean, with no port in sight and no lighthouse to warn me of the rocks. And yet I think this: if a group of philanthropic industrialists can produce a counter-force to this senseless plundering of the globalized economy, then so be it. It is a fair fight.”

“In just a few years, the canvas of the world could be repainted,” he ponders. “Skill is easily squandered, and not so easily regained.”

He looks about at the scenery, which has reverted to their seaside balcony.

“But, there is a chance: it is not certain that the government can bring about their own plan. There are, in fact, rules and regulations that are getting in their way. Things don’t move as fast as they would like.”

“So you could delay it? Perhaps even stop it.”

“We’ll see. It would be a funny irony indeed if the Norwegian state bureaucracy were the ultimate barrier that prevented this plot from being implemented. Truly a clash of the titans: the irresistible force meets the immovable object.”

She smiles. “I like the idea.”

“If I can tie things up in process for a while and distract from the issue, it might not pass through the ministry for some time.”

“Politics is about timing. If you delay it, it could become unimportant to them. They might even change their mind.”

“Yes, a change of context could mean a change of priorities, yes. Perhaps it would even be possible to make them actively support research again with some kind of advertising campaign... ”

“This is what the game itself is about. This is why we are here.”

“A battle for the greatest cause.”

Jonas remembers where he is, in his overrun office, in the middle of a bureaucratic tackle for a ball that no audience really cares for. If he hadn’t invested so much of his life in science and the people who do it, he might be less inclined to put himself in the firing line. But this is his moment. Fate has handed him Excalibur and told him to save the world. He can at least try to save a few of its souls.

“You should have met my student,” he says. “This is really all just the theory of signals. She is an expert.”

“Then use her. Make people stand up for their survival.”

He can see himself as a knight. “A campaign to save education from the clutches of theocracy.”

“Remember to use your greatest asset: thinking. If, like the politicians and advertisers, you only paint in broad strokes, with a fat brush, you cannot go into detail–you are an impressionist. You might be lucky and get some of those details by chance, but your fortune is not in your hands. Wave a flag, pick a brand, sing an anthem... You need to be more specific to push the buttons.”

“And I even have an idea how... ”

“Our technology can help you. It was developed for searching for gene actions in humans, but it allows us to trace the channels of cause and effect in the actions of any information system. It is very powerful, and it is being used by the international law enforcement agencies already.”

“That’s how you found me.”

“Yes.”

“So you can unwind the ecological web.”

“In a sense, yes.”

“A mixture of delay and de-stabilizing the current policy.”

He experiences a feeling of satisfaction as if something has been accomplished. Remember the days when he was still a teacher, not just a bureaucrat? He used to measure the success of his time by whether anything was communicated, whether any deeper understanding was achieved, whether they had moved forward.

“So, if you see a colour that is too strong in your landscape... ”

“Paint over it with big whitewash stokes.”

She nods as if this was something she has always known.

“Just like Sara,” he says absently.

“I must leave this meeting now,” she says. “But I am glad we had this talk. Good luck with your work.”

Jonas makes a bowing nod. “Thank you. It has been a pleasure meeting you.”

“Yes,” she agrees.

“Perhaps we can keep in touch?”

The image dissolves without an answer and he is left staring at boxes and plasterboard.

Later in the day, as he walks out to the Lighthouse café, he thinks about their conversation again. How it all makes sense to him.

As he passes the demolition parking, he stops and looks at the cars with momentary surprise. It fades quickly into satisfaction and then laughter. Freshly fallen snow has transformed the randomly parked cars into utterly indistinguishable white humps of snow.

He mouths the words: “Told you so”.

Jonas faces the ministry’s administrator with as calm an expression as he can maintain.

“How can we expect to rely on people’s brains when we have been systematically erasing them for the last forty years?” he says.

In response to his media attention, the ministry has issued a statement talking about its reform of the education system. It will require a higher level of documentation and quality control measures to make sure that the stupid academics are doing their job properly, not just sitting around thinking. The ministry claims that kids are no dumber than before, and that they will rise to the challenges of the new decade. This diversion of research funds is a necessary and temporary step for humanitarian ends.

Jonas continues, “We are beating up our thinkers, drowning them in the syrup of administration and economic board games. The need for administration is viral. it is a self-sustaining process. Adding more formalia is like putting an eagle into a jungle and expecting it to fly.”

It really is true, he thinks. I am not just selling her point. Every day I get more post, more mail, more telephone interruptions. In the end there is no room for anything other than servicing the noise from others. When signal gets drowned in noise, we are lost.

“How can you expect me to sanction a change that will result in the abrupt demise of a young girl’s career?”

He has been bombarding the administrator with focused information about the consequences of the proposed change. He has read them diligently: Jonas was careful to present them with the proper protocols and procedures. And one has to give the man his due, his does his job properly and professionally, however misguided it might be.

He returns to him sometime later with a new set of procedures, from a different set of regulations.

“If you can fill out this form by the end of the day so that I have it by tomorrow morning, I can bring the matter to the attention of the European Parliament, who might be able to bear some influence on the matter.”

“You would do that?”

“It’s a legitimate procedure. It is part of your right of appeal.”

“I wasn’t aware.”

“This is why you need a professional bureaucracy to manage your affairs. Glad to be of service.”

Jonas smiles a little bit on the inside. You just never know what’s going to happen next.

Later Jonas feels sufficient optimism to risk calling Kaja. It is a long walk through the snow to her flat, but the cold air feels refreshingly appealing after what seems like a long day. She receives him with a suspicious scowl.

“Martin in with my mother,” she says.

He lifts his head in acknowledgement, and immediately regrets coming. Even on a day which has been about standing up to adversity, he does not feel strong enough to tackle her Kaja. Her beauty and temperament are a crushing combination.

“I need you to explain to me what happened last week. Why you disappeared.”

“It’s kind of complicated,” he mumbles.

“Why won’t you talk to me?”

He doesn’t know how to answer.

“Isn’t your son important to you?”

“Of course he is... ”

“What about me? Don’t I mean anything anymore?”

“Yes you do.”

“If you spent a little more time with us, I wouldn’t have to spend my whole time trying to call you and get you to do things for your son.”

“That’s not fair, Kaj. I try to find a good balance.”

“Oh, balance. Of course. Let’s not let us be too important, Jonas.”

“Kaja, I love you, but you make it quite difficult sometimes.”

“I love you too,” she says more softly. “But we need you to be around.”

“You have other people in your life, Kaja,” he blurts. “I can’t be around all the time.”

“That’s none of your business.”

“No it isn’t.”

“Had we been together, it would be different.”

“But we were together and it wasn’t.”

“You’re no better, Jonas. You act as though your needs are more important than mine, but you’re just the same.”

“I have work... ”

“Always working, yes. You never have time for us.”

“I have responsibilities, Kaj.”

“Don’t give me that bullshit. Fuck you!”

“Kaj... ”

“Your work is just more important than we are. That’s it, isn’t it?”

“Sometimes it is, yes. I have to make that decision sometimes.”

“Fine, go on then. Get out! Get the fuck out of here and go to your stupid job. I know it is more important to you than anything else – more important than me.”

“You know that is not true – but this is real. It is not your fairy tale world.” Why did he have to say that?

“Fuck you, Jonas!”

“Don’t exaggerate and get all upset.”

“Oh, so will you stay now? Will you spend the weekend with us now?”

“I can’t spend the whole weekend. We can go somewhere, maybe, tomorrow.”

“Well, perhaps that’s not convenient for me, Jonas! Maybe I can only do something tonight. Why can’t you just do something right for once?”

“I have to do something now. This has to be done by tomorrow, Kaja. Hundreds of people are waiting for this. They are expecting it, relying on me.”

“And I suppose you couldn’t do it in working hours? You had to wait until now!”

“Yes, actually. I was waiting for someone else to finish their part. So I couldn’t.”

“So that means it is not your fault if it is late. Why do you care?”

“It might not be my fault, but it is my responsibility.”

“And what about me? What am I supposed to do in the mean time?”

He shrugs. “I’m sorry, I’ll make it up to you.”

“Well, fuck you! Just get out!”

He looks mournfully at the floor for a moment and then summons himself to leave. He closes the door behind him and hears her scream and throw something at the space he has just closed between them.

Vibe is playing with the sims, toying with the characters like dolls in a doll house, as if she would ever lay her fingers on anything so prosaic. She prefers the challenge of playing with real people who don’t know when they are being manipulated, but there is no one suitable in range.

Preeta is working her own magic, collaborating with Dermot on some private channel that Vibe prefers to keep well out of. The guy is seriously weird or something, but Preeta seems to like him, so who knows. There is certainly no accounting for taste. Preeta has been unwinding the skein of intricacies in the information network and is gradually showing Vibe how the patterns form. She has been learning at an impressive speed, and they have grown together into a mutual admiration society of two. Several long days have passed getting to know one another while working on this problem.

Preeta feels like fate herself, tangling with the ley-lines of cause and effect. Something draws her mind back to that fanciful intersection from her journey: the child and the ice-cream. What happened to that child? Has his destiny been realized yet? Has he changed the world forever? Is there still some role for him to play to make his difference to the future? And what about her own role? Will she make any contribution to the world that yet remains to be acted out? She does not feel fulfilled yet. That, at least, must be a good sign?

All in all, for all their petty distractions and foibles and neuroses, the rag-tag team has been working well together. They have come together as an unlikely, if not unholy union, working remotely or closely as moods and neuroses dictate. But they have made several strides of progress, thanks mainly to high spirits. That has pleased Bishop, and attracted the attention of several others.

Vibe has been talking to Dr Lindgren now and then and he has given her his time with a willing struggle, lending her ideas and suggestions. He seems to have some new hobby-horse that has inspired them along their current path of action. Based on those teasing splinters and arrowheads, they are constructing a bow from which to launch their weapon, out of the spinal curvature of their sagging postures. It is nothing if not back-breaking sitting at these terminals, inspecting thousands of lines of meta-code, hour after hour. Dermot is king at this task, however, whoever and wherever he is.

“Dr. Lindgren is really going tooth’n’nail at this,” Vibe tells them, as they play. “He reckons I might not have to give up my PhD after all, if he can get past this next few weeks without letting dropping the reins.”

“Really?” Preeta lights up in sympathetic optimism.

“Actually, I have no idea,” she confesses. “But the thought is a good one, don’t you think.”

“Look on the bright side,” she nods. “It must be awful not knowing?”

She smiles. “I’m getting better at living with it.”

A disturbance wells up in the darker girl’s hind-brain. “Will you go back, if you can?”

Vibe regards her without expression from the corner of her eye. “I’ll think about it when it happens. For now, I’m having fun.”

Although she pretends not to notice, she senses the relief in the satellite bodies around her. There is no denying that she has found a niche here that works for her and for the others. It is as though she is the final spark-plug that released the energy of this little engine. They needed her, and she delivered. It is not often that one gets to be that appreciated.

Maybe I’ve been chasing dreams for too long.

“Don’t underestimate the value of serendipity,” Preeta says. “It is also possible to enjoy something that you haven’t chosen yourself.” She says it with a wink, but Vibe feels it as a slap in the face. Vibe looks back at her and ponders.

Hmmm. You think you know me, eh?

Perhaps she is right. It is not written on her birth certificate that she always has to get her own way. Maybe it’s okay to let someone else make the decision now and then. It can still be the right one. She smiles at herself, at her own prima Donna arrogance.

Look at it this way. If it works out for the best anyway, then you really did get your own way, right?

Nina has been hanging around them, watching and learning. She is the sorcerer’s apprentice, just starting as a student, but she has already found her two role models. There is little she can do, with or without Mickey Mouse ears or a pointy hat, but if enthusiasm were a key, then they would have enough of them to build a piano from here to Mars and back. Mostly she runs back and forth, watching the others at their work, oohing and ahhing. It bolsters their egos and keeps them supplied with drinks. Vibe’s casual characteristic of her was that of a badly fired rat, ricocheting helplessly about the walls of its maze.

Not everyone is so focused, however. There are other issues in the mix of this little group than the solution of Interpol’s socio-computational puzzle for the betterment of mankind. Vibe and Preeta have been colluding on their own projects. These two stealthy ginger cats have been spending time looking after their own destinies, scouting through the nooks and crannies of police databases. Just the previous night they spent searching through the Interpol cobwebs, looking at what is known about Kuala Lumpur; now they have now turned their attention to the Norwegian forces, or rather one in particular. Vibe has missing property to recover, let’s not forget.

It is not demanding work, but it has a certain thrill about it. This is hardly why they are here, and there might be questions asked if they are discovered. Fortunately, security is lax on the inside. The police database was trivial to access. It did not take long to find Patrol Pussy Radmila Eva Salberg, otherwise known as Jotunheimen Beat Bitch. She strutted her way down from the North or Norway; she has worked in Narvik, Alta and now she has been in the National Park area for two years. If official photos are to be believed, she is a regular beam of sunshine. More like moonshine, by Vibe’s reckoning.

She is good for a certain amount of gossip and tall storytelling, but it is an incidental pass-time.

“Never mind the beat bitch. Let’s find Frank,” Vibe shudders. He is, after all, her best approach after this time.

“Frank what?”

“Not sure. Try them all.”

“Ah, here we are. Frank Grøndahl. He’s kind of cute.”

Vibe flashes her eyebrows. “Actually, yes.” Then a different thought flushes her enthusiasm. Can you find Peter Green?

How would she explain him?

Someone I’ve sort of been obsessing over. Someone who tried to put his hand up.

Maybe better to let that one go. Can’t keep hanging on to a dead duck, or whatever the metaphor is in this situation.

“So what do you want to do?”

Why not just send a message to Frank. Kill two birds with one asteroid?

“We write.”

She writes.

Dear Frank, thanks for your kindness in looking after me during my stay in Jotunheimen. Sorry I didn’t get to say good-bye. Got called to an interview. Long story. So anyway, maybe see you next time I’m in town. Do you ski?

She seems to juggle with the threads of cause and effect as though they are her playthings. And, around her, the world neatly falls into place. Of course, it cannot really be true, and yet that is the unmistakable impression that she leaves.

And what of me? Preeta wonders. I have been a runner, not a fighter.

Part of her would like to emulate her new friend; another half knows that that is not entirely possible. You cannot capture someone else’s spirit and hijack it for your own. She has seen people try, and the result is neither pretty nor flattering.

She cuts a beautiful figure though.

Vibe is narrower of frame than herself and has a boyish kind of charm that makes her look both athletic and divine. No one could deny that she is attractive at many levels. Every motion of her body seems animated, filled with life.

I am a China doll by comparison, she thinks. Even with more make-up, I am less attractive. Because there is no beauty inside me. I am wax.

Knowing the reason does not necessarily bring catharsis, but modesty owes her at least a return on her meager investment; she will call in the favour when her life has shed some more its old skin. One of the succubi identified it, or vice versa, it’s hard to tell. It calls itself Mary Cheung and claims to be able to influence billboard advertising in certain environments. She seems to want to help them. If true, this could be a major breakthrough. Did she appear of her own free programming, or did their own seeds sprout? They will not have the answer to that for some time to come.

What is interesting is that this agent is also claiming something a little odd: that the best way to achieve their goals might be through a programme of freewill and induced thinking in the players. That seems to tally with Dr Lindgren’s latest rantings. It seems almost a little too good to be true. Vibe ran a factor analysis, using Preeta’s new software just in case someone has been pulling their sweet feminine legs. The agents seemed legit’.

So how do you start the world thinking? Mary Shelley’s Frankenstein tried a massive electric shock to the temples. Bea uses a cup of triple espresso filled to the brim with sugar, as a potion barely fit for consumption. Neither of these need go down well with Amnesty International, or even the international power conglomerates. What is needed is a yoghurt. A healthy new age alternative. Homoeopathic thought? Nope, too dilute to be workable. This will be the new-new-age yoga of the mind. Thinking had to come back in vogue eventually. Now they have to make people buy it like it’s going out of fashion.

“I don’t really care what we end up using this for,” Vibe relays to the room as she chisels away on her digital sculptures. “It’s just fun working on this solution.”

“You don’t know until you try it. That’s why we do it.”

“Yup.”

“Dermot has promised us a last-minute miracle.”

Preeta nods. “Yes.” Then she adds: “If he doesn’t, I’ll not make him mince pies for Christmas.”

“You hussy.”

The days and nights run into one another in the failing light of Oslo’s impending winter, and the group seems to be heading for a conjuction of physical and mental concentration. “This is a true conjuction,” Preeta decides. “That sounds pretty New Age, doesn’t it? Instead of a conjunction of the planets and stars, this is a conjunction of information flows and people.”

“Which we have engineered together to create a unique situation,” Jonathan crowns.

“A situation that allows a change to occur,” Bishop enhances.

“I belive it’s called punctuated equilibrium,” Jonas informs them.

“And evolution shall be averted for lack of a catastrophe for now.”

“All right,” Jonathan calls, “Snow machines at the ready.”

And, as they deploy their infectious mist, rolling it in from the great ocean of communication, it forms a wave of influence that seeps almost invisibly through the onion layers of the game. Changes begin to be seeded; perturbations destabilize the hybrid potentials. Even in the primordial mixture of characters and notions they have concocted, there is a new possibility threatening to emerge. It aspires to be the blueprint for that most elusive of creatures: success.

So now the real game is on.

The Senator’s limo careers rapidly through the Washington districts, pursued by a posse of paparrazzi journalists.

They are like a pack of rats, he thinks, or enraged chimpanzees seeking their pound of human flesh.

The senator views focuses on his aid, tearing his mind away from other things.

This whole recent business fills him with a deep sense of suspicion and betrayal. It is almost as though there has been some kind of conspiracy to turn the tables against them. Only a few weeks ago it seemed as though their plan was invincible, and people were ready for it. They believed in the church’s authority and its rightful place at the head of the country. Did we offend the press somehow? How did they find out about this?

Their competitors in government are rubbing their hands together in anticipation of imminent failure. The mobile voters were supposed to force the issue for them, but the game campaign has neither fully materialized nor been the overwhelming success that was promised. How much money did government spend on building this wretched white elephant?

And their little coup was to come as a surprise, and yet obviously they have known about the plan for some time. You cannot hide things from the secret service or the Three Letter Agencies.

What makes it worse? Despite the best efforts of his team, god-damned Senator Weisskopf is actually getting ahead in the polls again, trying to push for some hell-blazing school rehabilitation program. “Amen to that.”

Denial is a powerful medicine.

They’re not going to stop anytime soon”

In a situation like this, they are the masters of an empire of dirt. What are they going to coordinate into action, eh? Fifty years of the American people looking at government as their enemy, and we have an emaciated infrastructure. The country is collapsing from lack of maintenance, and all because Americans won’t pay taxes. If we were running the show, things would be different. You can say one thing about the church and that is they know how to manage their finances.”

“Yeah, diddly.” Dean is apparently succumbing to the influence. He seems like a huffy child now.

The aid lacks the heart to tell him that the invention is Japanese, perhaps because his cardiac account is already struggling with arrears. The car swerves around a bend and hits a bump which sends them flying into the air. The senator’s brandy spills on his leg.

“Why not”

Dean sits back in his seat without moving. The car seems to have stabilized and is driving smoothly on a freeway. There is a silence to chill the warmth of the car’s interior. It seems to beckon to the ghosts of past failures and invite the circling of vultures.

What is he talking about now? His voice has begun to take on a slight slur. Is it the brandy, or perhaps another minor stroke?

“Sir, are you all right? Do you need your medication?”

“Idiot!”

Dean stirs from his statue-like pose and leans forward. He seems to be staring into space.

“Gentlemen, this was eventually inevitable and I see no reason to panic. We have always had deniability. We have agreements with allies and we already have a scapegoat plan. The aid stares, momentarily disoriented by the sudden change, then quickly recovers. He is merely an aid, and even a rickety old imbecile cannot be ignored, or a mere aid might be denied his righteous place in the pecking order.

“So,” Ivar babbles, to fill a predicted void. “What are you going to do when this is all over?” He jabs his apple onto the end of a knife and thrusts it in front of Preeta’s mouth.

In the game, Vibe’s appearance is that of a stunning young woman, with a mere sheen of metallic spray to clothe her female form. Her skin-tight attire covers more her psyche than her avatar’s body. Dermot finds himself staring and Preeta is equally entranced at her audacity.

And that means, he will do what she tells him.

So, the ghosts and denizens of the game have become adept at manipulating their creators, Dermot thinks. It is not really a big surprise though, is it? After all, the game rules are designed with just that in mind. They built the ultimate propaganda machine: naturally it would work on them too. But unlike a gun, a weapon of destruction, it does not kill: rather it becomes part deus ex machina, taming its master.

In the dream, Dermot is riding a bicycle over a silver rainbow. He is being chased by a gang of bicycle riders who are throwing stones at him. He is riding away from an industrial street, long and straight, like a dockland. He can see a crane. Why is he here?

Something compels him to escape, an understanding that transcends any rational communication: it is something primal, something unspoken. His only chance to make it back to the safety of his apartment is to ride over this silver arc that crosses the bay. Yet it is only half a metre wide. He will surely fall.

The climb to the summit seems to be a struggle that gets harder and harder. His friends might fall from the arc, down into the bay. They do not hit the water, for the water isn’t there.

But then he is emerging from silver rails on the far side of the Hudson. Down the other side, he seems to be floating. He is frightened. He has to get to safety.

He is heading for a group of old student houses in the distance. He is alone now, no one is following him, but there is a supernatural danger, a feeling of ill-will, a stirring in his breast. The children who were throwing stones are no longer to be seen, but the memory of them seems now to be larger than the footprints they actually left in this world, on the other side of a bridge that has long since disappeared. The after-image of fear is amplified by the irrational need to get home and to escape an intangible force.

As he reaches the parking spaces outside the old Victorian London house, he knows that he is safe. No one will be able to penetrate this painted white square. He leaves his bicycle, throwing it to the ground. Now if he can only jump to the door of the house without being caught in by the force that is swirling in the atmosphere behind him he can run to his room and be safe.

Caught in a panic, he is locked into position by the fear of being trapped. The parking square might protect him, but he needs to hide.

He breaks free of his paralysis, as if a thread has snapped from something his clothing was snagged on. He runs to the old red door.

It is locked.

He bangs on the door for someone to let him in, but the door is locked. He runs to the next door, around the side of the house, but the door is locked. He finds a ground-floor window that is half open and climbs through the gap with a sense of urgency. The danger is surely right behind him; he has only seconds to spare. A swirling, invisible, plain, absent presence. What is he running from actually?

He falls through the gap in the window, landing head-first onto the floor of a small room with a shabby old English looking carpet. Beyond the room he hears the sound of voices. He lifts himself to his feet and begins to explore the mystery of the chattering. Through an open door, he passes to get to his room. To get to safety.

The house is a labyrinth of rooms. A door leads into another room of doors. Each room is a lounge. Each lounge is a nexus of doorways. If I were trying to get to my room, I certainly wouldn’t start from here! His room is surely a long way from here.

It looks as though a giant party is taking place. There is no sound other than the talking, the old electric lights are not subdued; the rooms are plain and undecorated. It looks like student accommodation. People are sitting around on the floor in every room, smoking things and drinking from cans. He wanders aimlessly, as if moving through a graveyard, searching for a soul he has lost. Perhaps it is his own.

We seek it here, we seek it there... Whatever the mystery is, it isn’t there.

He continues on through the house, and people start to pull at him, drawing him down to the ground where they are lying around having sex. He pulls himself free and continues on, up a narrow staircase and through a bedroom.

He touches the girl. She is tall and has long braided hair. She could be Cleopatra. Who knows?

He nods, unable to speak. Dermot and the girl are to be married, here and now.

YOU ARE A BEAUTIFUL PERSON!

LIVE LIFE TO THE FULL!

The voice of water being sucked down a drain.

She nods.

She shrugs. “It’s a long story. It doesn’t matter.”

“Good to have it back though?”

“My stuff is in here,” she affirms.

“Maybe you should check everything is okay.”

She nods. “Good idea.”

Vibe drags the sack into the living room and clips it open. She peers into what was her home for the better part of a week. The pack is quite full: soft items on the top, heavier ones below. She begins to empty the contents onto the floor around her, making an impromptu campsite.

“Making a mess,” she smiles, feeling a little as though she is undressing in front of him.

He seems to sense her discomfort. “Can I use your bathroom?” he asks.

She nods. “By the door.”

The contents of the rucksack appear to be intact. It doesn’t even seem as though anyone has looked through them. Pussy beat bitch was obviously just messing with her. Her tablet is there. It still contains some of the work she did before she left. It hasn’t been synchronized with home yet.
