She has crossed a boundary within herself these past weeks, an unexpected frontier of realization. Perhaps that is what it means to grow up, or perhaps it is the first of many changes in her life. It doesn’t really matter, does it? She has seen through the deceptions that life attempts to pile on. There will be no more romantic fantasies in her life from now on. There is a sense of ending, as well as a sense of beginning.

In the bottom of the backpack is a hard item that brings a new dread. She looks at the box from Mrs. Laurent. There it is. Her nemesis, in monolithic form. She could open it now. But does she need to? Does she want to know what is in it? Perhaps some things are better left unknown? She places it on a small table, where she can look at it, and ponders its form. What will she release if she opens it? How will it change her new life? A life that it working out well, which she is enjoying. Could she have both lives? Is that greedy?

Frank stands in the doorway. “Okay?” he says.

She looks at him. “Okay,” she replies with a trace of melancholy, and her throat contracts so that she has to swallow to relieve the ache of guilt.

Frank looked after her when she was sick. How many people have done that for her? Now he has come all the way here with her backpack, on the slightest of hints. And he is nice, in an odd sort of way: not really the kind of person she expected to like, but the fact is there. And he clearly likes her.

“You know”, he says, “it’s not that far to Majorstuen. Maybe we can meet up while I’m here?”

She smiles. It is only about a kilometre. “But you’re not staying long.” The words seem strange in her mouth as though she is not quite sure how to phrase them suddenly. Why did she even say that? What does it matter how long he is here for?

He didn’t ask to marry you, stupid.

“Well. It’s not that far to Oslo either, and I’m getting transferred soon.”

“Where to?”

“Guess.”

She smiles optimistically and then it fades. He looks down at his feet.

Vibe feels disappointment envelop and flood through her, in an instant. She has not really understood, before now, exactly what she feels about him. Their journey together has been serendipitous rather than planned, and all the time she has been distracted by a different, stupid romantic fantasy.

It is possible to enjoy something that you haven’t chosen yourself.

Frank seems to reconsider and stops himself. “Give me a hug?” he asks, almost apologetically.

Vibe explodes into a toothy grin and leaps up from the backpack, embracing him needily. More than he expected, he reciprocates hesitantly.

Damn it, she thinks, I have to take charge here.

She pushes back from him and kisses him firmly on the lips for several seconds before looking him in the eyes and grinning.

“Wow!” he laughs back in amazement. Then again: “Wow!”

They laugh and hug again and steal another kiss.

“See you soon then,” she says.

“See you soon, Sara.”

They part slowly with a glancing farewell, grinning like two stupid adult kids.

Boys! She smiles. So stupid, so necessary.

Sara Vibeke Stensrud looks up to the ceiling to take in the moment. She feels somehow lighter than before, and jumps up and down twice to test the notion. The future is there in front of her. She knows a way forward. Perhaps it is only one of many paths, or perhaps it is the right one. She doesn’t really care. It feels good and that, after all, is a good enough reason to follow it. Everything is going to be okay, she thinks.

Then, almost as an afterthought she remembers herself and smiles. Bea has got to hear this.

So then, out with the mobile.

It is May, soon to be summer, and all the trees are exploding with green and white blossoms. The heavy pollen-leaden odour of the bushes makes the air thick and hard to breathe.

Jonas is out walking.

For a few moments, he has time to be alone with his thoughts, thoughts that tumble amidst a garden of possibility, which borders on a landfill of corruption. He has brought a book with him–a novel, no less. He took it in virtual defiance of his pursuers. When was is it last he was able to read for mere pleasure? How long has he been shackled by responsibility, his pleasure centres immobilised by fatigue? All that could be about to change.

He settles onto a wooden bench in the glade of the park, in a spot where he can enjoy the still water of a nearby pond. These moments of rest will do him good before they find him. A few words of something other than project descriptions, or rules and regulations: it helps to quench the impatience.

The park is relatively quiet here, at this late hour of the day. Most people are already on their way home from work, but there are some here. A woman strolls past him with her child and he pauses to admire their harmony. One has to envy the look of placid contentment, the calm rapport she seems to have with the youngster, as if some inner telepathy soothes their companionship with complete and mutual understanding. It is not exactly the way he frames his own image of fatherhood, with Kaja. Others seem to make relationships work, why couldn’t he?

Perhaps there is a dozen reasons, perhaps there is only himself to blame. The time for judgement has, at any rate, passed. Now the challenge has become a different one: one of continuation, of redressing past mistakes and moving on with future possibilities. He has been compiling a list of things he owes Martin, and now that there is more distance between them, he is even interacting better with Kaja.

Jonas can imagine now how a glacier feels, thawing from its own private ice age: all that independent water, once in free flight, dragged down into a pool of anonymity, locked into bondage by the grip of an oppressive winter, finally feeling its spirit released by a kinder, warmer sun. It signals the beginning of a new cycle. To happen all over again?

Perish the thought.

The woman continues on with her child, smiling at that sun, without a visible worry in the world. He envies her. He actually envies her.

In her footsteps, something stranger still: a large bearded man, dressed in black jeans and rock-group nano-shirt, ambles comically into view. Jonas turn his head slightly to see the man stoop and pick up the ice-cream paper which her child has dropped. He places it, with visible annoyance, into a litter bin near the bench.

Observe this overt display of civic responsibility! It is cause enough to be taken aback. The man is not a park employee. He is an ordinary man, with no apparent connection to her. On the other hand, he is about the right age, about the right profile. Could this be the result of Edward Bishop’s work? Has this man been influenced in his thinking, in his attitudes by a succubus?

It is surely too early to tell who is responsible: whether the effect of their campaigning is measurable, or whether he is just an anomalous occurrence, a fortuitous anachronism of the modern world. However you look at it, this is a wonder to behold.

His mobile vibrates suddenly, with a simple message from Sara.

She replies simply: “The vice president was an algorithm?” He smiles at the response, uncertain whether she is joking or not.

Jonas posted a quote from a former Vice-President Al Gore: something about “the greatest discovery of all this research is that we can no longer can separate basic from applied science The disciplines are connected in ways they have never been before... ” It seemed like an appropriate encouragement of her current work at the time: something to keep her on the hook of expectation. The machinations of bureaucracy are not over yet as far as her PhD is concerned, but Sara is a survivor. She will do all right, no matter what happens next.

Jonas tries to open his book. He has a lot on his mind that wants to say its piece. Reading seems out of the question. Another good plan extinguished.

Soon, soon.

This apparently bottomless process of defending the institutions of research and education has been long and arduous. It has taken him through trials and ordeals of stamina that would break many. Another man might have crumbled before him, but he has been partially anaesthetised by his own personal conflict. Jonas has weathered the adversity with a brave face; but he also also senses that he has approached breaking point several times along the way, as a donkey’s back is broken under the incremental addition of an infinity of falling pieces of straw.

But why should he care about any of that today? Today, he could be the survivor himself. This could be it: the end of this little battle for his integrity. Now that the sun is shining, he no longer cares as much for the problems of office. He is purged by a pregnant sun and his own endocrine reaction. The burgeoning warmth of the day surrenders his worries to the realms of the academic, pun or no pun. And now also: a relative calm has fallen over his personal life, leaving him to feel unconcerned about the outcome of the final challenge: the one final obfuscation that will permit substance to triumph over style. Politics will surely have to accept reason.

But it is a delicate business, and not quite done yet. No wonder influence campaigns have to be planned so carefully: if the sun alone can cleanse an individual’s purpose and passion, what hope does one have of ruling anyone’s attention? Each little environmental signal is simply part of a grand regatta of impulses, sailing into the finish line, competing for the attention–for the prize of the human brain.

And if there were a god, he would have to be pretty disappointed that such a powerful and expensive instrument could be played so easily, by so trivial a troubadour.

It will not be long now. He had better put his book away and start walking. He will head towards the canopy of the trees to find some shade.

Jonas gets up from the bench and stands tall. More than ever, at this moment, he feels as though he is alone, but surviving. It gives him a taste almost of power, of self-confidence. It evokes an eerily surreal sensation. He feels taller, when he walks: he feels every step. It is dizzying. He feels larger than life somehow, hypersensitive. Motion is accentuated.

It is supremacy.

Mastery over oneself.

He takes no particular pleasure in the feeling. That might come later. For now, it simply is. He acknowledges it rationally and files the observation for possible use, like the orderly clerk that he is.

And then he comes to the little wooden bridge that bisects the pond.

He knows that they will have been alerted to his work by now, at the ministry. The final stage has to include them, as the EU commission challenges them to confirm their surrender of research funds against the basic guidelines of the community. And therein lay an unexpected pitfall for the government.

There is, of course, a difference between making the decisions and actually wielding the axe. Both turn out to be double edged swords, so to speak. If a bureaucracy can hinder the implementation of the research council’s independent decisions, then the council has an equal power to obstruct their intervention with bureaucracy. The mindless leviathan does not take sides, it merely lumbers with the obstinacy of habit. A commander of government can easily run aground on the perils of its own bureaucracy, for commanders generally trust their soldiers, under threat of execution, incarceration or even ex-communication. What will be his punishment?

He has seen through their game. The tune they dance to is one of short term gains: fast rewards and sound-bite press releases, neither methodical nor considered decisions. So, he has been learning the tricks of the trade and has moved his pieces carefully on the board to manoeuvre his opponent into a check mate. Shah mat! Die king...

It has ground him down, and worn him out, but he is still standing. So, at this moment, he has earned the right to be in the park, observing the young and the beautiful, without risking the guilt or repercussions that have haunted him over the past year. And, my goodness, the spring hatches these beautiful visions of womanhood from their cocoons in numbers. It does not matter that they are merely distant fantasies. To him, they represent hope.

For a moment he believes he sees Edward Bishop, but no, it is someone else. He has gotten to know the older man a little over the past months. He is looking older these days, but with a contentment about his work. Bishop claims that they have put a temporary cork into organized crime: mafia, vigilante groups, churches. Those organizations are opportunistic scavengers, who operate best when society is broken and fearful. If the game’s many signals were to heal and unite people, if it were to be a unifying force for good, strengthening and educating people rather than driving them apart, it would signal an end to their power. He is their worst enemy. Someone built a crooked house, and his team is straightening it out. The world of tomorrow will live in the House that Bishop built.

That the churches have not visibly succeeded in usurping the power from western states tells them that someone, somewhere must be playing their games: games that his team has spiked with altruism. It would make an interesting research project to follow who is doing what to make it all work, but they have to simply take it on trust for now. That’s fine. Somewhere in the world, pretty much anything you can think of is happening somewhere. That’s what diversity does for you. As long as the melody resonates, it will find its place in the symphony.

Bishop’s team is a bright constellation and they have helped him in unimaginable and intangible ways. Without them he might not have understood how to avoid the final move in his own game of chess. It was the Indian girl, Sara’s new friend who told him: “Why is it that you didn’t think of simply asking anyone for help?”

It was an excellent question.

Have we become so independent, so disconnected that we cannot even ask our friends and neighbours to help us out in a time of trouble?

People don’t ask each other for help anymore. His mobile doesn’t have a menu option for that. It took an alien to diagnose the malady.

What is wrong with us that we cannot even recognize and come together when we have common goals?

They have become Africa, as Joe said. Life is mercenary in a selfish world.

So he asked for help.

And Bishop’s bright constellation was happy to assist. He shrugged at the suggestion that he was being generous. “My voice has been heard,” he confided. “I’ve done my little recruiting campaign and we’ve put together a plausible new force. My little mission has been fulfilled. Where does it takes us? Just to the next phase. Maybe yours in the next phase.”

“What you’ve done will last, as long as there are people with skills to carry on the team,” Jonas assured him. “With people like Sara at the wheel, a little bureaucracy won’t be enough to stop it.”

They might never know what was really going to happen. But that is not really the point is it? The point is that it is happening all the time. It never stops. And they are just participants and spectators. It’s all one big fairground ride, where big splashes are really just little ripples. The game will continue with or without the VR. It has been running since the start of time. Right now, it involves the future of education and of society.

Jonas smiles.

Even after all this time, Den is still confused about the way Catalin Cortina treated him. He is puzzled over her rejection of him as a man. It is not as if he tried to seduce her, though even that would have been better than what transpired. He feels soiled somehow by his encounter with her, and still he cannot quite escape the need to repair the misunderstanding, to win her approval.

That vanity might be the source of his unease could not possibly occur to him, for he has never seriously understood why other people, inclined along alternative planes of thought, cannot simply extend their friendship with physical intimacy, as would he in the same situation. When people allow themselves to be seduced, either mentally or physically, everyone feels so much better afterwards. Why would anyone bother to abstain? It is like a cessation of hostilities, a bridge of trust–a private bond between souls, not some merely superficial chit chat.

Of course, this is simply the blindness of a man that comes about from an excessive focus on his own performance. He is the Ptolemaic centre of his own universe: everything else revolves around that focal point of self.

He sought to use Catalin Cortina as a fulcrum for his own ascension; instead she gave him homework to do, as if her were little more than a naughty school boy. Now he flips between wanting to do the homework, to please the teacher, and wanting to purge all thought of the woman from his mind.

A causal onlooker might find the predicament an unreasonable and trifling concern, and imagine him to be wallowing in an obsequious self-pity: but that is only because they do not fully know him, or even begin understand what makes him who he is. There are good reasons for his ambivalence. His inner circle has noticed how he seems encumbered by a melancholy, but one does not ask about the whys and wherefores of such things in this day and age.

More than anything, he is unsatisfied with his own performance. He does not feel that circumstances have allowed him to demonstrate his abilities. An omen of failure hangs over him now, like a thief swinging in the gallows. Oddly, that thought weighs upon him more than most. Is it a failure to impress? Failure to steer the course of things? What is it?

Kylie McLachlan has been supportive in her tangential way, making fun of him, at his expense. Her humour and casual courting will carry him through it; she is a friend. And sensing his resilience, in spite of his wound, she has refrained from rubbing salt in the real sore.

If Den has hoped to rule the world, then he cannot do it as long as he cares what someone thinks about him.

Den looks at the invitation on his tablet screen.

VASCON INTERNATIONAL COLLEGE INVITES YOU TO ATTEND
THE FOURTH INTERNATIONAL WORKSHOP ON
UNSUPERVISED LEARNING IN HUMAN SUBJECTS

Vascon. That’s her, playing with him. Teasing him.

He could grow to despise her for that. And yet he knows that she knows that he cannot strike back. The only way he could get back at her would be to beat her at her own game, and that is exactly what she wants.

He is most inclined to simply do nothing.

Instinct tells him: he can neither go forwards nor backwards, nor choose between the gods who have summoned him for their bidding. The only alternative is to stand still, to carry on business as usual. Den the player had been played. And yet, as a pawn in someone else game of chess, he will be discarded unless he is useful. Circumstances seem to have drawn the burden of responsibility not merely around him, but partially away from him; the religious factions have been backing off somewhat, in the light of recent and certain revelations (no pun obviously intended).

And, now that he is no longer their centre of attention, he feels oddly disoriented, as if he has lost his compass bearing. Have the church leaders and their stooges gone underground, into some doomsday crypt? Have they been arrested? He has not received a single word from them or about them. Nor has there been any direct communication from the government contractor, though that need not mean anything other than that they expect their job done. Perhaps it is time to make a mark that people will notice, once again?

Revenge? Pay-back? It would be a crude gesture, an unworthy gesture.

No, no need for that. The world needs directed imaging. He provides that service better than anyone. Therefore he is needed. It is the simple logic of commerce. So why does he not find comfort in the syllogism? However he shuffles his cards, he cannot help but feel uneasy: one day these government level contracts might come to a close, then it will be back to catching small fish.

For now, he will simply bide his time. Business as usual.

I don’t know how to do anything else, he thinks miserably. I don’t know how to be anyone else.

Besides, there is nothing like a pre-arranged routine to legitimise the avoidance of the present.

He flips further down his list of other messages, weeding out the advertising, until he comes to a report from his sister. She has been quiet of late. That is another thing that makes him uneasy. Mary informs him simply that the missionary herd is still moving forward through the game. Other than that, she is still engaged in some exploratory work, but nothing on that yet.

Yeehah. So the work of the church is still on-going, even if it has, for the present, been sucked almost entirely into the virtual realm. There is no stopping the word of the Lord. Somewhere, they are still out there, and you can bet that men in black suits will come knocking again. He is not sure whether that is a good thing or a bad thing. Perhaps she can negotiate his formal contrition with the gods of fortune, as long as she is out there.

Move on.

Further down the list is another note about the bio-tech giant: Vascon.

Vascon, Vascon, Vascon.

Companies rule the world today, but this is too much. There is no getting away from the head that roars loudest, unless someone from the office is playing a trick on him. The woman’s tentacles seem to extend like creeping roots across half the world, in some form or other. She is a genuine nexus of power, while he is merely a wanna-be yea sayer. She has both wealth and influence. She hangs in the shadows, lightly plucking the strings, while he is trying to tug away on them. And on top of that, he is unable to dislike her. He admires her.

Bitch.

What he needs is a rest. A rest–and to talk to the one person who can both sympathize with his feelings and advise him about his strategy towards Catalin Constanca Alexandra Cortina: Celia Waites. Yes, Celia.

Since bumping into her in San Diego, Den has found himself thinking a lot of her. She has qualities–several qualities–that he admires greatly. She is elegant, demure, sexy but vulnerable, and she has excellent taste. She was surely thinking of his best interests when she connecting him to Cortina. That must be worth something in return.

Suddenly he is swimming in a memory of their time together: a curious meeting of minds and body, but wholly satisfying, unlike his short experience with Cathy Kim. Where did she go?

But surely he has better things to do than to go half way around the world just to satisfy his conscience? Well, not just his conscience. She is a fascinating woman and he has a feeling that she will be glad to show him more than a few fascinating things about herself...

I don’t know how to do anything else. I don’t know how to be anyone else.

Den sighs with something akin to resignation, or could it be recognition?

“We have met the enemy, and he is us”, he recalls reading.

He looks down at his tablet and pulls up a list of things to do on his calender. Meetings, brainstorms, reports to write. It is all there: all he needs to fill his head with pointless emptiness. But that is not what he is going to do. He flicks through it all several times, up and down, looking at it with weary disinterest. He has formed a different plan, and he intends to say yea to it.

No more procrastination.

His clicks his acceptance of the Vascon invitation and it is mailed in return, then he pulls up his directory. And now he is going to call Celia.

Yes.

He will call her.

He is going to call.

He punches call.

Another doorbell warbles. The old door-com phone falls off its hook as he lifts it.

“Hi it’s Christina, can I come in?”

Christina? Dermot searches his mind to see if there is anyone–anyone else he knows by that name.

Christina? Surely not?

The search returns with failure and the inevitable conclusion sets his heart and mind racing.

“Yes, yes, of course.” He is shocked. Confused. “Come in,” he says, clicking the door opener.

The figure that meets him from the stairwell is a study in tragedy. She is a skeleton, thin to the point of malnutrition.

His imagination races through the possible causes. In a game, such a change could be the result of disease or hardship: a lack of points scored in earlier rounds. Could that also be the case here? Perhaps an eating disorder? Or poverty? She was never very good with money. She was never very good at looking after herself.

It is practically summer, but she is wearing a long black duffle coat to contrast with her blond pallor. Her face seems greyer now; it is not merely pale. She has lost something. It hurts him to see her like this: she is a dream that has developed a fault. A tragic fair angel.

“No, no.”

“I thought I would say hello. Is that okay?”

“Of course,” he says. “Wow. That’s great. Can I get you some tea or something?”

She looks into his eyes, searching his face with an almost tearful insecurity, as if she expects him somehow to be lying to her. “No thanks.”

“So how are you?” he musters, after too long an interval.

She smiles, uncertainly. She does not know how to answer. She simply shakes her head slightly.

“A lot of strange things have been happening lately. So many strange things.”

“What kind of things?”

She looks at him with that look again, as if she is saying: are you one of them? Her expression flirts with paranoia.

Dermot might not be a king in the realm of social relationships, but he can recognize the signs people make with their faces. He has always been better at looking than engaging. There is something wrong here. Something has happened to her. She is not animated in the same way as before. The parameters are different. Something is broken. And she is scared: frightened of what she might learn, from what he might say.

“Just things,” she answers and looks suddenly worried. “Where is everyone?” She stares ahead into space, occasionally glancing fearfully at him, as if to plead for his permission to be there. He considers how he might answer, and to which question.

“I don’t know,” he says simply. “Who?”

“It’s so quiet.” Then a shy smile flickers across her mouth, as if sensing that her worry is excessive. “So how are you?”

He nods. “I’m okay. Too much to do.” He laughs, trying to lighten the mood. “Always trying to do too much.”

“You’re pretty smart, aren’t you?”

He laughs again. “Well, I don’t know about that... Hey, do you still see that friend of yours?”

“As if anyone cared about me.” She sits, huddled into her duffle coat, thin as a rake, her hands deep inside her pockets. “What are you watching?” She points to the TV.

“News. I like to watch the news.”

“Is it war? A lot of funny things have been happening lately. It seems like we are at war sometimes.”

He laughs, but she does not return the laugh. He wonders if she really means it.

“Can I get you some tea? Are you sure? Would you like a piece of cake?”

“Cake?” She looks hopeful.

“I have some chocolate cake.”

She looks disappointed. “No thanks.”

“So do you still see your friend down in Little Asia much?”

She considers his question, as if dredging a slow computation from the bottom of her mind. Her eventual response is not what he expects.

“I like the Chinese. They are sort of peaceful–and smart. They had this great civilization.”

Dermot does not let go of his point. Perhaps she did not understand him. He knows that she visited a friend down near all the Vietnamese restaurants. She was always talking about it. “But you had a friend who lived down there. You used to visit him. Do you still see him?”

She looks at him, examining him as if she is looking for some sign of betrayal or as if he is talking a foreign language. Or is she blocking out his thoughts? It does not compute.

“The Chinese built the wall, you know. It’s supposed to be huge, visible from space. I’ve been going to the library you know.”

He nods. “That’s right.”

“I used to go to the Deichmann a lot. I used to read. I didn’t have anyone to talk to so I used to talk to the people in the books.”

“Yeah, it’s good to escape in books,” he injects, supportively.

“I like the library.”

“It’s been a while since I was in a library,” he thinks out loud.

“It must be a good thing to read a lot. You’re pretty smart, aren’t you?”

He shrugs.

“Everyone would stare at me in the library. I think they hate me there.”

Dermot frowns. “Hate you? No they don’t. Perhaps you feel that when you are depressed, but that doesn’t mean that it’s true.”

She smiles momentarily, happy at his answer, but then the infinitesimal intervention of grace crumbles into fear once again.

“Anyway, how are you?”

He nods. “Okay. Okay, you know. I, eh, am working hard as usual. Thinking of travelling now.”

“You have a pretty high IQ right?”

“I’m not sure everyone would agree!” he laughs, more suspiciously this time.

“You could be smart.”

She must be desperately lonely, he thinks, and feels a flood of sympathy for her now. He compares her figure with how she looked when he first saw her, when all he felt was blind yearning and searching admiration. It was he who was the misfit then. She looked so normal, so much more respectable than he did. Now look at her. What could happen to a person to transform them so? What could go so wrong?

“So do you have someone that you talk to regularly?” he asks,

“You mean the doctors? They are all bastards. They think they can just tell you what to do and manipulate you.”

Doctors?

“They put me away for a while.”

“What about your parents?”

“Parents?”

“Didn’t they live across the bay? In... what’s it called... ”

She shakes her head. “They’re dead.”

He frowns. They are not dead. He saw her together with her mother before he broke off his contact with her. Does that mean they are not talking to her? Surely parents would not abandon their child, not even a difficult one.

“Everyone is trying to manipulate you all the time, take advantage. It’s not fair.”

“Dead? How do you mean?”

“Doctors, pretending to care. They just take advantage of you.”

Dermot stores a dulled shock, as though someone is feeding a persistent and persistently painful electric current through his body. Has someone taken advantage of her? Is that what has tipped her over the edge? He is not sure what to believe. Earlier he might have been unnerved by the thought of someone even touching her, but his growing sense of disbelief has been dulled down even further with endorphins.

“That’s not good,” he says stupidly.

They sit in silence for a few minutes while she watches the images on the TV, and Dermot struggles to prove that he is not mute.

“Why is it so quiet?”

He flinches from his racing thoughts. “Sorry. My fault.”

“No, outside.”

He shrugs.

”No one is around. I guess everyone is staying at home. It’s Sunday.”

“Is it Sunday?.”

“Perhaps they are on holiday somewhere. Holiday.”

“It’s weird, I mean without people. Is it a war?” She picks up a leaflet on his coffee table and looks at it. “Are you joining the church?”

“Eh, no. I don’t know.” He takes it from her and packs it away at the bottom of a pile of papers, embarrassed. No one is supposed to see that.

“Someone told me to join too,” she says.

“Maybe it would give you something to do?” he suggests. A church would at least give her someone to watch over her, something to be part of.

She shakes her head fearfully.

“Bad men.”

Dermot exhales, sensing an incumbent heaviness prey upon him. He resets his mind, and summons his strategic faculties, realizing that he bears no emotional debt toward her, but somehow feeling culpable. If the visit is disturbing, it merely confirms to him, once and for all, that he has made the right decision to walk away from her all those months ago.

Pausing to chew his upper lip, he glazes over and extends into what seems like a space behind her face, for a long moment, looking both through and beyond her into his future–into her future. His imagination is easily up to such prediction; he is used to making such analyses in games. And for a moment it is as though time passes before him and a possible future it played out. It is a future that he has seen before and which he knows only too well. It is something that confirms his belief that truth can be stranger than fiction and it holds a terrible fascination for him. It is the impossible, and he has made it the forbidden: an image that frightens him and fascinates him in equal measure. He beholds it and acknowledges it. Then his wandering mind gradually re-contracts back into the most immediate present, where she is trying not to watch him stare.

He makes his decision.

Dermot takes her out to a local coffee shop and buys her something to eat. He is not sure how else to make her leave, in a nice way. He tells her that he is expecting a visitor soon and that he has to return home.

“I should get back home soon.”

She nods. “Everyone in the flats pointed at me you know. When I came.”

“Attractive girl like you. They might look to catch a glimpse of you.”

She smiles.

“It’s quiet. Are you sure it’s not war?”

He looks at her head, so close to his, her emaciated face, her malnutrition. Inside there is a brain, somehow damaged. What connections are missing from her program to so distort her view of the world? What perceptions have emphasized the poor judgement?

Is it the result of lethargy, inaction? Is it due to drug use, or lack of it? Is it a trauma that has shut down some crucial circuit, or perhaps a conspiracy of parts in her brain that have fragmented into independent, schizophrenic agents, all competing for dominance, and all of them losing. On top, there is still a remnant of her former beauty. She could be beautiful again. She has the framework, but not the support.

If he were to provide some sufficiently strong, unifying message, could he steer her confusion back into some form of integrated sanity? It is a powerful idea. They have done it for society, with the team. If they can do it for society, could they not do it for the society of mind? If he took her and retrained her in basic skills, like a dog, could those brain connections be re-established? Could she return to her former state of grace?

“Your guest is coming,” she says. “Bye then.”

He nods.

“Come by sometime,” she says.

She walks off into the distance and Dermot wonders what he should do. She does not look back at him, she simply walks off in the wrong direction for going home. She has become a phantom, a lost soul.

Can she be repaired? he wonders.

He balks at the thought. Involvement would only mean a script for his own cerebral imbalance. She would drag him down like a lead balloon towards a black hole.

Dermot walks back towards his flat. He will play some music and consider the matter. For now, his logical mind serves only to inform him that his decision to keep to himself is both justifiable and correct. Getting to know people is just too dangerous a sport for someone like him.

One is better off alone.

Dermot closes the door behind him and tries to forget the incident. If he sees her again, he will deal with it when the time comes.

A few years from now...

and society’s addiction to mobile phones and personal consumer electronics is beginning to drive a wedge between traditional, community structures all over the world. Citizens no longer talk to their neighbours; they connect only to buddy-lists and address-books. Society is dissociating into little more than groups of rival gangs, with little respect for authoritarian government or the rule of law.

“Dumming down” and dropping out—people have become spoiled and greedy as they watch the tumble drier of commerce process an existence that is going nowhere. So much for the knowledge-based economy—spoiled consumers barely remember how to charge their mobiles.

In a desperate effort to cement new public loyalties and consolidate fragmenting government power, American media giant PhoxHollywood is tasked to create a carefully crafted computer game, virtual-reality world called simply ‘the game’. It is free for everyone on the planet and it entices humans to meet and interact as never before. But the game’s moral agenda attracts unwanted attention from the press who claim that it is merely a front for Whitehouse propaganda. When a religious group moves to secure its own share of the power, an unlikely constellation of citizens, from around the globe, interested only in their own futures, unwittingly find themselves pulled together by circumstances, and playing a game of their own...
